Frankly Cowboy Bebop suffers from its age.
Its got great music, and good animation. But its clear the story and more importantly the animation are limited by the tools available to the studio at the time.
The fights are great and are probably the biggest reason to watch the show, but their so few and far between you can count them on your hands and all in they probably total ten minutes of the whole show.
The music is also really good. It both suits the anime and is enjoyable on its own. Not every track is something I'd enjoy but it all works.
But problems start to emerge
                  with the episode format and the characters.
Each episode follows the same exact thread; new bounty guy shows up, hi-jinks ensue as the Bebop crew try to catch him/her, new character joins the team, plot twist happens to keep the Bebop crew from getting paid, and then bounty guy or random new character dies and everybody is sad.
Every. Single. Episode. And it really doesn't work, I don't care about anyone these characters only get a few minutes of screen time each and then just die for cheap shock value. 
The cast also aren't much better. Jet never really does anything, Faye is just plain annoying, Ed exists to be either a Deus Ex Machina or deliver info dumps, and Spike.
A lot of people really like Spike. I'm not one of them.
He comes across as completely arrogant, like he's too cool to give a damn about his friends or anything. 
He's so unsympathetic and detached that it really makes it hard to root for him, especially when he's ditching the Bebop crew for the sixth time to go do some random thing.
The final issue is one that I admit is very personal and probably wont effect anyone else but its still the one that kills the show for me. 
There is no real sense of stakes. The Bebop crew is always getting beaten up, their ships wrecked and their bounties escaping. But they never suffer anything for it. Oh sure they complain about a lack of money and food. But it never amounts to anything. There is never a moment where they are bared from doing something, ANYTHING because of the constant losses they suffer.
In one episode they establish that in the whole universe, there is one guy who can work on Spike's personal space ship, parts are getting rarer and the repairs are complex and expensive. Then at the end of the episode Spike sheers both wings off the thing and utterly beats the snot out of it.
And in the next episode the ship is completely fine, restored to the same condition it started the series in.
In the third (I think) episode Spike gets shot like five times and launched out a forth story window . And he's completely fine. No long term injuries or anything.
It just really makes me feel like nothing is at risk. I can't feel broke up at the end because the team has been shown to rebound from similar situations in the past with no difficulty too many times. 
I'm not worried about how Jet will fix the Bebop because their ships have been magically fine in every episode. Spike has survived worse injuries than a single bullet and sword cut. Faye is dumb and I don't care about her memories. Ed is the only character I really cared about but she was dumped from the show 3 episodes back for no real reason and no one else showed any concern for her so why should I?
It really lets the show down. Music's still bangin' tho.

Overlooked classic I never watched lived up to it's fame and a OST I fell in love with.
Story: Bounty Hunters in space, while this isn't something that has been touched in fiction before I feel it does it the best. At times it's vague, which it doesn't need to be detailed with certain characters past not being completely explained till later adds to the mystery of some of them and the over all events that lead them meeting each came together pretty well. Had the right amount of comic relief and tension not many shows I feel do it this well no over zealous comedy
                  and it was serious when it needed to be.
Art: For it's time the art is top notch, the environments are well designed, characters aren't all copy-pasted templates they are unique looking. Gives a nice mixture of the wild west, and space mashed together.
Sound: I loved the OST so much I ended up getting it for myself. I'm a fan of jazz, and Cowboy Bebop does it well. The opening song is pretty spicey and smooth got to say it's one of my favorite Opening OSTs to date. Tank, Rush, Space Lion, etc never get's old listening to them.
Characters: The main characters work well together, from the chaos to the sad moments it feels like one of the better choices for bunching them together. Even a lot of side characters weren't dull and many times I was wishing I would see some again. 
Probably the best space bounty anime there is, and it left me wanting a little bit more feeling it ended to quickly.

---------------------------------------SPOILER FREE
I usually dont write reviews because if the show is good i just enjoy it and if the show is bad i just ignore it... but its been long since a show ending was so stupid that made me angry..
CB in general is a story with no real meaning behind it more than show the adventures of the most incompetent ream i've seen since Team Rocket, they fail on almost every job making every episode a repetition that make you facepalm over and over and over again.
Sometimes they throw some flashback about characters but that's it, they dont really go deeper than that, until
                  you reach episode 25 and suddenly the story matters and they rush it so bad that the amount of story wholes they leave behind is so big that make me regret starting to watch this show in the first place and i dont wanna even start to talk about how the story ending developed.
I really entered this show with positive hopes and ended up disappointed in a way i didnt think possible. I can now say i really REALLY dont understand what people like about this, it really doesnt deserve the 8 it has, not even a 5 and if im really realistic not even a 4.
i really wanted to like this show and even when i was half way through and i wanted to drop it because of how unentertaining it is, i didnt because i really thought i was gonna finish and at least say "you know what, after all, it is not a bad show" but i cant, i really cant.
Dont watch this show, not even because you wanna say "yeah i watched it", is not even worth that.

First off Cowboy Bebop isn't an anime that really needs a review; its success says it all. No matter what you might think about it just hearing about it, this anime really draws you in with its characters and holds you firmly planted in front of your viewing device. Its cleverly placed comedic moments perfectly balance out the overall seriousness of the situations. Its full of action while still having the occasional bit of crack that we all love. In the end, its an anime I would recommend for every fan to watch as a classic of what makes a good anime.

It seems pointless to review Cowboy Bebop given that in the past 20 years it's been hailed as most likely the best anime ever. And I certainly don't have much to add to that assessment, but I will add my thoughts to the collective wisdom.
First, the art. I absolutely love the retro 60's Golgo 13 inspired style on the landscape and vehicles. If you grew up watching Japanese cartoons from the 60's and 70's like I did, seeing that style updated in such as cool and futuristic way is just the shit. It really contributes to the sparse, lonely atmosphere of the Bebop universe. Just
                  as Japanese cartoons in the 60's and 70's were sparse and bare out of necessity - it was expensive to hand animate everything so they relied on techniques such as panning the camera over static images - the same aesthetic works here.
The characterizations are top notch. Spike, the not-so-bright but very stylistic ex-gangster trying to eke out a living as a "cowboy" bounty hunter. Always right on the edge of success but somehow living with failure right in front of his face. You underestimate his skills until he puts them on display and you sit and watch in disbelief as he deftly eviscerates his quarry. I'd cry if my eyeballs hadn't already melted out of their sockets.
Jet, the mysterious ex-cop owner of the Bebop. Has a, let's call it "complicated" relationship with Spike and Faye. Hates how much he cares about Spike and relies on his comradeship. Just a guy trying to make a buck in a crazy universe stuck with a bunch of assholes that don't respect him or carry their weight, and he wouldn't have it any other way.
Faye, the femme fatale. Saddled with the soap opera trope of a lost memory, she has become more than the sum of her missing parts. Faye is fiercely independent, completely capable, and the prototype for the modern female lead character. Completely owns every scene she's in and I'd call you a liar if you said you wouldn't watch the shit out of a solo Faye series.
Ed - whatever the hell Ed is - the chaos monkey that knows everything and nothing all at the same time. Where did she get those skills and how does she always manage to tempt fate and synchronize her life completely the opposite of the forces of death to stay alive? We'll never know, unfortunately.
Music: if Cowboy Bebop is legendary for one thing, it's the music. From composition to performance the music is timeless, flawless, and incredible. Do yourself a favor and listen to the soundtrack. 
Favorite episodes: the one where Ed feeds the rest of the crew the magic mushrooms to see if they are safe to eat. Hilarious and sad to watch all at the same time, you feel bad for laughing at Spike's Sisyphean walk up the unending stairs - nah, you don't feel bad. Other favorite episode: Faye's tape, Spike and Jet crawl the bowels of the crumbling city to find the ancient electronics museum and bring back a Beta instead of a VHS. Spike's insistence that it would work if Jet just crammed the tape in the slot the right way is every human's struggle with technology ever. And so exemplary of Cowboy Bebop - a story makes us both laugh and cry with the same breath. 
Please watch if you are a human being that appreciates having your life and spirit enriched with the twin gods of happiness and sadness.

Cowboy Bepop
One of the most popular and well-known works of the older generation. I didn't grow up with it and never saw or heard of this series in my younger days. It wasn't until this year that I watched it for the first time on recommendation and was pleasantly surprised. 
The anime adaptation of Cowboy Bepop was especially convincing in the detailed realization and illustration of the Sci-Fi genre. Through this, an immensely detailed world was constructed, even if there was virtually no world-building, so the individual detail was in the foreground. 
Furthermore, the anime possesses very impressive and likable characters that have both individual
                  character backgrounds, as well as ambitions. This was well embellished by various amusing conversations and the interaction of the characters. 
However, beyond all the positives, Cowboy Bepop also has certain flaws. First and foremost, this series has a relatively mediocre plot that is not convincing in any way. Very slow pacing and it is relatively episodic.  70% of the anime are only based on small experiences and bounty hunts. 
[Story 4]
The story mostly revolves around the everyday tasks of Jet's crew, who somehow try to keep themselves on their feet by taking on various missions. Unfortunately, luck is not on their side and they usually come up empty or cause more damage than they deserve. 
Along the way, you get to know the respective backgrounds of the 4 main characters and learn where fate will take them. Especially the background of Spike, followed by Fraye were in focus here. Spike's future as well as past with Julia, symbolically formed the rest of the plot and how he wanted to face Vicious.
Overwhelmingly, the result was disappointing, as there was almost no tension and the plot between Spike and Vicious was relatively monotonous. Julia was just an empty shell until the end and the finale resulted in a very weak climax. On the one hand, it's interesting to see how quickly and spontaneously this ending developed. On the other hand, you couldn't get anything out of it. Which left Spike's arc and the actual plot with an average ending.  The extremely slow pacing didn't help the whole thing much.
My favorite were the 2 episodes about the fridge and the mushrooms. 
[Characters 7]
The series was based only on the focus of 4 main characters. The respective side characters that one met in the course of the plot were relatively simple. They had small backgrounds and there were no great developments.
Vicious, who was the main antagonist of the series, was practically a pushover. He was built up with much more drama than he had in terms of influence and character. Compared to the 4 protagonists, he practically disappeared into thin air. 
Faye had the most individual and interesting character arc, which was very much about her personality and development, making her undoubtedly the best character. 
Spike is my personal favorite and I liked his personality a lot, even if it became very dull and linear in the long run. He reminded me quite a bit of "Patrick Jane" from "The Mentalist".
Jet had a rather simple background, but in my opinion, he had the strongest and most emotional personality, a real Tsundere as it should be.
Ed was mostly a comedy character with a relatively small but significant background. As a humorous character, however, she was more suitable. 
In the end, the characters have been the biggest strength in this anime, through their balanced personalities.
[Animatioen 9]
I was especially fascinated by the backgrounds and their detailed designs, it's been one of the most beautiful post-apocalyptic worlds I've seen.
The actual animations have been very dynamic. 
[Music 6]
Quite a short and individual intro which certainly lingers in the mind, how simple and crisp it was. Musically nothing earth-shattering, but that's not what matters.
The Osts have been very rare and were scattered very scarcely over the series to give respective moments more momentum. This also resulted in many moments lacking atmosphere.
[Conclusion.]
Cowboy Bepop is remarkable for its age and has stood the test of time and has a very good reputation in the community. For me, too, it was an interesting experience to have watched this anime. However, one thing is clear here. Cowboy Bepop has a much stronger appeal to the audience through its character than through the actual content. Although the series has been relatively empty, especially the characters have entertained me very well. 
Whether I will be able to watch it again, however, is unclear. 
[Enjoyment 8]

This is one of the best animes of all time. It's got great animation, designs, and story. The soundtrack is so energetic and downright a master piece, the opening is so iconic and catchy. 
I'd say the story itself is pretty unconventional, since the main plot is hardly ever touched until the last 3 chapters. But despite that, you get so attached to the characters that it doesn't even matter, and the world building is good enough to keep you engaged.
I watched this during quarantine and it was one of the best experiences of my life, I hardly recommend it. The vibe this anime has
                  going on is indescribable. The world is so believable, and the characters are so fun and badass. The battle sequences are magestic, and just, everything is great. It will win your heart without you noticing, until you realise you're in the last episode and it will all be over. It's a must watch.

Wow. If a review starts with a word normally assosciated with epicness or being left speechless, such as wow, it's a pretty good indicator the product, in this case Cowboy Bebop, is going to be fantastic. Believe me, this is one space oddessy you don't want to miss! Let's get on to the review:-
Story:- Hmm, aahh, what? Yeah, the story is a bit... Mixed, to say the least. I'm 98% certain there's an over-aching story, but most episodes have their own story, which I liked. It meant each episode "wiped the slate clean" for want of a better phrase, and made each episode original. One
                  I particularly enjoyed 
*SPOILERS AHEAD, DON'T READ IF YOU HAVEN'T WATCHED!*
Was the VHS tape episode, as, it being set in 2071, Spike and Jet had no clue how to use it until they found the 20th C tech otaku. Found it hilarious!
*SPOILER END!*
So yeah, the "umbrella" story I don't know and don't really understand, but you understand who the good guys and the bad guys are to get a general grip of the show when it comes to it's climatic end. 8/10.
Art:- The show was produced in 1998, and wow has it aged well! Honestly, I mean, there are many space scenes reminiscient of star wars, with all the lasers and guns in space, but from a hand-drawn perspective (which, of course, the show is set in) I just can't believe the amount of detail! There's all the little control panels in the many ships through the series, to the sprawling landscapes of the different (alien to us) worlds. Speaking of worlds... 9/10.
Character:- Oh. My. God. The character in terms of the "feeling" of the show and the characters themselves were outstanding. As I've just mentioned, the worlds themselves are brilliantly both familiar and alien. The story is set in 2071, and while this seems like an age away, the late teens to mid twenties guys and gals, myself included, this is going to be in our life-time. We'll be old and decrepit, but alive (hopefully). That Tanabe chose this year, that is, so far yet not too far, is brilliant, as it does mean that it strikes that balance of familiarity and unknown. 
Now, the characters themselves. There are many characters, but I'm just gonna touch upon the four protagonists, from my least favourite to my most. Firstly, then, ED. F*cking Ed! Ed is a, hmm, I'm gonna go around 10 or 12 year old girl, who, in classic anime fashon, looks like a boy. One thing that makes him not a boy is the voice! I cringed and had to turn my volume down every time she went hyper which is, well, most of the time. I like her character (a sort of hyper tech otaku) but it was just the voice, in both sub and dub (I watched the show in sub, before a friend recommended dub. WATCH IT IN DUB ENGLISH VIEWERS!). Second is Faye. Faye is a beautiful woman who joins the Bebop (the ship, y'know, space ship, because it's set in space. OVER-CLARIFICATION FTW) team quite early in the show. I had a big break halfway through the show, but I think she joined around episode 10. She jumps in and out of episodes, being prevalent and then not so much, but she's the woman of the team, and is quite strong-willed, witty and just adds the sense of humor achieved by a woman character. She doesn't follow the traditional women view in anime, which is great!
Next, is a two-way tie, so I'll cover both of them. Spike and Jet, our main protagonists. Jet is Spike's mentor. Not much is known about Jet (except a couple of background episodes, which are NOT flashback episodes, which is always good) but he becomes a loveable character, being a very fatherly figure and caring towards all his crew. I think he owns the Bebop, so he cares very much about the ship too. He also has a fascination with bonsai trees, because why not. Every anime character has to have a wierd fetish, rule #1. For Jet, it's bonsai trees. Hey, he runs the ship, helps out his crew, and cooks. You gotta let him have his moments.
Lastly, is Spike. I love Spike. He is brilliant. He is a 20-something bounty hunter, and uses his guns, martial art-type moves and quick witts to get him out of his many skirmishes he encounters. Despite being the main protagonist and having some "bone-head" moments, he's actually the most philosophical of the team. I'm rambling on and don't want to spoil him, so I'll leave it there. 10/10.
Sound:- I realize I am rambling on , so this section is going to be short and sweet. All you have to do for this (AUDIENCE PARTICIPATION!) is go on Youtube and type "Cowboy Bebop OST" and then sit back, with a optional beverage and snack, and enjoy. You will not be disappointed, trust me. 10/10
Enjoyment/Overall:- As you've been able to read, I love this show, and will ever be in debt to my best friend who introduced me to the series. However, along with Ed, I have one nitpick. IT'S SLOW! My God, does this show take it's time! Once you get passed, say, the 8 minute mark, it's fine, but this show takes it's sweet. sweet time to get up to speed, then, as per usual, you lose yourself, as you will do in a fantastic anime. Other then that, this is a beautiful, jaw-dropping, action-packed and sometimes sentimental show that will have you laugh,cry, punch the air and rock in the corner all in the space of 5 minutes. Not just a beautiful anime, but an inspiring experience. If ever there was a show to reccommend, it would be this. I can't say it's my favourite, not just because I may find a new favourite, but because I all ready have one, but this is a very close second. Thank you, Tanade, Thank you, Spike, Jet, Faye and even you Ein, Spike's dog. Thank you, Cowboy Bebop. 10/10

A timeless Anime Classic on par with older gems like the vaunted 'Akira'
One of the finest pieces of television anime ever produced, with superb writing and genius characters. Cowboy Bebop is a powerful narrative with great action set-pieces and masterful noir detective mysteries. The protagonists are a wonderful band of bounty hunting rogues who are full of their share of secrets, in a Solar System filled with bandits and rogues, that the Bebop crew bands together to hunt for the rewards to survive the harsh solar realm of the series. The fantastic worldbuilding and great musical score are complemented by superlative artwork in an anime,
                  which in most respects is rather flawless.

So for my first review I decided to tackle one of the most hyped and well regarded anime around. Hope I'm not being too ambitious.
Cowboy Bebop is, in one word, cool. Everything about it is cool: the soundtrack, the art style, the characters... everything. But the amount of coolness can not hide some of it's problems. It is an overall pretty good show but I found it somewhat lacking in some aspects. So lets start with the things I enjoyed and them move on to what I think it could have done better.
First, I should say that it took me a long time to make
                  up my mind about watching Cowboy Bebop. Even though it was recommend to me endless times, I just couldn't get over the fact that it was a rather old show and that the animation would suck - I'm someone that easily discards shows if I don't like the way they are animated. But it turns out I was wrong! The animation has hold out pretty well and it has something very stylish about it. The character's designs are great - except for Faye's awful even though iconic yellow suit - and the whole universe is full of charisma. The soundtrack is just as great, having one the best opening songs ever - hell I'm listening to it right now just to get pumped to write this review.
The episodes are very entertaining, full of action and funny moments. There are also a few more dramatic episodes and others where you can see they were trying to mimic or mock some genres, which adds to the show. There's some variety to the characters which is a plus and their iterations with each other can by very funny to watch.
But for such an iconic show I was expecting a little bit more of a story. Truth is that in all of the 26 episodes maybe 5 or 6 of them really matter for the plot. Every other episode just repeats more or less the same formula: there's a bounty to catch, Spike, Faye and sometimes Jet go after it, they all get in each other's way, they manage to catch it (or not) and in the end are still broke because they have to pay for all the damage they made. It is entertaining to watch but at some point you start to expect a bit more.
The characters don't really help much in developing the story either. Even though they all have at least one episode dedicated to them individually, they don't really change. Faye is the most frustrating one, having such an interesting back story and not really changing when she finally finds out what she wanted to know.
There are a few episodes about Spike that hint to a very complex and interesting story. This actually seems to be the plot the whole show was supposed to revolve around but it doesn't. This leads to a last episode that even though is cool and has fun action scenes, just seems like it came out of nowhere. In the end none of the characters learned anything and, even though they might have started to care for each other, they don't show it.
I might sound overcritical towards a show that I rated pretty high. The thing is that a see the amount of potencial Cowboy Bebop had. Every episode is entertaining but when it leads to nothing, even though it seemed it wanted to lead to something, it is a bit frustrating. If it was just a show about the daily struggles of the cast I would be completely fine with it. But when it adds Spike's darker story and tries to pass it as a main plot point even though it is brushed off for most of the show I just get confused. I think Cowboy Bebop could lose that whole plot and be just as good, if not better.
But overall, this is a great show that you will certainly enjoy and have fun with. I guess the best way to watch it is just to forget about the hype and not take the story too seriously.

This anime will always have a top spot among GAOAT (Greatest Anime of All Time). Some of the reasons why are clear... a very gripping set of sub plots in each episode that sometimes linger on to the next episode and sometimes are not seen to have lasting effects in the character development. Part of this lack of roll-over into characterization adds a mysteriousness to the tone of anime. This is one of the main reasons why Cowboy Bebop will forever remain in anime watchers' hearts. An amazingly crafted overall tone that intertwines with the plot, leaves strikingly unique characters that in our present day
                  are imitated by cos-players regularly. 
The themes in the anime were not that of minor ideologies, but delivered strong themes that could cause drastic changes in people's lives. I couldn't imagine that this anime has not changed many peoples' lives in regards to how they think about life. The creativity for the sub-plots is congruent to an author's dream to write a whole book that would inspire readers. But Cowboy Bebop is able to deliver stories of similar impact in a single episode. All this is done in a futuristic world with old-school animation where the ideas for technologies and methods of doing daily tasks requires true creative genius.
Returning to the reason why Cowboy Bebop is so influential, a single reason cannot actually explain its impact, but a good watch of the anime should be able to do the trick. heh.

A true classic. Cowboy Bebop is a sort of slice-of-life anime about retro futuristic bounty hunters in the 2070's attempting to keep food on the table and nab their next head. Warning, very biased review.
Story: 10
Fantastic, as I said, it's mostly slice of life, but don't let that dismay you (unless you love that sort of thing, like I do), for each episode has a fun to watch adventure (or non-adventure, I suppose) that really is delightful.
Art: 10
I find the griminess of its 1990's animation somewhat endearing and very pleasant to look at, even if it might not be as clean as the modern art
                  style.
Sound: 10
Tank! is an iconic opening, if I've ever heard one. And Real Folk Blues is a great ending, as well. The voice acting (dub) is one of the best that I've heard, each voice fits the characters very very well.
Character: 10
Their characterizations are very well-done, quirky, and overall incredibly enjoyable to watch them interact with whatever the situation is.
Enjoyment: 10
I watched the first two episodes and let it sit for about six months before picking it back up again, promptly devouring the rest of the series post-haste. I loved it to bits and miss the characters already.

Having watched Cowboy Bebop for the first time back in the early 00s, I was really curious to see how it would pass the test of time. After all, not all great series have the same impact on you on a second run. However, this was not the case for Cowboy Bebop, a series so brilliantly crafted that it really makes you reconsider the quality of some of the shows currently airing.
In my opinion, characters are one of the most outstanding aspects of this show. With four main leads, it would have been easy to make them stick together all the time and create one
                  storyline for all of them to fit in. However, notwithstanding the importance of ‘team moments,’ I love how personal background has such a big role in this show, with flashbacks and encounters from the past casting light over the people we see on the screen.
Character development is one of the main reasons why each episode feels so important in terms of where the show is going. There might not be a big end goal for these four misfits, but you remain hooked until the very end because you still want to get to know them more. What in other shows would be considered ‘filler episodes’ has a different importance in Cowboy Bebop, where absolutely nothing goes to waste. Even the secondary characters that you meet along the way are memorable and you wish you will see them again at some point in the future.
Despite being shot 20 years ago, the action scenes are still pretty amazing – I actually wish there were more. However, considering the aim is to mix different ingredients (comedy, drama, romance, sci-fi), everything seems perfectly balanced.
Finally, a word about the soundtrack. The opening titles are some of the most iconic in TV animation, and the use of jazz tracks throughout the series really stands out as an inspired director choice. I would listen to this soundtrack over and over.

Cowboy Bebop is good, but I don't think it deserves a rating of 8.9/10 which is incredibly high. There are plenty of good moments in Bebop, but at the same time you need to give a lot of patience to fully appreciate the show. From time to time, there are some good episodes, but most of the time it is just average or acceptable, but the thing is that I don't think there is a single bad episode. There is definitely an episode for you somewhere which will make you appreciate life, because Bebop at its essence is a slice of life of these individual
                  characters.
It is episodic in nature, so the best way to judge its quality is to ask how many episodes are considered worth-watching? In my opinion, there are about 8 out of the 26 episodes that I consider a must watch, these are: Ballad of Fallen Angels(ep. 5), Heavy Metal Queen(ep. 7), Mushroom Samba(ep. 17), Speak like a child(ep. 18), Pierrot le Fou(ep. 20), Brain Scratch(ep. 23) and The Real Folk Blues part 1 and 2(ep. 25-26) with each deserves a rating of 7.5/10 to 8.5/10. The remaining 18 out of the 26 episodes ranges from 5/10(average) to 7.4/10 which for me, drag the show down. 
Characters: 7.5/10
- The characters have a sense of coolness attached to them. They are very likable and have depth to their writing. They are very reasonable and deserve sympathy. They deserve more screen time especially Ed and Ein. The good moments of Bebop come from the individual character arcs. The show would be better if we get to see more of these characters.
Story: 7/10
- The main story of Spike which comprises of episodes 5, 25, and 26 is definitely the best and I think deserves at least an 8/10. Taking everything into consideration however, with some average and fine episodes, it's just a 7/10.
Art and Sound: 8/10
- For its time, it looks good and captured my senses. The classical sound is very fitting to the show and it made the good moments even better.
Enjoyment: 7/10
- Will I ever watch this show again? Probably not, but there are moments worth a replay.

Very rarely, if ever, do I feel so strongly about a product, offering or service so much that I feel compelled to write a review about it. Cowboy Bebop falls on the very end of the positive side of that spectrum. If you are wholly unfamiliar with Cowboy Bebop, well, read the summary on it's page.
I've never really watched a lot of anime. A few episodes of some intensely popular anime such as Death Note and Shigeki no Kyojin aside, the medium is foreign to me. However, the immense praise that I've seen for Cowboy Bebop on the internet combined with the comfort of it
                  being readily available to watch on Netflix, enticed me to give the show a shot. I am very, very glad I did.
The way Bebop is built up is fairly interesting. The show is quite episodic; on a practical standpoint, every main character (Spike, Jet, Faye and Ed) have a few episodes that are basically 'their' episodes, focusing most entirely around those characters. These episodes mostly tap into these characters being confronted in some form with their past. What in my opinion are the best episodes, are the episodes centered around Spike. These tense, dramatic episodes, is where in my opinion Cowboy Bebop excels even further than it already does. Beautiful animation, woven deftly with what is the most amazing score to any film/series I have ever seen, while you are slowly being let into more and more of Cowboy Bebop's secrets. The first minute of the show is practically the plateau on which Spike's story is built, making his episodes especially rewarding. It gives a more consistent tone to what is otherwise, like I said before, a fairly episodic show.
Overall, I have enjoyed Cowboy Bebop immensely. It's a sight to behold, a glory to listen to. It's enthralling, and relentlessly clever. I recommend it immensely.

This is an awesome anime! It's probably my all-time most favorite anime. Once in a while I'll go back and watch the last two episodes just so I don't forget why I like it so much.
The music, for one thing. Seatbelts is an awesome group and I wish I could find some of their non-Cowboy Bebop music because I would definitely listen to it plenty.
The story is probably the best part in my opinion. How mysterious Spike's past is, and yet how clear it becomes without even having a character recount the occurrences. And then the ending itself, that's something else. I won't spoil anything,
                  but if you see all the stuff that happens in the first 24 episodes then you'll know why the last two are so open-ended.
Art, geez, that doesn't even need to be said. Some of the visual effects they use can ordinarily only be captured on film, and yet they use most of them to the nth degree. Their portrayal of certain scenes are so perfect that I don't think Hayao Miyazaki himself couldn't have done a better job.
All in all, 10/10 because it's just that great.

Title: Cowboy Bebop
What is it: Firefly if it was an anime with half the characters (which, BTW, you should also watch. If you don't know what Firefly is, it's pretty much a space western)
How good is it: 9/10
What is it rated? MA for cursing, brief nudity and (ironically) little (though bloody) violence.
Where to watch: There's the 25 (or 26, not going to check right now) episode series that's available on Funimation, and the movie that's on Netflix DVD. Watch the movie before episode 22, as there will be SUPER MASSIVE SPOILERS after that. One of the best dubs out there.

Cowboy Bebop. Cowboy Bebop. Cowboy Bebop. If there was any anime that I heard such raving reviews about more than Cowboy Bebop, I don't know what it is. People were telling me right and left that Bebop was the best anime ever. So, I finally had to check it out. I did. And my final opinion: it was really good. It is pretty easy, though, for me to write my likes and dislikes about the show. First, dislikes, I'll just get it over with. The episodic nature of the show. I have never really been a fan of episodic shows, sure they add great character
                  development to the show, but I have a sense of longing, waiting for something, like the story, that never comes, or doesn't satisfy me. Though now that I understand the show much more, especially the themes of longing and alienation, it is fitting that a show sort of holds the viewer to the same expectations as the characters. Something that has made me love the show even more.
Now, here comes what I liked about the show. The characters and the music. If I loved anything about Cowboy Bebop, it was the music. The intro song, Tank!, does exactly what I think an intro should do: get the viewer excited to watch each episode, which it did and more. The outro, on the other hand, The Real Folk Blues, does exactly the opposite. It is filled with a sense of melancholy and longing, which was also perfect. After a couple episodes I felt the loneliness of many of the characters and the outro perfectly captured my emotions. I was so impressed by the music that I looked up who was in charge of it, Yoko Kanno, and I just wanted to give her all the praise in the world. The last time I heard a soundtrack so amazing was after Silent Hill 2. It was that great. 
The characters also make Cowboy Bebop what it is. Spike, Jet, Faye and Edward (you too, Ein!) were a joy to adventure with. They each had drastically different personalities, something I love, and had their own interesting stories to tell. Learning their back stories was like a punch in the gut and made me fall for each character even more. 
All and all, Cowboy Bebop is a show that deserves all the praise it gets. I don't hold onto this show maybe the same way that others do, but I admire and respect its craft. I'm sure after more time has passed and I rewatch it a couple more times, I will love it as much as some others do but until then ...  See You Space Cowboy.

Cowboy Bebop is an critically acclaimed Japanese science fiction anime led by director Shinichiro Watanabe. The 26-episode series deals with topics such as loneliness, existential boredom and the difficulty in facing our past.
Although it was been premiered in 1998, which means that it was released more than 20 years ago, it does not mean in any way that it is outdated. 
It is a captivating, unique and innovative work for the time it was launched. Clearly inspired by the “western” and “noir” films of the 40s, the series features a soundtrack with elements of Jazz, blues and classic rock that fit the theme perfectly.
The main
                  plot focuses on 2071 where the Earth became uninhabitable and humanity was forced to colonize the planets and moons of the Solar system. With this sudden expansion of humanity, the crime rate has skyrocketed and it has become increasingly difficult to contain. In the midst of all this situation, Inter Solar Space Police (ISSP), created a system of contracts where bounty hunters immobilize criminals and bring them alive in exchange for a payment, very similar to the Wanted system of the old western, making with these hunters to become known as "Cowboys".
The protagonists of the plot are a group of bounty hunters who operate on a ship they call Bebop. The main group consists of Spike Spiegel, a renegade Mafia assassin and Jet Black, a former ISSP officer. As the story progresses the group gets bigger, with the entrance of Faye Valentine, a delinquent woman who lost her memory, Radical Edward, a girl who is excellent at hacking and Ein, a modified corgi in the laboratory with an intelligence similar to human.
This group of extremely captivating and entertaining characters roams the space in search of criminals to obtain their due reward. Each episode is a different journey that captivates us to watch more, while we discover more of the morbid and tragic pasts of the characters that hold us to the plot, reaching a final that I consider perfect, where the story ends in an incredible way.
I really admire this work and consider it on of the best plot and group of characters I have seen to date. That group of former thugs, officers and hackers captivate the viewer to watch in an unusual way, making each character and episode memorable and unforgettable.
Cowboy bebop is a great animation series for those who like action, mystery and drama movies, or even for those who enjoy a good classic of investigation and western. And I recommend anyone to watch for its excellent quality and for its extraordinary ending that is recorded as one of the best works developed to date.
"You´re gonna carry that weight"

One of the classical gems, personally I am very picky with my anime. The first time I encountered Cowboy bebop was in 2001. At the age of eleven I fell in love with cowboy bebop and when I grew up it played a large role in defining my taste in the genre.
I'm not obsessed with Japanese culture but I respect good anime when I watch it. Quite honestly I dislike a lot of anime too but cowboy bebop just overall was and is so good.
While episodic in nature each individual story really sets up and tells the stories of these bounty hunters, that was the
                  point, in my opinion of having individual stories set in individual episodes. Bebop isn't about some hero trying to save the world from evil. It's about the lives of the crew, what they do to survive, they are just people with extraordinary pasts, that have specialized skills for the jobs they perform. It's a gathering of different personalities that after awhile they grew onto each other and this is reflected later on.
Once the "main arc" of the story reveals itself it turns into quite a roller coaster, and each character obviously has their own back story revealed in their respective episodes. If you're looking for a cliched anime obviously this won't probably do it for you but for fans that are looking for more. This show is for you. 
The only way I can see you even having anything negative about this show is if you're trying to be a hipster or search for things you dislike. There is games, anime etc i have personally disliked but i could respect that game or movie for being good but sometimes things don't click with you. That's Bebop, it's a classic. Hate it or love it, you have to respect it.

Well, if this isn't the poster child for "a pure and true anime classic" I don't know what would be. Cowboy Bebop is visually dated but is otherwise timeless and it has rightfully gone down, and will continue to go down, as one of the greatest anime series ever.
Art-
The art was perfectly fine, if not quite good, for it's time and it is now, understandably, a bit dated. Reviewing this anime in the present as opposed to objectively for when it was created, the art is likely the weakest point of the show, but that's largely because everything else is exceptionally good and time has
                  been kind to the other aspects of the show.
Sound-
Cowboy Bebop has one of the most acclaimed soundtracks ever. The opening sequence is among the greatest of all time, the jazz throughout the series is exciting and of high quality and the perfect song always seems to play during any given action sequence. I don't see how any objective person, regardless of personal taste, could give the sound of Cowboy Bebop anything other than a 10.
The voice acting is solid and there are no low points, but the outstanding soundtrack steals the show in the sound department.
Character-
The characters and the story are likely the biggest factor as to what makes this anime truly special. The crew is super memorable, the lead is one of the most iconic anime badasses of all time and the sheer variety of villains, planets, scenarios and mini-stories, which eventually build up to an exceptionally good ending, combine to make one of the overall most unique and memorable experiences in the history of the medium.
This anime truly has a little bit of everything and it just works. Other shows have tried to replicate this and they almost always end up a convoluted mess but Cowboy Bebop pulls this off masterfully in a way no other show, prior or since, has been able to achieve.
Enjoyment-
There isn't a single episode without action, there's a plethora of gunfights and fist fights and you genuinely give a damn about the characters and the trouble they're getting into, so it's damn near impossible not to enjoy this show. There are so many stories contained within the overall larger narrative and many of them have feel good endings that simply make you happy to watch. Perhaps how enjoyable the show is to watch, even all this time later, is the biggest reason it has aged so well and is still so revered today.
Overall-
A timeless classic and a masterpiece, Cowboy Bebop, while old and visually dated by today's standards, is one of the greatest anime series of all time.
+Pulls off the "a little bit of everything" formula perfectly
+Amazing music
+You'll genuinely care about the characters and what happens to them
+A 26 episode show that honestly truly has no bad episodes. It just doesn't
-Visually dated
OBJECTIVE RATING- 10
PERSONAL ENJOYMENT RATING- 9

This review isn't going to go into huge detail one why it's a masterpiece that should be evident. I will say the only real problems people commonly find with the show are due to it's age. (clinches/sub par animation, ect) and that's just plain not fair to say that about a 1990's anime.
When infact those common problems were actually non issues during the time, and infact some would say those problems you didnt like were ground breaking at the time. 
Simply put. If you don't like cowboy bebop, you don't like anime. Im assming most of the dislikes came from people who insist that one
                  piece is a 10/10 show.

what can i say about this one except that its a classic...Arguably the best show i have even seen. Great characters, great plot, classic storytelling, classic music and great direction.
The best aspect i like about this anime is the simplicity in the portrayal of characters and their behavior in all sequences. The remarkable sections are the comedy ones where no overstressing is used to underline the humour. The humour sequences are simple and to the point and downright funny..they have to be in that avatar. The dark characters are well created and well placed in the plot and no overtures of positivity are introduced in
                  these characters at any point of time which is refreshing. 
I fell in love with the music of the show right from the word go. Jazz rocks! and you've got to be down with that. The sophistication in music is evident from the sounds of the classic jazz orchestras and brass bands. Even the saxophone and harmonica bits played during the scenes and sequences are quite catchy. The build up to one of the great endings that i have ever seen in anime is fantastic. Each character is given color along the way and the show keeps your interest utill the last frame...which is quite a scence really.
If you havent seen this one...God you are missing a classic.

There is no greater purpose in Cowboy Bepop, no goal to work towards, only a past to come to terms with. Underneath the no care attitude of the Bepop crew lies a deep sense of ambiguity and turmoil as each member makes repeated shallow attempts to supress their past tragedies with meaningless day to day activities. Only to find themselves where they were at the start of each episode, staring at the bottom of a bowl of bell peppers and beef without the beef.
“I was watching a dream I could never wake up from. Before I knew it, the dream was over.”
Cowboy Bepop is not
                  for everyone, and I sincerely mean that. The reason why it is regarded as a cult classic amongst the diehard fans of the genre is an enigma in itself. A 90’s anime boasting gunslinging space cowboys and thrilling fight sequences seems like the tools used to create a decent anime. However, chief director Shinichirō Watanabe utilised these staples of the shonen genre in order to create something so needlessly melancholic that not only does it shatter our perceptions of the suave protagonists we wish to be, but the very nature of life itself.
Plot 8/10
Mellow and carefree Spike Spiegel and his boisterous and pragmatic counterpart, Jet Black, try to make a living by chasing bounties across the galaxy in the year 2071 aboard their ship, the Bepop. As they travel, they reluctantly welcome others aboard who share more in common than they think.
Cowboy Bepop is fairly episodic in nature, each episode there’s a new bounty to collect and on the surface, there seems to be no overarching plot. The crew aboard the ship are merely used as vessels by Mr Watanabe in order to give us a glimpse into a minor character’s life and help them achieve their goal. Whilst this is enjoyable to watch, the overall theme of the show is one of despair, episode after episode, a relentless barrage of excessive heartache as another minor character loses something they once cherished, only to be forgotten after the credits roll. Even the crew themselves are not exempt from this grief, Mr Watanabe reminds us that no one can escape this harsh reality as every now and again he turns his focus to the very past the space cowboys try so hard to suppress.
Characters 9/10
The entire Bepop crew is filled with unique characters that complement each other quite well. For every calculated measure there is a spontaneous decision, for every suave action there is an uproar of laughter. It’s fun watching their interactions and how each of them behave in a certain situation. However, beyond that each member has a past life that calls out to them, longing for them to return in order to complete their story. Reminders are placed intermittently throughout the anime simply to showcase that they cannot run away without losing something, and whether they answer the call or not… well that’s for you to find out.
The supporting characters within this anime are an excellent means of a plot device for each episode, where all of them have been uniquely created with their own wants and desires. I found most episodes enjoyable and discovered that the key to gauging how good an episode is, is by how distinctive each supporting character’s goals are. Episode “Pierrot Le Fou” comes to mind.
Art and Sound 9/10
Being a late 90’s anime, Cowboy Bepop’s art style is much different to what you’re probably used to, but it holds up well to this day. The anime features a beautiful array of different planets across the galaxy with an imaginative display of how each society functions. Metropolitan planets are teeming with corporations whilst barren planets are left for those who are only focused on surviving. The imagery within the anime itself is very strong, each episode uses a different gradient scheme and highlights objects that make their appearances throughout the entire show and serve as aforementioned reminders to the characters.
The Bepop type of jazz, identifiable by its complex harmony and rhythms, is a heavy influence for this anime. Evidently seen in the spaceship’s name, episode’s titles, and most importantly, the music. Bepop is littered throughout the soundtrack and it is an amazing experience to listen to it both within the context of the anime and by itself. The soundtrack is full of energy lending to the intense fights scenes, whilst also toning itself back when required during a sombre moment.
Final Remarks
Cowboy Bepop is by far an excellent anime, full of vibrant sceneries and exciting action scenes with the unique flair the crew carries. But underneath that is what turns a decent anime into, well… a cult classic. The lasting impression that sets Cowboy Bepop apart leaves is sad and frankly, uncalled for. The thought that upsets the natural progression of shonen animes in order to address the bleakness of life and how…
“Whatever happens, happens.”

Alright, my first review here so let's get right into it. 
Cowboy bebop, where do I even begin... For me, this anime was a rollercoaster of  ride. At the beginning I enjoyed getting to know all these characters and how they slowly become a part of each others lives. But around the 7th episode, I couldn't keep watching it. I asked my friends who had watched this show whether this will ever get interesting, in the sense, whether there is a bigger story that all this is leading up to or whether this is just an episodic anime series, which by the way I
                  don't like. They couldn't give me a straight answer and now I understand why. 
If you're seeing this review and you're someone who doesn't enjoy episodic series, then pay heed to my advice and watch Cowboy Bebop. No matter how it may seem, there is a bigger story in this anime. I was bored to death till around the 13th episode, but then I started paying attention to details. Every episode has some or the other reference to the characters' pasts. Sometimes it's subtle, sometimes it's blatant, but it's present. Things get interesting somewhere around the 20th episode (Also this depends on the person. For me it was interesting from the 20th episode, for someone else, it may be before that or after that) and everything starts to fall into place in the final 3-4 episodes.  I liked the story that cowboy bebop was trying to tell, it was... how do I describe it... Philosophical. I won't speak more, but all I say is WATCH THE SHOW.
After seeing me write so many positive things about the show, you might be wondering why I have given it an 8. Let me justify my rating here. 
I liked the ending, I really did, but it's those 7-8 episodes in the first half of the show for me. Don't get me wrong, they weren't extremely bad, but I found them really boring. I slept halfway through one of the episodes too. If it weren't for the ending being so good, I would have probably rated this a 5 or possibly even a 4 because like I said, I don't enjoy episodic anime series. But Cowboy Bebop is much more than that, and I think majority of the people here won't find the first half of the show boring because some of the stories in the episodes are really compelling and you won't even realize how time passes by.

Cowboy Bebop is, essentially, an American-style "Western." Set in Space. To an awesome and varied soundtrack, as our anti-heroes bebop around the solar system, from the moon of Saturn to the clouds of Venus, collecting bounties on various criminals, trying to avoid their various troubled and mysterious pasts.
But...
There's a lot of tropes and stereotypes played with masterfully, ironically, humorously, and, strangely enough, straightly, throughout the series, blending East-Meets-West in a delectable fusion not unlike it's outstanding soundtrack.
Blues; Jazz; Rock; Western; Classical; the list goes on-and-on, each "style" represented and counterpointed by its particular episode.
Science Fiction. Comedy. Drama. Action/Adventure. Cowboy Bebop has something for everyone. And,
                  unlike most series that tries to be "everything for everyone," Cowboy Bebop somehow manages to succeed.
Watching Cowboy Bebop is only half the experience; listening is as much a part of the pleasure. Like putting on your headphones and cuing up your favorite playlist of various styles of music, and letting each piece pull your emotions this-way-and-then-that, until at the end, you're satisfied and yet strangely melancholy; you've laughed, you've cried, you've reminisced fondly in turn.
That's Cowboy Bebop.

I normally hate anything with a futuristic theme, but this was different.  The setting, art, and music are all outstanding.  There is a strangely relaxing flow to Cowboy Bebop that makes the series just fly by.  Each episode I was more focused on the setting than the actual story, but the story was good enough for me to watch every episode, which is saying a lot.

Aaa Cowboy Bebop, the classic everyone -must- see, and then ideally praise!
But what if.. What if it did have some flaws, like just about any show? ^^;
Okay so, in this anime, we're in the future; the year 2077 or something like that. And yet, we're still using technology from the 90's, because this show was made some time ago. It's a fun contrast, actually! I enjoy the innocent, jazzy, backwards sci-fi setting - including -literal- cowboys, indians, and more!
In this universe, humans have conquered space and are living on all sorts of different planets. It's hard to police it all, so the government pays bounty
                  hunters to help them out catching criminals.
Spike, our MC, is one of these bounty hunters, and over the course of the show, he will gather a motley crew of very special people to try and live a semi-honest  life catching bad people on his spaceship, bebop. Tadaa!
It is fun to see the characters introduced and develop, and go on their episodic adventures to try and earn a living often failing due to circumstances.
The best part, other than the fantastic setting, is the character interactions. All characters feel vibran and a live, with unique characteristics and motivations.
The soundtrack is jazzy and smooth, and the animation is surprisingly good for its time, living up just fine even now!
BUT!
.. There isn't really an overarching plot.. ^^; And that might have been fine, if there really had been nothing, and it just was happy space adventures. But, about 6 episodes out of 25 try to go really deep. Sometimes, it's some personal backstory, and it's kinda ok - but then it gets immediately discarded again.
I guess, my main issue is with the "main" villain, Vicious, who is edgy as can be, has a sword in the future, survives explosions on a daily basis, and who doesn't get given nearly enough screentime to care about. So, in the final battle, we've only seen him for 10-odd minutes, and hardly know why it is a final battle at all. And, the battle itself, honestly is rather lackluster. And then it's over!
There's also something about a love-interest, who literally is around for only 1 episode.. :(
It had potential, if they had spent some more time on it, it could've worked out. Or, it could have been happy space adventures. Instead, it was an in-between, and that didn't work for me - the ending fell flat.
THAT SAID. It's still a fine series overall, especially for the time. Probably something good is that anyone can watch it, even non-anime fans.
See ya next time, cowwboy!

Story 9/10
     Though many of the stories/problems end in an episode, I think the viewers will find themselves enjoying most of the 26 episodes with the unique bounties, ways they catch them, the fighting scenes, and the slowly revealing tragic past of the characters. The last few episodes were very intense, and the ending was very shocking but I also believe they were able to wrap up the show perfectly. I myself did not enjoy all of the episodes though, there were maybe one or two episodes where I wanted more fighting scenes or more accomplishments.
Characters 10/10   The characters in this anime all have their own originality and are unique. The protagonist of this anime, Spike Spiegel and one of the crew members, Edward are now one of my favourite characters. As each and one of the crews have different personalities, each and one of them stands out and they are all important to the story. The characters were very well developed, it was nice to see all of them change as they met and interacted with one another. It was nice to learn more about the characters in a very nice timing, I think they were able to decide on the best places to include the characters' sorrowful hidden past and helped the viewer feel connected to the characters.
Music 10/10
     The music played in this anime are just awesome. They are songs that makes one move along with the rhythm and the opening and ending songs are just so catchy and cool. I believe Yoko Kanno did a truly and unbelievably amazing work. All of the songs matches the scenes and none of them seemed to be out of place.
Art 10/10
   By comparing the art of this anime to the other 90's anime art, you can easily see how high quality the art of Cowboy Bebop is. Even if you compare the art of an anime that has been aired recently to Cowboy Bebop, the art quality of cowboy bebop may be better. The character design is very stylish and the fighting scenes are very well drawn. 
Overall 10/10
     I really enjoyed this anime, it is now one of my favourite. The high quality fighting scenes, the characters with tragic pasts which made me want to encourage them and made me feel connected to them, and the last few episodes which were very intense and made me very nervous are some reasons why I ended up loving this anime. I was very satisfied with the ending, I think the anime was able to end very nicely. The art and songs are also high quality, the opening song did not leave my head for a very long time after watching the anime. Finally, the characters are all unique, each characters act as a different and special spice for the anime. In conclusion, I highly recommend this anime and hope all of you will be able to enjoy this as much as me.

There’s a lot I like and dislike about Cowboy Bebop. The characters are all fun and likeable. Ed was a little too “lol so random XD” in the beginning for me, but I warmed up to her. The world, as well as the fusion between the retro and futuristic technology was inspired. Unfortunately, that's about all I liked. One of the series biggest flaws it the overarching story. I didn't think it was very interesting.  It was best when it was about four likeable characters and worst when it had to go back to the overarching plot (not a controversial stance, I’ve heard). Also,
                  the show could be cryptic at times, with the character spouting dialogue that sounds deep but means nothing upon examination. It’s not a bad show, in fact it’s very good, but I expected more from what is considered the best anime ever made.

STORY: Cowboy Bebop involves episodic moments of a team of intergalactic bounty hunters catching criminals for rewards. It also contains some references and origins/flashbacks of the main characters. There are also a cool action/fighting scenes, but it can be quite comedic too. The show also lets the viewers sees what life in space looks like and the fate of planet Earth.
CHARACTERS:
Spike: Bounty Hunter, hates pets, kids and women with attitudes, born in Mars, smoker, lazy and practices martial arts.
Jet: Former officer, bounty hunter, owner of the Bebop, chef, mechanic and pilot, and has cybernetic body parts.
Faye: smoker, sarcastic, tough but kind hearted.
Ein: Corgi, cute and
                  funny, & has a close relationship with Ed.
Ed: Youngest member in the group, usually talks about herself in third person, intelligent, human, has a close relationship with Ein.
OVERALL:
A lot of people have talked about this anime. To be honest, I didn't watch it when it first came out during the 90's (until recently -- since Chris convinced me to watch it with him together). I enjoy the adventures in every episode where the group has to catch bounties of wanted criminals while it contains some backstory of the main characters. They also meet some new characters along the way. If I wanted to make any comments about improvements... I would have to say... MORE opportunities and episodes of the backstories of the main characters. Even though it is nice to see some sub-plots for couple of the main characters, it would be nice if the rest of the characters can get a chance too. I would love to learn more about them.

An absolute masterpiece of an anime!
Cowboy Bebop is a gorgeous slice of life anime filled with interesting characters, stunning visuals and incredible background scores. With fluid fight sequences and homage to different genres and cultures, each episode is unique in itself and bursting with art and life. 
This is an anthology series at it's finest and people complaining about a lack of continuity or motive to the series need to read up on the meaning of an "Anthology format" and perhaps veer away from it altogether. 
Cowboy Bebop was, is and will always be a timeless classic, and it has arguably, one of the best,
                  most fulfilling endings to a story in anime history. 
See you Space Cowboy.....

I normally don't write reviews for anime but I found that I should write one for this one. I was surprised that something with this much age could still be relevant today. I adored the music and the interaction of all the characters. I knew however that though Spike longed to be with Julia it would never happen. Their life together was doomed from the start because something that genuinely doesn't exist in reality and rarely in stories. I enjoyed the crew of Spike, Ed, Ein, Faye, and Jet. I felt that in some way they all needed each other to fight against the boredom
                  of the emptiness of space. They are all searching for meaning in their lives and searching for something that will pull them out of the dullness of life. Just moving on and through life just as bounty hunters of the old west frontier did. 
I watched it because it was recommended to me and I enjoyed it.

I want to preface this review by saying that the "classic" armor that this show has been given is a pile of shit. If you don't like it, don't be discouraged to let it be known. The show certainly has its issues.
But fuck all that for now, let me tell you why I'm giving it a solid 10.
The art, considering the show was made in the 90's, is absolutely superb. Everything about this show's art is as it should be.
The story, which I will not spoil, is absolutely masterminded (apart from a couple of things here and there). It goes in and out with a
                  bang.
The music, oh my god, the music. Every time I listen to that opening theme my dick is at half mast.
The characters are simple and complex at the same time, and they compliment each other quite well, in most cases. This is where my few issues with the show come into play.
Overall my enjoyment of the show is about as high as it's ever been for any other. In my humble and often bullshit opinion, it's a masterpiece. Even people who hate anime, and, let's be honest, there are plenty of reasons why, would be people I could recommend this to. It's just that good.

I do not believe I need to stay too much for this anime because I am pretty sure everyone has probably seen it already but if you somehow have not taken the time to experience this series then I highly recommend you do because you will not regret it.

👉🏻
𝘽𝘼𝙉𝙂
When strong animation is combined with such an incredible storyline, along with extraordinary music we get a masterpiece like this. It isn't a show only about space, noir, tragedy, romance, fun, philosophy, etc. But it's a show with each episode different from its last one in every sense.
The world where it takes place is beautiful in itself. Spaceships fly through hyperspace gates and on the other hand pilots use handguns on their jets, where the technology is way too advanced and problems of politics and crimes still exist.
Coming to music, which definitely was the strongest point of the series. Yoko Kanno created music that was
                  not only fresh but way ahead of its curve, and I am pretty sure it laid some foundation for the anime music industry for the future. CB used the music to its maximum effect. There were some scenes where not the visuals but the audio made it more splendid.
Honestly admitting, where I thought anime was just supernatural powers who beat evil, schoolgirls, adolescent boys with a ton of life problems, and robots. CB tells us that there was never a boundary to this 2D world. Even their motivation was not what we expect from the usual ones. Never did they do something to fight crime or ensure peace, they just did it for fun and money.
From fistfights to shoutouts in bars, from car chases on roads to aerial fights, from space chases to cool rides, Bepop didn't have a limited spectrum of stuff. The character development(both light and dark) was mixed with humor and a pinch of sad feelings.
Keeping aside the jaw-dropping ending never had I seen such a show with such style, music, and intelligence.

If I had to describe it in one word: Cool.

I mean I don't even like jazz, but this got me to be like "Wow, jazz is actually pretty awesome!" Don't let that sentence fool you either, the soundtrack is a mix of genres, not just jazz.
There are so many things going on, but they are woven together beautifully. If I had to pick a favorite episode, it'd probably be Hard Luck Woman. Edward is my favorite character, and I

This is my first review, so bear with me
Cowboy Bebop was an anime I heard about for quite sometime so I decided to give it a shot, with all previous interest
Story 9/10- The Story is Great, it highlights themes like boredom, loneliness, and most importantly the inability to escape your past and move forward. The anime is episodic, which can take some adjusting at first, but does not hold back from the excellence this story gives us.
Art 10/10- This was animated in 1998 by Sunrise and they did phenomenal. Everything looks great, including the unique character designs as well and how well they match each
                  character. The art is simply the definition of a 90s classic when you watch it. 
Sound 10/10- If there is one thing Cowboy Bebop is most noted for it is its sound. Cowboy Bebop has this western influence inside of its soundtrack that is perfectly represented in the show. The Opening and Ending remain some of my favorite in anime. This is one of the anime's where the English Dub is equal if not better than the original in japanese. I personally watched in Dub and was amazed by how well the voice acting is done especially Steve Blum's take on Spike Spiegel which is nothing short of a masterpiece.
Characters 10/10- Cowboy Bebop has some of the best written characters among its cast, with many characters being crucial to the story and each having a backstory that adds to that character and how they act. Without going into too much detail, to keep this review spoiler-free Cowboy Bebop shows how phenomenal and how attached you can get to characters in the span of 26 episodes.
Enjoyment 9/10- Cowboy Bebop is a very enjoyable series and is thought of to be a gateway for new anime watchers, due to its episodic and western influence. I enjoyed Cowboy Bebop and it will definitely etch itself in my memory as one of my favorites of all-time. It is simply an anime, that is non-forgettable and will continue to remain a classic for years to come.
Overall Rating- 10/10

From the energetic jazz-filled opening to the melancholic "see you space cowboy" at the end of each episode, cowboy bebop never fails to invoke excitement and sadness respectively as each episode begins and ultimately ends. The soundtrack is amazing by itself and can be talked about for hours on end but when used as a support to the immersive world and characters shown to us throughout the series it all comes together as a masterpiece. 
The story consists of a group of bounty hunters and their journey throughout the galaxy together. It sounds very simple and in many cases, it is because it follows the
                  "catch a new criminal per episode" formula but it does it well with its good pacing and brilliant short stories that expand the world of cowboy bebop without feeling overwhelming or overbearing with context dumps.
The crew of the spaceship bebop are quirky and are all vastly different from one another but also seem connected from a silent bond of companionship, mutual appreciation and respect for one another which is a very refreshing take of a good dichotomy that isn't only just arguments and conflicting personality clashes. Each episode can involve comedy, action and sometimes even mystery but the most memorable moments are when the vulnerabilities of the cast are revealed. Their different methods of coping and reacting to each of these opened scars are so human that they can't be told apart from just being characters written from a script. Its a story about running, fighting and dealing with life, the coat of sugar replaced with a more mature and realistic view of a sci-fi world. 
The art style is very retro and stands out in comparison to generic art styles of most seasonal anime of 2019 (with some exceptions*). It looks unique, beautiful and in my opinion, very fitting of the sci-fi dystopian world filled to the brim with love and smooth jazz. Animations are a visual treat with hand to hand fight scenes, shootouts and dogfights that all look amazing and are coloured amazingly. 
Overall Cowboy Bebop is a beautiful series for those that want to watch a good story unfold and a good journey that would leave you wanting more.
tldr section:
Story ~ 9/10
Art ~ 10/10
Sound ~ 10/10
Enjoyment ~ 10/10
Overall ~ 10/10
This is my first ever review and to all the people that found this helpful (and those that didn't) feedback is always appreciated.
*megalo box tries to recreate the retro art look and also captures the tone with its art style brilliantly

Cowboy Bebop is a collection of passable episodic action adventures that gets elevated by audiovisual excellence and stylish directing. Having seen a lot of action adventures, the individual stories themselves are nothing special and the characters, though cool at their base, are too stiff to contribute much chemistry to spice up the adventures. As an action adventure, Cowboy Bebop cannot compete with the sheer fun factor of Justice League or Clone Wars or Lupin III. 
In general, although it's better to be understated than to tell too much, I couldn't discern much character development, as you can scramble the episodes and not notice a difference
                  in the characters themselves and their interactions with the other members of the crew. I'm open to opposing thoughts on this, but I don't think it's a coincidence that this problem shows up in Samurai Champloo as well. The only thing that changes is that the characters become slightly more tolerant towards each other. Even so, any bonds they share are quickly torn when they each are so ready to abandon the crew. 
SPOILERS
Spike straight up disregards his partnership with Jet and leaves on at least two different occasions for selfish reasons. I get that he's the lone wolf, stubborn type, but still, he won't budge an inch for anyone else when his own interests conflict with the crew's. When Faye tells him not to leave, he doesn't give a damn and walks off. Speaking of Faye, there's no reason shown for why she decides to join up with the crew again after she runs away. Implicitly, it's because of what Gren said to her, but she also doesn't apologize for leaving the crew out to dry. In addition, Jet was only looking for the money she stole and picked her up by coincidence. I get that Cowboy Bebop's style is very macho and people don't talk about their feelings aloud, preferring to leave things unsaid, but at a certain point you need to give me something to hold onto. OK, even if we accept that resolution, later Faye doesn't waste a second high tailing the hell out of the Bebop when she thinks she's found her family, only to come crawling back because the crew is all she has left. I can understand that Faye is selfish and she would leave a second time, but it's the way she left--- she didn't even look back. That doesn't sound like a strong relationship to me. She's just desperate and looking for a home. The same thing goes with Ed. She just gets up and leaves with Ein one day without even bothering to inform the crew face to face. Just like in Samurai Champloo, Watanabe doesn't seem to want his characters to get too close to one another and it baffles me.
ENDSPOILERS
It's a shame, because many of the episodes that I'm lukewarm towards could be substantially improved with great character banter and having the events of the episode actually change the characters, even incrementally. Instead, most of the time the characters work on separate jobs, rarely working together as a team. They talk to each other like coworkers, not as friends, which is fine in the beginning, but not when you're 20 episodes in. It's not really that big of a problem since Watanabe is so good at crafting interesting, charismatic, and yet deeply human characters that feel alive on the screen. The characters are well designed enough that they can get through 26 episodes without much change or bonding, but the show could've been so much better if they didn't just do that. Much of the time Spike does the field work, Faye's doing something else, Jet's the intel guy, and Ed is off doing her own hacking stuff. 
It gets much worse if you watch the dub of Lupin III and realize that Cowboy Bebop's cast is just a pale version of Lupin III's, and the excuse that the characters are stiff with one another because they're not the type to change doesn't fly anymore. Selfish femme fatale with commitment issues? Fujiko pulls that off with much more charisma, sex appeal, and chemistry with men. Straightlaced, stable beard guy? Jigen's the man. Spike doesn't really have a direct analog, as he's nowhere near as silly as Lupin, but the fact remains that the collective chemistry in Lupin III far surpasses that of Cowboy Bebop. Don't believe me? You can just look up the "best of Lupin III dub" on Youtube. 
Yeah, it's a nostalgic show about broken people wandering aimlessly in space, but it seems content in reveling in the cool factor of this state rather than exploring the ways their bonds with each other change them (it does, but it's rather weak, as I mentioned before) or how they try to amend that brokenness. When the ending comes, it feels like Cowboy Bebop just decided to end after a series of fun adventures, rather than as a culmination of events that incrementally lead up to the choices that the characters make to bring about that end. You can say that the characters and ideas are developed around the concept of the past, which is valid, but it seems to me that all of it amounts to, “You can’t forget the past, so you’re going to have to carry that weight.” I don’t see how that’s insightful, as obviously your past is going to weigh on you and it’s impossible to completely forget it and move on. The main problem is that simply talking about the past in general is superficial. People's pasts are different and what matters is exactly what about their unique past the keeps them from moving forward? The question for me is, how do we reconcile with our pasts without letting it drag us down? The answer to this question is unique to each individual and their personal struggles, and it isn't as simple as, "just move on".  With Cowboy Bebop, I was looking for the crew to find new purpose, form a new family, and do something new with their lives. Jet seems to be the only character who has closure on his past because he engages with the reasons for how things turned out the way they did. 
SPOILERS
