Of course, Spike breaks that family in an attempt to confront his past, which made no sense to me. Spike may be the coolest animated character ever, and effortlessly so, but his edgy death wish attitude is not cool. "I'm not going to die. I'm going to find out if I'm really alive." *Proceeds to go off to die*. It's alright for a character to have this attitude, as Spike has good reason to. The crux of the problem is that I don’t understand how going back and killing a bunch of mobsters and dying because of it provides any type of emotional catharsis. That’s not confronting your past. Confronting your past would be correcting the mistake you made by not repeating it. You can argue Vicious’s rise of power was Spike’s fault and that Spike is going back to prevent Vicious from taking any more lives, but Spike seems to kill Vicious as a symbolic gesture. Dude, you just repeated the same self destructive, violent behavior that messed up your past in the first place. Perhaps that’s the point, that Spike couldn’t move on, but that’s not confronting the past and that's not saying anything more substantial either. 
ENDSPOILERS
The other half of the problem is that your immersion in Cowboy Bebop is highly dependent on whether or not you resonate with its nostalgic longing for the past. I don't. I always look towards the future. If you gave me the chance to go back to my childhood or high school or college, I wouldn't take it because I'm always trying to build on what came before, so that every day I'm a better person than I was before. Thus, when I see the crew of Cowboy Bebop with all the freedom in the world and long lives ahead of them, I don't understand their unwillingness to look at new possibilities. This wouldn't be a problem if the show did a better job of making me understand why exactly they have trouble letting go instead of talking about the past in general. Spike has trouble letting go of two things: 1) Julia 2) his time in a crime syndicate. It's easy for anyone to understand how hard it is to move on from a loved one, but still, the relationship between Julia and Spike is barely shown and when Julia does show up, she has a pretty boring personality. As for the gang activity, is it that Spike has trouble leaving behind his gangster ways? Does he miss the brotherhood of the gang? Does he need the adrenaline? It's never entirely clear, so it's harder for me to comprehend why this good-looking, talented 23 year old with no laws governing him doesn't go and enjoy his life. It's the same story with Faye's past. If I got a look into her touching relationships with her family and friends, it would be much easier for me to understand why she wants to go back to that so badly because I too, would be feeling her attachment. Whereas in her current situation, I see that Faye is lucky enough to find three other people that give her a place to stay, a job to work, and company, which is a damn good deal for a person who just woke up with nothing left. If the show did go down this more specific role, it would also allow a scene where Spike or Jet inadvertently do a specific gesture for Faye that her family once did, cementing the ragtag family dynamic in a much stronger way that also helps Faye cope with her past in a specific manner. Instead, her attachment to a place of belonging or her past is hard to understand because she has amnesia. Jet, as I mentioned, gets the best treatment in that I readily understand his pain from his girlfriend leaving him and he gets to throw away his broken watch. At the same time, just like with Spike, the discussion around his attachment to his police days is muddy. Jet is deadset in his methods, straightlaced, and carries the image of a dog who never lets go. This is the mentality that gets him shot and betrayed, which he finds out later. Ok, but now you're retired and free to do whatever you want? In what way are you being tied down by your past? Is it that your straightlaced attitude and stubborness still leads to problems in your life? Well you at least dealt with your commanding nature in Waltz for Zizi already. You find out your partner betrayed you. It's never shown what kind of impact this has on Jet's straightlaced dog persona. Having a past that defines and weighs on a character is basic character writing. The rest of the work has to deal with the specifics of each past instead of settling for a useless general statement of "the character can't move on from the past" or "the character decided to move on". 
The Bourne series does this past thing a whole lot better in terms of having a past that you can't escape, because it literally has the CIA constantly try to kill Bourne despite his attempts to start a new life. Mind you, Bourne has no memories just like Faye, and he's been a gun toting martial artist just like Spike. You see Bourne specifically struggle with resisting the programming the CIA gave him and struggle to decide whether or not to kill someone. On JJ Redick's podcast recently, former NBA MVP Steve Nash talked about how hard it was to accept that his days in the NBA were over despite his desperate attempts to keep himself in the game. He then makes peace with it by acknowledging that he has had a good career, and that he can transfer his competitive spirit into other areas in life. For him, letting go of the past was letting go of the spirit of competition and the support from the fans. Satoshi Kon's short film Magnetic Rose deals with an opera singer stuck in the past of her glory days. We clearly understand that she misses performing and the fame that comes with it and that's why she can't let go. The answer to the question of the past is always "you have to make your peace with it and move on". That's kind of a non-statement. The duty of shows that choose to tackle the topic is to explore how exactly this is done on an individual level (and not simply have a character decide to move on abruptly like Ed). Or if people keep falling into a cycle, still explore attempts to move on rather than just drifting around and then pinpoint the factors that counter these attempts to move on. Because despite what the show suggests, the past is not always a weight. It is certainly not for me at this point. A show can take the opposite approach and talk about the past lovingly as fond memories, like Kaiba. 
All in all, why am I even bothering to write so much about this issue? If I hadn't known any better, I would've just said that Cowboy Bebop is a good to great action adventure with a lot of style and a sprinkling of brokenness and themes about the past to add some dimension the characters carrying out those fun action adventures. There's a simple message that's repeated for 26 episodes. The thing is, Samurai Champloo is pretty much a mirror image of Cowboy Bebop and you don't see people proclaiming the same things about Samurai Champloo as they do about Cowboy Bebop. Champloo literally has characters doing suicidal things to find out they're really alive TWICE in the same episode. At that point I decided that Watanabe really doesn't have anything more to say beyond "people can't let go of their past so they're stuck in a state of limbo" and my feelings about Cowboy Bebop weren't a fluke. And just like Cowboy Bebop, characters will go through events and things from their past and it doesn't change them at all. Sure, it fleshes them out, but you don't even get to hear their thoughts on it. Later in Samurai Champloo, another character must let go her past by letting of of her hope that her son is alive, but this one moment is more powerful to me than Spike's and Faye's stories. 
There's a case to be made that Bebop is really about simply showing how people repeat themselves and can't move on from their old habits, and that's fine but I don't know, maybe I'm just not old enough to connect emotionally with it. 
It looks like I'm nitpicking Cowboy Bebop, but in an episodic series, you really have to nail every single minute, and as for its substance, it failed to arouse emotion or resonate with me. I think its massive hype also affected my opinion, as I might have rated it higher if I just went in not knowing anything. Is it a masterpiece? Yes, if you buy into its message about the past. I don’t, but perhaps that will change as I get older. Still, it’s not just a legendary anime--- it’s a legendary work of storytelling in general.

The first time I saw this anime, I was in high school. By chance, the third episode was the one that I saw first, and I don't think that if I had started from the beginning, this show would have had as much of an impact on me as it did. I may not even have continued to watch. But for angsty little me, I was amazed by that episode. I had found an idol in the cool woman with no past, Faye Valentine.
I continued to watch the show, over and over again (as it met with a lot of success and was aired for
                  a number of years), and I fell in love with it completely.
The characters in this show are amazingly done. They are all very interesting, and you want to know more about them. They have flaws and problems, and sometimes they get on your nerves, just like ordinary people. They pass in and out of your life, just like ordinary people, too.
The music is amazing as well.
It feels as though there really isn't much that I could say that hasn't already been said numerous times before, and by far more eloquent people than I am. This is one of my favorite anime shows, and it is a classic for good reason. It is a very well-made anime.
If you are curious, and haven't seen it yet, go for it! Chances are very good that even if you don't love it, it will entertain you as it has so many others. Both subtitled and dubbed versions are wonderful. I would recommend the dubbed (english) version, simply because it's so well-done, and you will be able to enjoy the show more without having to read the subtitles.

Reviews by me go by "Keep it simple." rule so here it is:
Cowboy bebop is an excellen anime, no doub about that. But what makes it better than the others? Is it the uniqueness of the cahracters or the originality of the style? Or is it by a chance the flow of plot which is subtly injected into an episodic anime?
All those above are for sure reasons why it is better than the others, but the main reason is actually quite simple: Every time you see the typical
"See you space cowboy..."
at the end of each episode you just feel the urge to watch the next
                  one.
To make a long story short :) It is awesome and when it ends u will still want some more :)
Re-watch: (this is just subjective) Every time I re-watch the anime I have a feeling like I've found something new about the cahracters or the plot... What a strange feeling that is, I can't describe.

Cowboy Bebop is my favourite anime ever created.I remember the first time I saw it, it was airing on a channel called AnimeCentral in the UK. I was just flicking through channels at the dead of night, as soon as I landed on the channel I was blown away by the sheer brilliance of the soundtrack combining with the animation so perfectly.From that day on I watched it every night, religiously.This show was the whole reason I got into anime.
STORY (10)
Cowboy bebop is an episodic anime with a general plot underlying the whole series.The individual episodes have great stories within in them and are all
                  very different form each other and will keep you entertained.The underlying plot is superb, although there are not many episodes that are part of the main plot the story is told brilliantly.You really feel for the characters and personally the end was one of the saddest moments I have ever witnessed.
MUSIC(10)
Now, the music of Cowboy Bebop is still the best music you will hear in an anime.The music itself is fantastic but not only that, it goes perfectly with animation and really draws out the emotion from your very soul.Without the music Cowboy Bebop wouldn't be considered the legend that it is today.
CHARACTERS(10)
Characters much like the rest of the show are executed fantastically.Each of the characters has their own unique personality and background.They are all likeable, have there own storyline and character development.Cowboy Bebop uses the episodic nature of the show to show all the lives of the people and what they have been through and lets you get to really know the character.
ART(10)
The art is absolutely fantastic. Due to its darker colours and faded looks it adds to the general theme of the show as well adds to the more sombre mood of the show.(I don't really know much more about art and this is my first review so forgive me if that bit was a tad short)
Overall(10)
This anime is absolutely fantastic and you don't even have to like anime to like Cowboy Bebop as it crosses the boarder into a whole different realm where all the great anime belong and can be appriciated by anyone.This anime is an essential watch for anyone and especially anime fans.This anime will always, personally, be considered the best ever made. But I'm hoping there will be an anime to prove me wrong.But don't forget once you finish this anime You're Gonna Carry That Weight.

I apoligize for writing another review for this show on a different account, but I love writing reviews for this show and decided to write a more detailed one. Well, here we go.
Cowboy Bebop is probabaly one of the best anime shows on Earth and I'll tell you why. The artwork is amazing and so is the animation and is good for old-schoolers to enjoy. The animation makes you feel like you're back in the 70s along with the music. It's jazzy and has its blues from the 50s-60s I think.
Story:
The story focuses on a duo of bossy bounty hunters who happen to be poor
                  dogs. They need money so this guy named Jet (who's the owner of the ship) leads a man named Spike to help out to get some cash. They soon come across three other bounties and their names are Faye Valentine, the bossy gambler, Radical Edward, the playful but mischevious teen, and Ein, the smart and intelligent dog. Soon, their adventures begin... into an amazing one. I can't spoil the ending, but it does get funny every once in a while... it has its drama, comedy, romance, action and thriller, but is also very painful at the end... which most crybabies can't handle.
Sound:
I loved the jazzy music and blues in this. Especially with the Tank! opening or the Space Lion songs... both of these songs rocked and are one of my favorites in Cowboy Bebop. I also liked "Blues" too. And let me introduce the amazing voice actors they picked... Steven Jay Blum and Wendee Lee both did a great job with their characters and I thought that they had the best voices to ever exist in dubbed anime. At first, I never liked to watch anime dubbed, but now I'd want to watch it in subtitles except for Cowboy bebop, the voices really fit the characters' moods and attitudes and I'm very happy for the creator who did it. It was better than the Japanese subtitles... which were a lot better in dialouge because you could understand that some of the characters are moody every once in a while.
Characters:
Oh my gosh! My favorite is definietely Spike... he's my all-time favorite. And I loved Faye too... of course I didn't really care for her in the beginning, but now she seems like the funniest anime character ever behind Spike Spiegel. I also loved Ed too, who I'd say was pretty annoying at times, but I still loved her. Spike had his passion... he's quite mischevious and so is Faye who was pretty naughty, bossy and tomboyish while Ed is simply just onrery. Nothing to say about Jet but he was cool I guess. Ein was adorable!
Animation:
The animation seemd to match what the future may be like including the artwork. Yeah, I know it may be a little jumpier than most anime are, but it is pretty cool and I loved how they drew in the artwork for what how Mars, Jupiter or Asteriod would look like.
Enjoyment:
I guess I wasn't really enthused with the anime the first few episodes, but on Honky Tonk Woman, it got interesting... I didn't really like Gateway Shuffle very much, but Ballad of Fallen Angels made me want to watch the whole thing. There are very unique episodes such as Stray Dog Strut where Ein comes in and they have to track down a puppy, Honky Tonk Woman where they go to try to get money on gambling but coincendentally permitted a woman to join the team who is actually a bounty, Gateway Shuffle where they capture a bounty who is fond of her son, Sympathy for the Devil where Spike has to help this senior kid-looking guy turn into a senior so that he could die and many more. My favorite episode would have to be Brain Scratch, but Toys in the Attic where the Bebop was filled with plutonium was interesting too and then I enjoyed the series mainly the whole way through even though there were some episodes that weren't my cup of tea or were just nothing special.
Overall: A Great series to watch for the old-schoolers and definetely for anybody who doesn't watch anime... they could warm-up with a very good start on Cowboy Bebop unless they've seen a couple.

Now I had put off watching cowboy bebop for a LONG time.  My friend had talked to me about it, and I had sorta just taken a glance and put it to the side.  I finally picked it up after almost 7? months and I am so happy that I did.
Story:  Initially, I found the story to be somewhat slow and uninteresting.  However, as I progressed, I slowly fell in love with the episode-by-episode sort of style that Cowboy Bebop took on.  Each episode was a different plot.  However, what truly makes the story good is the characters. 
                  Each episode would simply not be complete without the funky music and personable characters that make the show so fun to watch.  The plots themselves are only brought to life because of the amazing backing.
Art:  Not much to say here except that I really enjoy the art.  The color palette is so fitting and it really just ties the show together so well.
Sound:  Genuinely one of the best soundtracks ever.  Each song is so unique and fits so well with the show.  I listen to the music in my free time, often when I'm cleaning (my favorites are Cats on Mars and Wo Qui Non Coin :)).  The opening is so different than the usual, yet it just fits so well!  I wish I could better express how much I enjoy the soundtrack and how great it is, but I really can't.
Character:  Like I said before, it's really the characters that bring the show to life.  The crew consists of Spike, Jet, Faye, and Ed.  Each episode is so interesting simply because they make it so enjoyable to watch!  My personal favorite was Ed, who was a silly and fun side character,  When she left, I was somewhat suprised to feel myself shed some tears.  
Overall, I really enjoyed this show, and it's one of my favorites for sure.  Hell, I rewatch it so often whenever I'm feeling down (particularly episode 17).  I highly recommend this show.

[STORY: 7/10]
I'll say that the overall story is good, but what holds it back is its tendency to be cliché and even boring at times. A couple of episodes are completely irrelevant to the main story, and with only twenty-six episodes and a movie to portray this story, it can get annoying, as those slots could've been used to better develop the characters or feature a way more interesting adventure.
[ART: 10/10]
The art for this show is older and very pleasing to the eye. Alot of the character design and set pieces are very unique and creative, putting together an atmosphere that is epic in scope
                  and beautiful to look at.
[SOUND: 10/10]
The show is known for its iconic soundtrack containing heavy jazz influence and it really sets the style and mood for the show. The music fits the designated scenes and is very pleasant to listen to. The voice actors are very good and give their characters life, and I've heard the dub is just as good as the sub, which is a rare occurrence. 
[CHARACTERS: 6/10]
There are some very interesting (albeit not all very original) characters that occupy the main cast of this show. The main downside is a lack of character development throughout. Relationships are built, but unless it's a major part of the story, mostly nothing changes. Almost each and every episode or set of episodes follows a separate adventure that could be watched in any order and it wouldn't make much difference. This isn't inherently bad, but for the characters we grow to care for, we want to see them grow and change, finding out who they are and why they do what they do. Sadly, we just don't get enough of that here.
[ENJOYMENT/OVERALL: 7/10]
Alot of people won't dare to criticize this show, either because it was their introduction to the medium or they are afraid of the backlash that comes with this show's popularity here. I would say I enjoyed my time watching this series, but it isn't mind-blowing or game-changing for me. I do appreciate the unique atmosphere, characters, and story when it's good, but the way the show is done, it just falls short too much to warrant anything above a seven.

A lot of people think Cowboy Bebop is the greatest anime ever made. There is quite a simple reason why that is, and that's because it's almost objectively true. Even if you don't agree with that, which some of you might after completing the show, it's a fact that Cowboy Bebop with all its iconic-ness and themes has become one of the most influential pieces of not only Japanese visual media, but even worldwide. I will keep this as short as possible, and will refrain from using any spoilers (except for vague descriptions of the general themes, and opinions/emotions regarding events that happen late in
                  the series. I WILL NOT describe those events in any way, shape or form, so be calm). This is my first review, so feedback would be appreciated.
STORY - 8/10
For promotional purposes, the series' creative director Shinichiro Watanabe said in the initial presentation that Cowboy Bebop would be "A new genre unto itself". Why he said so becomes apparent to anyone that watches the series past episode 1, where it becomes apparent that the show really can't be categorised under a single genre. It pulls inspiration from so many different visual media that it almost literally becomes a new genre. It has themes from genres like western, science-fiction, crime, mafia, romance, post-apocalyptic, even a bit of horror, and the list goes on. There even are a few homages to popular western media (like one that I especially adored somewhere in the middle of the series, which I won't spoil, but it has a hilarious conclusion). Anyway, all I'm saying is, it will make you laugh, it will make you cry, and most important of all, it will make you watch the series to the end.
 The plot takes place in the late 21st century, with technology being as futuristic as you would expect; Space ships, planetary colonisation, and, of course, bounty-hunters. The main character Spike Spiegel is one of those bounty-hunters with an unknown past (which becomes more clear in later episodes). He is joined by his friend Jet, an ex-cop who lost his arm in an accident, years ago. They both go hunt bounties each episode, which usually ends up in them receiving no money at all.
The episodes are set up in a 'monster-of-the-week' style chronology, with overarching plot-lines occasionally bopping their head in to make the viewer remember they were there in the first place. This type of storytelling really has a lot of downsides, and is mainly the reason why I didn't give the story a 9/10. If you don't know what 'monster-of-the-week' means, it means that every episode is basically its own arc of the story, with new characters (aside from the main cast) coming in every episode. The big downside is that any buildup made in the previous arc is usually mostly forgotten by the time the next arc starts (this happens a few times later in). However, I'm not saying it is all bad. Because Cowboy Bebop has literally a bazillion different genres and themes, it's easier for the storywriters to address one or more themes per episode, instead of making it a huge clusterfuck of themes and ideas in one giant 24-episode plot. All-in-all, I think it could have been done better, but it would be really difficult.
ART - 9/10
I can't say much about the art except that it was pretty good. The fights are well-choreographed, the animation is smooth, however, it being such an old anime kind of has its downsides which may be hard to get used to. For example, the CG in some episodes are really outdated and practically destroy the immersion, but thankfully the CG is used extremely rarely. Most scenes are very well-made and even ahead of its time at some points. It really holds up well (aside from the CG).
SOUND - 10/10
Oh lawd, the music.
I can safely say that Cowboy Bebop (especially the movie) has the best anime soundtrack ever made. Like the series itself, it really is a mix of all kinds of genres. One episode you may be listening to a wonderfully composed vocal track, and the next episode you might be listening to a piece of hard rock. It not only enhances the thrill, or the enjoyment of certain scenes, it enhances any kind of scene. Dramatic, comedic, action-packed, silly, happy, sad, you name it. Yoko Kanno is by all means an amazing composer, and she even outdid herself. I can't even describe the feelings I felt when I first heard some of these amazingly well-done tracks, and it really is an experience I probably have only felt with maybe a handful of other anime. To round this segment up, Cowboy Bebop's soundtrack is amazing, and you should NOT listen to any tracks before watching the series, as it's kind of spoiler-y.
As an extra, I can't really say much about the original Japanese dubs, as I'm not Japanese, but I can certainly say that the English dub is incredibly well done, and if you aren't Japanese, I advise you to watch the dub instead of the sub.
CHARACTER - 9/10
Ah, the 90s. Character archetypes were still in their infancy, new archetypes were made up everywhere. It was all pioneering. This series might not have the most original characters ever made, but they certainly have amazing backstories. In a way, the character-building might have both gained and lost some of its values because of the 'monster-of-the-week' format. It gained some since every single backstory is bloody beautiful, and the format condenses much more character backstories into a shorter timeframe. On the downside, this makes it so the character buildup feels slightly rushed sometimes, and, like I said in the STORY segment, sometimes these buildups are just completely forgotten by the next episode. For example, there's one episode late in the anime where one of the main cast's characters who has amnesia basically finds out their past, with a terribly sad/dramatic ending to the episode. What, do you expect the drama to go on the next episode? Nope, just back to bounty-hunting with a new bounty to hunt. I might be spoiling things a bit here, but it's just a heads-up.
ENJOYMENT - 10/10
Personal enjoyment is probably the biggest factor in the end-score, which is a good thing for Cowboy Bebop because I enjoyed every last second of it. I can't really explain why. The anime is extremely enjoyable, there.
OVERALL - 9/10
Does Cowboy Bebop deserve to be engraved in culture forever? Yes. Yes it does. You honestly do yourself a disservice if you don't watch this before your 10th anime. Cowboy Bebop is a classic of anime, and visual media as a whole. The story is amazing and original, the art is good, and still holds up now, the sound is fucking amazing, the characters are interesting, and the series is enjoyable. What more do you want? A hyper-intelligent space-corgi? Oh, wait...

Cowboy Bebop is outstanding in every way. The only aspect it fell even a little short on was characters, but it was practically unnoticeable. The premise is a fantasy that I'm sure many people had wished were real since the discovery of other planets. The premise of humanity colonizing other planets in the solar system and bounty hunters roam the seas of space to catch criminals opens itself to a plentiful amount of settings to place your characters. Paired with it's stunning art that'll be sure to hold up forever, the plot and setting never cease to amaze the eyes. The sound in this show
                  is astounding. With it's classic opening, Tank, and it's jazzy soundtrack. It's simply like candy for the ears. Now here's what I was saying before on falling flat somewhere. The characters in this show don't go as far as they could've. But that doesn't mean that they aren't still great. They're still charming, lovable, and leave an emotional attachment even after finishing watching. This sets up one specific part of the show that still hangs with me and will continue to hang with me as long as I remember the name "Cowboy Bebop." This'll contain a spoiler, but i'm not sure how anyone hasn't finished Cowboy Bebop yet or had this spoiled for them yet. Skip to this 
"--" mark for when the spoiler ends. My favorite and at the same time least favorite part of this show is when Spike dies. His death is set up all too perfectly that I hate whoever sat down and wrote it. The entire show made us become attached to Spike to the point that I even felt like he was a close friend. So when he passed in the ending, it dug deep. It does it even better with how it's timed too. With a couple episodes of build up to Spike confronting his past. It slowly sinks into you that Spike is not going to come back. The characters in the show also slowly come to terms with this as well as they say their last goodbyes to Spike when they never wanted to part in the first place. Everyone that knew Spike(except Ed and Ein) know that someone they never thought they'd become close with is leaving in such a cruel way. Then to top it all off, the show ends on a shot of Spike's smile as he lies on the ground lifeless with the final words appearing on the screen. "You're gonna carry that weight" Powerful words that'll stick forever. -- Cowboy Bebop is a ride of fun, action, and lovable characters. It honestly does deserve it's crown that the fans gave it. There isn't a single person who shouldn't watch this show, even if they somehow don't like it. This show rightfully deserves a 10. That's about it. Until next time, see you space cowboy.

The basic premise and presentation are evocative of Whedon-san's Firefly, right down to the stand-alone nature of many of the episodes and the lamentable yet appropriate brevity of the series' as a whole. Interactions between the characters are always lively and engaging, and no part of an episode is ever wasted. Everything, even the music, works together to tell the stories of the bounties and the cowboys alike, each episode dovetailing to form a richly populated universe that serves as the stage for the members of the Bebop in their struggles to come to terms with their pasts, their comrades, and their woefully meager cash
                  flow.

A modest success in it's home country that became a bigger hit once it aired on Adult Swim in 2001, Watanabe's jazz-infused space western has become one of anime's most enduring classics and for good reason. To a lot of people in the early 2000s, CB was their gateway anime and it's by far one of the most accessible titles due to the fact that it almost feels tailor-made for western audiences given how the show heavily draws from westerns, john woo action flicks, and film noir. 
Despite being mostly episodic in nature with the over-arching story being relatively thin (only 5 ep touch on
                  the Spike vs. Vicious plot), CB manages to stay engaging throughout due to it's intoxicating atmosphere, immersive world-building, layered characters, light-hearted comedy and memorable scenarios. Plenty of my favorite anime episodes ever are in CB (Ex. Ballad of Fallen Angels, Sympathy for the Devil, Ganymede Elegy, Jupiter Jazz). CB also has one of the greatest and most satisfying endings to any show ever. 
The English dub by Animaze is also deserving of all the praise it gets as one of the greatest dubs of all time with Steve Blum, Beau Billingslea, Wendee Lee and Melissa Fahn delivering iconic performances. Not a single voice sounds out of place and the line deliveries sound so natural. Probably my personal favorite of the show's guest stars was Daran Norris as Andy von de Oniyate, who is a complete riot! 
When a dub is so good that even the most hardened sub-purists would tell you to watch the show in English first before the Japanese, then you know it's something truly special. 
While I have nothing but love for CB, there are a couple of flaws that prevent me from giving it a perfect score. Given it's episodic nature, inevitably there are going to be episodes that are better than others. Despite containing plenty of good to even great episodes, there are a couple stories that come out average (Ex. Bohemian Rhapsody) and episode 21 (Boogie Woogie Feng Shui) is a straight-up stinker. It also would have been nice if the over-arching plot episodes were more evenly spread out throughout the show's run. 
There is also a part of me that wishes the show utilized Ed more often in the plots. I love Ed and her surreal comic antics never fail to put a smile on my face, but we rarely get to see her put her computer hacking skills to good use. 
One character that I felt could have used more development was Vicious. We never get much of a glimpse of what Spike and Vicious' relationship was like in the past. Vicious also does not have much of personality and thus feels more like a force of nature than a fully-fleshed out character. Maybe the whole force of nature thing was the point but nonetheless, Vicious always came off as one of the show's less interesting elements. 
Despite some of these minor issues, I still come back to CB often and watch the series at least once every year. There is a lot of re-watch value due to it's subtle deep existential themes and well-crafted stories.

It's the very definition of anime for me, and from what it seems a classic for many. It oozes class and a great degree of style. The European and American influences may be the reason why I consider it so, but nevertheless, it's a great overall package. Another point that sticks out is the great jazz, blues and soul soundtrack - does not quite sound obvious at all for an anime set in the year 2071 on the planet Mars, does it?
It's the anime that got me into it all and made me set up an account here, for what it counts.

"An anime that was delivered to the bebop with no return address. Because we wanted to view the tape, things took a turn for the unexpected. Well actually it doesn't go anywhere, at first glance the story is pointless, the action is on a small scale and the ending is forced but then again what conclusions will you draw from it?" - Jet Black
Next episode: I don't give a shit because there is nothing to look forward to in this anime, the story I kid you not actually made me fall asleep. The characters were so undeveloped I didn't cry when any of them died,
                  Viscious is also just a one-dimensional villain who is bad for the sake of being bad.
The fact that I even got through this entire anime is a miracle, I usually get swayed by public opinion alot, like for example if an anime gets really high ratings and I watch it, I would give it a rating higher than I thought it was. But Cowboy Bebop was such a let down, I just can't lie about my feelings. So yes, it is boring and it is overrated.

Very rarely can I give an anime an across the board 10/10 rating. Cowboy Bebop is deserving of such high regard. Followin Spike Spiegel and his crew of bounty hunters about the Cowboy Bebop in a futuristic setting, this anime has a unique feel. It is a mix of the wonder of science fiction, the mystery of classic anime, and that bit of adventure found in many American shows. Yoko Kanno's composition for the soundtrack includes majorly jazz style music, a style not commonly found in anime. Though each episode is its own story, the underlying arc that links it all together leaves the watcher
                  longing to see more. The unexpected ending gives a feeling of completion but still leaves that sliver of a possibility for the story to continue. 
Cowboy Bebop is very similar to the American Scifi show Firefly and it quite likely a source of inspiration for it. Watching Cowboy Bebop is a blast. At times it will put you at the edge of your seat in anticipation and at other points falling to the floor in laughter. Definately a classic masterpiece.

This is one of those classic Anime series that will always be fresh in people’s minds even if it gets older and older.
I loved it a lot.
When I watched Cowboy Bebop first, I was pretty excited given the fact that I had heard a lot of positive reviews about this.
Though it is just 26 episodes, halfway through the show, I started to feel a bit bored.
This was because the story didn’t follow the main storyline. This series is unique because it is an episodic one. That means, the episodes featured individual stories with different adventures.
But I made myself watch it and boy! It was a
                  great decision to continue watching this greatness.
Not to get you excited but the ending of this show is just mind-boggling!!
The past of the bounty hunters (main cast) in this show is explored in a unique way.
SEE YOU, SPACE COWBOY!

Space cowboys be like. Before watching this I had gotten the "bebop hype" as I'd like to call it. I had asked some friends before hand of what they thought about it and should I watch it. I wasn't too much ready for this anime, expecting  some form of complex plot or something of the sort. But I was wrong. Instead, I just got prices of the crazy life of Spike and Jet. The episodes don't have any real chronological order, except for the first few episodes, and that what I like about it. The fights scenes paired with the art style, are what
                  really sparked my interest though. Don't even get me started on the fight scenes. Although they are quite rare in the anime, they show real combat that involves the environment quite a lot. I also enjoyed watching the side main characters get involved with Spike and Jet's adventures as well. I'd highly recommend this anime for perhaps new comers and for people who just wanna watch something not too mind boggling.

The Positive Side:  Cowboy Bebop was the first anime I could really get into as an adult, and its maturity remains one of the things that sets it apart from most popular anime of its time.  After watching hokey kids’ stuff like Pokémon and the cheesy, attack-name-screaming, adolescent violence of Dragon Ball Z, I was a little surprised to find an anime I could actually take seriously.  Despite it being science fiction, Cowboy Bebop’s setting feels both believable and extremely original.  The smokey, ill-lit bars and gray, rain-washed city-streets could have been pulled straight out of a crime noir film, and
                  there’s a joy in watching hi-tech innovations like space-ships and computer hackers interact with mafia hierarchies and drug deal plots.
Despite hailing from the era of pre-digital animation, Cowboy Bebop’s art is superb.  The character designs are striking and memorable, and there’s just enough color to offset the generally somber backgrounds.  The fight scenes are particularly wonderful, and Spike’s martial arts motto, “Be like water,” translates into action that is both fluid and visceral.
As for the music… well, just about the entire soundtrack is composed by Yoko freakin’ Kanno, perhaps the greatest musical talent in the anime industry.  The Seatbelts deliver a blend of jazz, blues and rock that moves from melancholy to energetic and back in perfect sync with the story.  The lyrics are pretty terrific on tracks that have them, so it’s worth putting an ear to the OST.
The character development is all-around great.  Our protagonist, Spike Spiegel, has more than enough casually badass attitude and ass-whupping ability to serve as an escapist character, but also has just enough brooding moments that you can feel how his past has scarred him.  Jet is an ideal foil, constantly fretting and worrying over Spike’s well-being like a surrogate father while insisting that he doesn’t care what happens to Spike if he leaves.  Faye serves as wild-card, shifting femme fatale to ally at the drop of a hat, constantly keeping the audience guessing as to where her loyalties lie, or if they even exist.  Ed is a consistently bubbly comic relief, but also contributes to the team through her incredible hacking abilities.  Even minor characters who are only present for an episode or two gleam with life and intrigue.
The show gives us a good look at how people struggle against their own pasts.  There are plenty of other themes—vengeance, war, and ambition—but at its heart, this is a story about the struggles between past and future, a theme captured by the anachronistic setting as well as by the struggles of our intrepid bounty hunters.
The Negative Side: Where does Cowboy Bebop come up short?  Well… uh… it isn’t the cure for cancer, nor will it help you lose 20 pounds in 30 days.
Joking aside, this anime is about as close to perfect as they come.  Some fans are put off by the plot structure, which is far more episodic than most anime, but every episode is capable of standing on its own, so it really doesn’t suffer from a lack of over-arching plot.  Criticizing Cowboy Bebop simply because its structure is different is more a failure on the part of the critic than it is a failure on the part of the work.  Take the show for what it is, and you won’t be disappointed.

Wether you have experience watching anime or are just a newbie like me, you have probably heard about the so popular and controversial Cowboy Bebop. 
The anime raises two main discussions that i would like to mention in this review: 
- That it's overrated
- That it's "style over substance"
To the first statement, i partially disagree. To the second one, i am utterly against. Just let me explain. 
I can understand why a person would harbour the opinion that Cowboy Bebop is so popular that people tend to automatically rate it a ten even before starting the series, saying that it has absolutely no flaws
                  whatsoever. No piece of work is free of having flaws, not even this masterpiece of an anime, and that is a fact that we all must face. I can mention a couple if you want me to, like the episodic way in which the series was arranged bringing too many convenient coincidences and abrupt conclusions to some conflicts. But when those flaws acquire little relevance compared to the positive aspects and do not tamper with the overall quality of the show, that's when we find a good series worth watching. 
The enjoyment a person experiences while watching it is completely personal depending on his or her own preferences and that is why i can totally understand the different ratings this series gets. But something i consider extremely important when reviewing any piece of work is separating our own subjective opinion from the objective view. Subjectively, you may enjoy the episodic arrangement of the anime and its theme or not, but objectively it is almost impossible to state that this series does not have lots of magnificent effort put to good use wether its in the audiovisuals or the character development or any other technical aspect. The combination of those two is what makes a propper review. 
That is why it really bugs me when i find people saying cowboy bebop is overrated and then continue justifying it with facts that revolve more around personal tastes than anything else. 
I, for example, don't tend to enjoy nor episodical nor space anime and that is why it took me so long to pick this up. And yes, it  was a little slow to me because of that, but the fact that i enjoyed it anyways and even finished it actually amazed is a proof of good quality. I could have rated it a 9, but i realised it wasn't fair for the series itself when comparing it to the other animes in my list and the ratings i gave them, because Cowboy Bebop seriously seems like it's made of something else. 
Moving on to the "style over substance" matter, i do think that's truly a complete nonsense.  Yes, the style is magnificent and we all can agree to that. The art is good though not a wonder to me, but the animation is flawless, especially in the facial expresions and in the space related movements (meaning laws of physics are not broken and it actually seems realistic and coherent). The music is something from another dimension really. Someone could think that it would be a total mess considering all the different genres of music being played that can either match or not the theme of the anime, but in the end that does not even matter because it mixes so well the scene that it's overwhelming. It's like some words are cut because they are not need, it's the music that speaks to you about the atmosphere and how characters feel. 
But style is not merely enough to make an anime good, and here comes the substance of it which i think is fantastic. This is the first anime i have seen so far that made me really think of the characters as real people. They are so well done and their background is for each one of them so very well developed i was really amazed. The action scenes provide their moments of badassery for the characters but are not overly pretentious and do not cross the line of coherence and possibility. The plot could have it's occasional flaws here or there, but it is obvious that it was carefully sewed into place, so as to establish a sequencial plot involved with the past of the characters even in an episodical series. 
Conclusion: please watch it. It really stands out how this anime is different from the rest and a unique piece of work.

To be completely honest I was lucky enough to be introduced to anime through this medium, with its stylistic art and music with help from many a western reference watching this anime was a joy. The characters were great to watch with aspects of mystery that kept you intrigued and guessing, suave Spike, battle-hardened Jet, the smart yet vaguely annoying Edward, and the kinda (well no other way to say this...) bitchy but lovable Faye Valentine. As the show goes on in the latter part of the series it starts to veer off from the western media-inspired tales and tell its own, about spike and
                  the only woman he has claimed to love Julia along with the ever-present threat Viscious. The ending was powerful, stylistic action-packed and really brought the story to an end. Overall 9 out of 10. 
I didn't come into the show thinking it was a classic but definitely left that way.

What can I say about this show that hasn't already been said by everyone else that has ever reviewed this show? Despite the fact that I have watch the show beginning to end almost, and the movie which is also great, almost 10 times. Probably not much.
First the bad:
Well, if you are not a fan of action/drama oriented anime this show won't change your mind. That is pretty much all of the bad I can think of in terms of flaws.
The good:
This show is definitely in the top 25 anime for a reason. Fans of action, drama, sci-fi, or film noir anime agree pretty unanimously
                  that this show is a must see.
The animation, despite being nearly 20 years old, holds up extremely well and all the action scenes are still beautiful to look at.
The characters are all memorable, cool, well written, well developed, and 3 dimensional.
The soundtrack is arguably the greatest in all of anime. Especially if you are and lover of jazz and blues.
The writing is amazing. It has some of the greatest dialogue in anime and knows when dialogue isn't needed. The story is presented in a way that does not insult the audiences intelligence and I can't think of a single instance of exposition (when character's speak in a way just so they can give information to the audience).
Also, the dub is incredible. It is arguably the best dub in anime history and a must see. I have talked with people who refuse to watch dubs, that prefer Bebop dubbed. Some of the original Japanese voice actors and the creator of the series himself even admitted that the dub is better.
This is easily my favorite anime and I can talk all day about why I love it, but I will spare you such torment so you can go watch the series ASAP.

A colorful mix of westerns, sci-fi, gangsters, kung-fu, parts of alien and the blaxploitation cinema with a lot of jazz results in a perfect anime series like no other.
Shinichiro Watanabe and his team create a bounty hunter troop that will never be forgotten in your life.
The show doesn't live on a big storyline. She lives off the bepop crew consisting of Spike, Jet, Faye, Ed and the dog Ein. Each episode deals with a new adventure in a different genre.
The series is split with episodes that are there to entertain and the other half is far more profound than it initially seems.
The most famous antagonist
                  from Cowboy Bepop is probably Vicious from Spike's storyline.
The biggest antagonist the crew has to deal with, however, is the past of the individual members who catch up with them.
The characters are always confronted with their personal past and learn to let go of it and look ahead.
In the conversations within the group, you realize that they all harbor a grudge against each other and don't talk to each other much except when it comes to bounty or food.
As soon as they realize that they need and are dependent on each other, you are already in the last 3 episodes and have to watch with tears in your eyes what is happening with this legendary group of bounty hunters.
In the end, I don't have much to say except that Cowboy Bepop will be worthwhile for everyone and that you can expect a wild ride from many film & music genres.

(I apologize in advance if this review turns out to be terrible) Cowboy Bebop. What's there to say about it other than it being one of the most successful 90's animes in the western hemisphere. Its possible (after watching the series) to understand why people hold it in such high regard. Bebop is nothing short of an amazing series where you have a slew of characters that are just plain fun to watch and who get into situations that are always interesting to see how they turn out. I personally found Bebop to be a fantastic show due to it's characters, atmosphere, and soundtrack. If
                  you're the kind of person to enjoy a good gun-slinging, smooth, and above all else cool anime then you should watch Cowboy Bebop. I can guarantee that you'll be satisfied.

TL;DR - The episodic nature that involves different genres is a blessing and a curse, but there is some cohesion between each episode. The characters are full and well-developed and the OST is on another level. Additionally, the show is directed beautifully. Although the age has shown in the art, it still looks good. Watch every episode, but if unsure as to whether to watch to completion, try to watch through at least episode 5. English dub is great, too.
--Full Review--
     Cowboy Bebop is lauded by many to be the one of the greatest, if not the greatest, piece of art
                  to come from Japan. This praise does lead to a lot of exaggeration of what it does right and the ignorance of the flaws which are in this piece of work. This is not to take away from what Cowboy Bebop does well. When it is good, you might have to take a moment to appreciate it, but then again, what I enjoyed might not be your cup'o'tea.
    Cowboy Bebop is episodic in nature, even if the the episodes occur chronologically and a few episodes will recall events of previous episodes. Each episode is a new bounty to collect or a new issue to deal with. There are a few "two part episodes", but that is the longest the show presents a continuous event. On top of this, many of the episodes tackle a different theme or concept that seems to be influenced by a western film. An example of this is "Toys in the Attic", which is inspired by Alien. This, along with the music selection, makes Cowboy Bebop very friendly for newcomers or the western world.
     This episodic nature can be a curse and a blessing. While a vast majority of the episodes are extremely well done, there are a few episodes that remain unmemorable. One or two of these are agreed upon, but others are debated largely. This stems from the wide variety of subjects and themes. You might not enjoy "Bohemian Rhapsody" and "Brain Scratch Fever" simply because you are not a fan of the thriller, mystery genre, but highly enjoy the comedic nature of "Cowboy Funk" and "Mushroom Samba" instead. The combination of styles and genres leads to biases from the audience, but at the same time guarantees that there is something for everyone to love.
    However, for a first time watch through, watching every episode is a good idea. They play off of each other very well, and this is part of the reason this show is so highly praised. Each episode fleshes out the crew of the Bebop even more, sometimes causing you to recall previous episodes to see how the character has either changed or remained the same.
    Additionally, for a first time watcher, I recommend trying to stick it out until you have completed episode 5 "Ballad of the Fallen Angels". I have yet to read or hear that someone disliked that episode. The characterization, the action, the music, etc. are all present and done well. I have heard other people say that this is where the show really starts. I do tend to agree, but at the same time, the four episodes previous are all necessary to get the most out of it.
     Also, the English dub is really well done. Steve Blum as Spike alone makes the English a recommended watch, but all of the other characters are cast with great choices. I have yet to watch the Japanese except through clips, but I have watched it in English multiple times. I'll stick to English on this one. I tend to not have preference in the matter when picking a show to watch, but this one has my vote for English 100% of the time.
     Now that I got that all out of the way, I'll try to hit the different aspects of the show.
--Story--(8)
     The episodic nature does prevent a true over-arching story to unfold through the show, but each episode carries its own unique personality. All of the episodes are well done, but at the same time, there are forgettable episodes. The backstory, however, is well presented for each character, leading up to one of the best endings for a show that I've ever seen.
--Art--(7)
     For the age of the show, the artwork has held up. It might not be as clean as modern shows, or as fluid, but it still can be breathtaking. The age shows a bit, but how its held up over the years and the use of shots to help tell the story that is being portrayed is a testament to the show itself.
--Sound--(10)
    That the OST for this show is great is practically indisputable. The use of Jazz, Rock, Chorus, and more leads to a beautiful mix of sounds. The OP and ED are also amazing, making it difficult to skip if you tend to do that. Music is also used well throughout the show. It is placed in great moments and really helps get any message across.
--Enjoyment--(9)
     This is something that will vary most among people who have watched this show. Certain episodes will appeal more than others. This is something that is unavoidable, however, the show can still be captivating, even during those episodes that you might think that you would be inclined to skip.

This show is a timeless classic, after watching I honestly don't know why the heck I kept putting this show off. Because it's one of the best shows I've EVER seen. The music is so outstanding, I had the soundtrack looped for days. The cast is lovable, yet also have their own pasts, their own story. The script is very well written, with a lot of badass quotes you'd want to note down and keep them for use. As for the story... it goes from light-hearted comedy to complex, mature themes, but the balance is perfectly maintained, where serious scenes are weaved into the episodes
                  in little bits and pieces. Despite not getting Spike's past laid out right smack at you, the flashbacks were more than enough for you to piece things together, and the entire process of figuring out is what makes it exhilarating. I'm just sad Ed and Ein had to leave at the end, and that there can never be a continuation to this AMAZING show. Also, animes these days really REALLY need to bring back jazz music fight scenes.

Cowboy Bebop is a quite simplistic series. There's an overarching plot in there, but mostly it's an episodic series that starts the first couple of episodes setting up some plot points, spending an episode in the middle bringing it up again (so you don't forget, I guess) and in the final episode it all comes to a close. The rest of the episodes are basically you following the crew on their adventures and getting to know them a bit more.
Normally, this would be a problem for me. This series, albeit short with only 26 episodes, is like Naruto on steroids. If you decided to skip
                  the episodes that have nothing to do with the set up plot, you would have an anime of about six episodes. However, it's the simplicity of Cowboy Bebop that makes this somehow work. It's not 500 episodes long, which makes me... not mind it at all, so to speak. In fact, it does the job like a charm.
The cast is nice and compact, with only four characters to focus on, which the series does a good job of fleshing out. At the end of the series, I found myself not really having a favourite character, in the sense that every character was nicely balanced out and all just as likable as the other.
My biggest praise goes to the sound design. This series does sound REALLY well. It's a pretty quiet series, featuring sound effects and voice acting mostly. Only on selected occasions are you treated by the series' outstanding music.
In the 23 years long life I've led until now, I never was very big on anime. Sure, I grew up with Pokemon, but that was really about it. Really, this is like my first serious anime. My indifference towards anime completely changed after having finished Cowboy Bebop. It's the first anime I watched from start to end, in about a week or so, and I'm planning to watch many more anime in the future.
Cowboy Bebop is amazing in all its simplicity. It's a mature tale, with nothing too grand and epic. Definitely would watch again.

As my rating shows, this is (completely subjective) a masterpiece.
It has everything that an anime (particularly 90s anime) should have. The right pacing, the right story, the right characterisations, the right visuals, the right soundtracks, and of course the right coda (ending) of the show.
The anime has 26 episodes and that's enough. It does not need seasons to complete or lengthy episodes to solidify its status as a legendary show. It only needs 26 episodes to show the anime that it means business, with the delicate characters like Spike and Faye, strong and mature Jet, with the addition of goofy but intelligent Ed and Ein.
                  26 episodes to explore about humans and their lives; discovering the past, making peace with the past, and even escaping the past. 
The anime also gives lessons like 'things happen for some reasons', 'make your own stride because no one's gonna run your life for you', and 'people are walking on different paths', or at least that's what I saw from the show. Those things add more value to this piece of art.
The only downsides are some episodes could be bland, not as exciting or action-packed as the others, but you will have some favourite moments from this. My favourite episodes are 'Pierrot le Fou', because it crept me out, and the final 2 episodes. Witness them yourself.

This show is the Gold Standard for Space Westerns.  I dare you not to like this show.  This show has passion, heart, story telling, ambiance, and a fkn Corgi.  Listen hear you little sheet stain, if you are one of these new age "Otaku's" that sleeps with body pillows of your favorite Slice of Life character, then go somewhere else.  If you think an Anime's greatness is defined by some 13 year old kids voiced by a female actress inheriting super powers, then go somewhere else.  If you think lens flare and sharp lines are what "good animation" looks like,
                  then go somewhere else.  But if your a hard azz parachute rigger with a five finger discount at your local gas station, then this anime is for you.

!!! COWBOY BEBOP IS AN AMAZING ANIME !!!
Cowboy bebop is a masterpiece, it's amazing, funny, relatable, hyped up and sad, it's everything you'll want in an anime which is perfect. Through all of the characters that may leave or pass, all of the pot twists and how the turn out may end. This anime I cannot nitpick at simply. It's amazing, so lets talk about that.
Cowboy Bebop starts with out protagonist called Spike Spiegel, who if I could describe I find Spike to be Reckless, Relaxed, and a lot like water. In an episode when people think he dies, instead of freaking out like your
                  classic boring protagonist like Deku from My Hero (IMO), what spike does instead is he lights a cigarette and says. "Oh well, whatever happens happens." That quote from our amazing protagonist got me hooked into this show and eventually makes him different from all the others characters on the Bebop crew. Whats the bebop crew? Well let me tell you....
The bebop crew is the crew Spike is in during the show, like his team. During the show then end up gaining more characters which could leave, betray, or die at anytime. Plot Armour isn't big in this show so you can't say that there's a huge flay related to it because there simply isn't. A lot of the members are different, We have Spike, our reckless underdog, Jet, the leader and the more quick thinking person of the pack. Faye Valentine. The hot blooded savage of the group, And my favorite member; Edward, who is the comedic, funny thinking mad hacker of this group who uses his skills for a laugh and entertainment.
This show isn't your classic shounen and myself wouldn't even call it Shounen, I would call it art and simply downright amazing with how the characters go, the fight scenes, resemblances and more. If there was anything that I would say would be the worst in the show, the only thing that I could possibly say isn't as good as the other amazing aspects in the show would be the art (which literally isn't bad) also here's a tip but if you turn your brightness down really low then it looks like normal animation and looks really smooth and clean so thank me later. Tee Hee!
Essentially I found this show to be perfect for beginners and to be downright amazing. The fact that Spike's fighting style is Referenced off of Jacky Chan and more and just how the character is made make's him not like any other, and literally just perfect. If you haven't watched this show I recommend you do it now, this is simply amazing
Rating: 10/10)

Anyway, starting off with the usual: the visuals. The art style is somewhat gritty and dark, very similar to Western animation, and misses some of the usual tropes we’ve come to expect from anime – huge eyes, crazy spiky hair, et cetera. The only character who looks particularly anime-like is Faye, but she’s a visual anomaly all to herself. Seriously, what in the world was up with her clothes? I could overlook that in a less serious anime than this but it’s so freaking hard to take the show seriously when this woman is dancing around in a… whatever kind of get-up that is. I
                  don’t even know how to describe it. Anyway, the animation is pretty consistently smooth and good-looking, although they like to notch it up during fight scenes. You’ll rarely see fight scenes as dynamic and sexy as those in Cowboy Bebop. All considered, this anime looks awesome, although not particularly like an anime.
The cast of characters is also obviously influenced by Western entertainment. Spike, the laidback, goofy badass; Jet, the battle-hardened mechanic and only responsible person on the Bebop; Faye, the tempestuous and self-absorbed woman; they all feel like they were pulled right out of a Western show and animated. Ed is the only exception here – she’s too heavily moe to really be anything but an anime character. The show focuses almost exclusively on developing these four characters’ backstories, and resolving their conflicts from the past. All of them have some sort of important past – Spike and Faye especially – and each episode usually happens to bring those pasts back to them. It makes for a cast of characters that have more depth than many I’ve seen in anime before.
The story – yeah, that’s right, also pretty Western-influenced. The show is heavily episodic, where each episode contains its own small story that’s resolved by the end, except for a pair of stories that were both spread into two consecutive episodes. However, like I mentioned earlier, these little stories have a tendency of bringing in, with incredible regularity, parts of the several grander, over-arching storylines that pervade the show. What looks at first like it could be just another bounty being tracked down, might somehow actually connect to some part of Jet’s old life, or Faye’s, or Spike’s, or even Ed’s (although I think Ed only has one episode that deals with her past). And if the episode doesn’t do that, then it instead uses that bounty to highlight the issues of the setting – usually political issues, sometimes just personal issues that have been blown out of proportion. Pretty much every episode has another layer of depth and meaning to it (except maybe the mushroom one because I don’t really know what the point of that one was).
Basically, this anime rocks and you should watch it. It has a startling level of depth and complexity that is uncommon in anime, especially modern anime. The only thing to really look out for is the decidedly non-Eastern style, but I seriously doubt that could ever be a problem. This show is too damn good to dislike for a dumb reason like that.

THIS IS THE ANIME EVER
To this day, the style and overall direction are unmatched. I adore the smooth execution of the space/sci-fi genre with western and noir influence. 
Bebop is so sure of itself and never wavers in what it set out to do. It oozes with confidence. It's flashy but subtle, it's got attitude but it's also very sensitive - Cowboy Bebop always strikes the perfect balance and I still don't know how they did it.
The overall and per-episode plots as well as the themes were enjoyable. I think everything I have to say about the characters has already been said. Basically, I love
                  them and I will leave it at that.

This anime is an absolute masterpiece. It is a marvel. I can't believe I was lucky enough to be born into an era where art like this exists. Every backdrop, is like a painting. The characters are all memorable. The music is original to the anime and is honestly very good. The music fits the mood of the plot when it's played, and the music helps drive the plot as well. The dialogue is authentic. It feels like real people are interacting witch each other. The story is so mysterious, and every episode has it's own unique story line as well.  
Cowboy bebop has
                  a "villain of the week" aspect to it, but there is an over arching storyline. The way they introduce new characters is like finding long lost treasure.  And that actual story is in depth and integral the character development of Spike Speigel. 
Spike, is the coolest character ever. His philosophy is so deep, and so moving. And the fight scenes are so beautifully animated. it is a high octane ride, that's for sure. And people of any IQ can enjoy this. 
This anime DOES NOT slack on production value. And, there is NO FILLER.

*Spoilers*
As a very casual anime watcher, this was one of the first series I watched besides the mainstream shounen animes. I was afraid to watch it because of how old it was, but the animation was amazing in my eyes. It gave me a retro, but smooth and crisp feel, the animation aged very finely over the decades. Now, the sound stepped up the anime, with simple vibes yet free-flowing and complimented each scene, which is what the anime was built around. And on to the characters. They seem simple at first, but are more complex as we learn more about the characters, especially Spike
                  Speigel. What really confuses me about him is that he wouldn't seem like the guy to be so thrown over by a girl, or by anything. I was still left with so much confusion about the characters like the backgrounds between Spike and Viscous. The anime provided enough information to fill in most of the rest, but I was still left with many questions after the anime ended. I really enjoyed this anime as the story is simple yet the characters are not, it uses amazing music to add to the already amazing scenes and clean art, this is why it deserves a 9. Now, remember, I'm not the most experienced watcher, but I loved Cowboy Bebop because of how simple it was.

The first thing that I need to say is that this anime is highly overrated
