The thing that apears in all episodes is the meaning of
                  letting go you past and live a new life and in all episodes are representes in a way or an other and for me sometimes was a little over used but in almost all episodes these idea was wery well adaptated and "cool".
ART : HUH the art in this anime is just simply perfect, hyper fluent animation in combats and spaceship battles it´s just beautiful and the episode that shows this the most is the episode 5 in the church, simply beautiful
SOUND : one of the most iconic soundtracks of all time, what can I say that it hasn´t telled already
CHARACTERS : I will talk about Spike cuase it´s difficult to talk about this anime without making spoilers
Spike : He is the typical lax, floopy or loose character that hides a super cool side, almost all people like this type of character and me I´m not gonna lie I love him too, althaugh he is one of these stereotipical characters, he highlights a lot, his evolution is realy an involution because after the conflict that made him leave the mafia he changed little by little but a part of him was still clinging to his past, thanks to his memories with vicious and Julia

This review contains a bit of spoilers there and there
I was young enough to watch this anime when it first came out in the late 90's but I never bothered to watch until 2022 because, as little as I knew, it never clicked with me, I never found it interesting despite I never really watched it, I just had that feeling.
Now in 2022 I know for sure that that feeling I had wasn't wrong, it was spot on; I genuinely have no idea how this anime is so highly scored, it's one of the most plain - boring anime I've ever seen, not super bad,
                  but so ungodly filled with edgy-ness and cliché it's almost unbearable at some points.
Why edgy? because most characters show the maturity or plainly act like teenagers, with only Jet acting vaguely like an adult - what I mean by that? simply put, they're always over-dramatic or over-theatrical, it's like they have a couple of traits each but those traits are so engrossed in each of their action they don't really feel like real people: Spike for example, the main character, is a typical introvert-cool-easy-going type, which is okay when that's a part of your character, what is not ok is when that is ALL of your character, seriously, aside from vaguely hinted tragic backstory filled with all the cliché you could stuff in (an unrequited love, a past you ran away from, a nihilistic yet tranquil behavior).
Even worse, almost no character is really explored despite the serie has 26 episodes plus a movie, ED, Jet and Faye have a backstory that's barely mentioned, yet at times it's treated like of an huge importance in the episode, yet not enough important to explore.
The story flow is a pure mess. The episodes are auto-conclusive and can be seen in pretty much any order, which wouldn't be a problem if this was some sort of slice of life, but instead it's an anime that pretends to have an overarching story which only matters in the last episode and that's it - it's like all the filler episodes (almost all) pretend to be part of a greater story yet they do act like fillers, with nothing of relevance really developed past their own enclosed mini story of a characters you have no time to grow to be attached to to the point you care about for whatever happen in the said episode, resulting in barely any interested from the viewer (me) as, as I just said, these 1-episode characters have zero appearances / mentions outside their own episode; this becomes clear pretty early in the anime so you end up realizing that no matter what happens, it's yet another one-time story with one-time character that is given too much weight for what is worth.
So while the anime wastes time developing 1-episode long characters, it neglects it's main cast to an astonishing degree, only dedicating one or two episodes to the main characters and leaving tiny bits spread among other episodes.
The sci-fi element is staggering bad as well, the anime is supposed to take place around 2070 yet it's clearly just the late 90's with spaceships... the writer clearly didn't even bother to try and image a future, he just took the 90's and added spaceships and THAT'S IT - I'm NOT faulting the writer for not imaging the future "Right", I'm faulting the writer for not even TRYING to come up with something, so lazy writing, I hate so much when writers use the sci-fi elements but don't really do anything they couldn't do in the current time with slight differences...
Another BIG problem with the anime is it's lack of a mood, it is a comedy? it is serious? it flip flops with moments clearly absurd moments yet it pretends the viewer to take it very seriously when it says so... 
Also, where the hell is the police? why capturing the criminals, down to small thugs, is the duty of random bounty hunters?
The most lame of all episodes is that one where a kid gains "Eternal youth" by staring at a space gate explosion... only problem is: 1) It's not simply "Eternal youth", the kid become literally immortal as it can take a bullet in the head and regenerate in seconds, and: 2)Why the hell, in all of of planet earth, he is the only one who got this effect?, not to mention, HOW exactly staring at an explosion or being exposed to some magic rays gives you super regeneration? the anime doesn't even try to explain, it simply happens and damn you if you try to question! you see, the writer wanted to use the genre "Sci-fi" but he was too lazy and non-creative to come up with ideas, so instead he used the genre "Fantasy" disguised as "Sci-fi", and that's because, when things happens with no reason, that's just fantasy, that's magic, that's no "Sci-fi" - I myself can come up with a teleporter device that can teleport you from one place to another and call it "Sci-fi" when I could to the same thing with a wizard casting a teleport spell on you and archive the same goal... in both cases, I would give 0 explanations so why would bother with the teleporter (Sci-fi) and instead going straight to the Wizard? (fantasy).
The movie is also lame, the antagonist is just some crazy person wanting to destroy the world by killing almost everyone with thin as air reasonings; It's pretty lame the fact that Spike gets shot in the chest in a scene yet he is 100% good as new the next day, while in Episode 26 Jet gets shot in the leg and it's pretty much down for the rest of the episode.
Oh yeah, and let's not forget about ED and just how random she is, at some point she meets a guy that's supposed to be her father but she cares more or less about 0 but then in the same episode ED decides to leave the gang, and the dog follow too, and... that's it, the anime is super anti-climatic when it should have had a bit of an emphasis... maybe? no? okay, whatever; ED's presence was thin as air anyway, she was basically the random super hacker of the show written by someone who clearly doesn't know what hacking looks like (Granted the anime was written in the late 90's but still...), and thinks it's like some sort of high-tech voodoo of some sort, really I've never seen a "Sci-fi" this bad.

People who have seen my previous reviews will most likely understand the style of Anime that I particularly enjoy.
Cowboy Bebop is not an Anime that I enjoy but this doesn't mean that its a bad Anime and in fact, I believe it to be an exceptionally crafted experience and a beautiful episodic piece of art.
Cowboy Bebop throws you into the deep end immediately and doesn't take much time explaining to you how things work in this world and it completely expects you to figure out how it works for yourself while providing an upfront (but not that obvious) paper trail for you to follow as
                  it slowly begins expanding and winding you in deeper with seemingly disconnected stories.
The animation at times can come across as a bit stilted and blocky but when the series decides to open up you'll find that there is also a lot of craft that has been put into it that can make you completely forget about other minor details that may appear throughout.
Dealing with themes of loneliness, the past, transhumanism and sorrow Cowboy Bebop tells a rather mature story through stylistic influences ranging from noir, old westerns and martial arts movies.
The soundtrack consists of beautifully blended yet diverse soundscapes with musical influences ranging from blues, jazz, funk and sometimes a hint of country.
I might not enjoy Cowboy Bebop and a large part of that may stem from the fact that I might not just 'get it' but I don't believe that I don't need to 'get' something in order to appreciate it for what it is.
I feel as though I'm missing out on appreciating this anime to its fullest but on the other hand I can confidently give this anime a 9/10 and say that if you're a fan of westerns, noirs, martial arts, cult classic films or any of the music genres I've mentioned before then you'll certainly find something in Cowboy Bebop that you can enjoy.
And on a final note, I just want to say that without Cowboy Bebop I might never have gotten into Jazz so for this I'm forever thankful.

It’s no surprise Cowboy Bebop is so popular in the west. It’s clearly heavily influenced by westerns and sci fi. From Blade runner to the good the bad and the ugly. At its best Cowboy Bebop is a fantastic show with fun characters and a gripping story. However there were too many instances when I thought to myself ‘why’?
Let’s start with the story, it’s wonderful. The show centres around Spike Spiegel, a former gang member turned bounty hunter. Who teams up with Jet, a former cop, Faye, a debt ridden gambler with amnesia and Ed a little girl with incredible hacking skills. While the story
                  does have a overarching plot it’s only prevalent in a few episodes. The rest are self contained story’s that make our characters grow. This sounds like a recipe for disaster, but for the most part it actually works. I say the most part because there are a few episodes which seem to exist to pad out the episode count. Which is baffling, (but I’ll get onto that later). 
The characters are all really likeable. Spike is fun, loving and has a tragic past. Jet is honest, has a heart of gold but can also make mistakes. At first I hated Faye due to her addiction with not just gambling, but cheating too. However once I found out why she does this, it changed my perspective completely. However once aspect that didn’t change was Ed. Seriously Ed is by far the worst character on this show. She adds absolutely nothing to the main plot. And that would have been fine if she developed, but she doesn’t. And what makes it frustrating is that they had the perfect opportunity. In episode 24 Ed meets her father who abandoned her at a young age. The two seem to bond for a bit and he even offers to take her along. Though he leaves before she has a chance. Ed then leaves the crew, implying she’s going out to find him. And she’s written out of the show! No end of an arc you yourself started! And with that whole killer leftovers and hallucinogenic mushrooms episodes could you not have time to finish Ed’s arc? 
Then we have the ending. Everyone says it’s a masterpiece, and I just don’t see it. The main problem is that the ending conflicts with the main theme of the show. It’s about facing and moving on from your past. Except when Spike does eventually move on, he’s retroactively punished for it. I don’t understand what happened, Faye’s arc was done so well, so why wasn’t spikes. 
Overall Cowboy Bebop was a fun ride that unfortunately fell at the last few hurdles.

Cowboy Bebop takes you on this awesome journey accompanied with a perfectly matched soundtrack. It has a retro vibe and uses the power of different types of genres to glue together an interesting story.
First of all, the music totally slaps. With a mix of jazz and blues it creates the perfect mood for each scene. Music is also import as it matches the pace at which events happen. It’s composed just like live music at a musical and that is what makes it so magical.
Sound design overall is just very pleasant. FX is very fitting for the devices used.
The last aspect about sound is that
                  the voice acting is superb. Each character just lives on your screen , partially due to the lively voice acting and fitting voices.
Each character has a load of personality. Each is very defined but also refined. Modern characters could be summed up in a few sentences, but the character from cowboy bebop their mannerism let them write books about themselves.
First off our protagonist Spike. A charismatic person, long slender and surprisingly strong. He’s a real marksman when it comes to shoot-offs and he’s a great pilot as well. We don’t know much of him but a few fragments from his past. So you can add an air of mystery to him as well. What makes him so likeable is that he unlike modern protagonist, Spike is actually doing is job as a cowboy, not being bother about doing the right or wrong thing.
Jet is also a lovable person. He almost looks like a toy monkey. Being the engineer of the ship we get to see him a little bit less in action. An interesting thing is that he sees Spike as a comrade but not as a necessity.
Lastly we have our fairy Faye Valentine. My personal favorite of the show. She’s a femme fatale, being also skilled at flying and shooting she helps Spike in getting bounties or into trouble. Her amnesia makes her yearn to know more about her past.
All these 3 characters are desperately trying to look forward but they are bound by their past. They have something to look back to or to regret and that is also what motivates certain story elements. When the end of the series is nearing everything sort of beautifully falls into place with each other.
Bonus mention Edward (aka Ed). She’s absolutely adorable. Her carefree attitude and her hacking skills are so funny to watch. She’s a real waifu 10/10 with such a great skin tone.
I could thoroughly enjoy this anime. The plot elements are amazing. Everything fits within that one episode but also connects to the bigger picture. It mixes a bit into action and slice of life. There were episodes which had a very light and joyful tone and others were very heavy. Cowboy Bebop mixes just the right amount of mood each time creating a perfect ambiance thorough the story without feeling out of place once.
For some scenes I was really feeling up or down, with the character. The anime succeed in making me emotionally invested in the events largely because of the right soundtrack.
The action was also plenty. It was really nice to see a skilled gunman without him being overly protected by plot armor. On top of that the flow of hand to hand combat was also really refreshing to see.
In summary, Cowboy Bebop brings a mix between action and slice of life accompanied with the perfect soundtrack. The 26 episodes together are one coherent story but every episode can also be seen as a standalone. The feeling of them just being free and roaming the galaxy is so liberating. If you like retro styled space cowboys then this your perfect fit!
Cowboy Bebop also reminds me of the style of Trigun and Gurren Lagann

" Dramatic, Chilling, and Bittersweet"
Probably one of the most unique and original animes I have seen in a while. It had a very interesting and amazing worldbuilding I mean who thought of doing a sci fi anime that takes place in the future in our solar system which has 2000s technology except for the spaceships and having a old school vibe/tone it. The consistency of this anime was alright, some episodes were just amazing and out of this world and others were a bit dull and were ok.
The visuals were good. The art was alright, it didn't have that sharp and crisp look to it,
                  everything seemed a bit unclear and undetailed. But the animation was amazing especially the fight scenes which was hype and the character designs which felt unique and original. The music was just everything! I shouldn't even be explaining. Jazz, country, mixed in with music from Japan it was just sweets for my ears.
The characters were good. Even though we didn't get to know about much about the character cast's past they really did an amazing job on writing characters that were original and felt fresh. They had interesting flaws and unique personalities. Majority of the screentime went to the main characters and there were barely any recurring characters.
Overall a enjoyable series. It had some flaws and some confusing parts but also a lot of hype and just crazy moments. It leaves some questions behind and makes the viewers answer it themselves which was sort of a double edged sword for me.

why I loved this show:
- OST and sound affects are top notch. Its soundtrack is really unique and one of the things that make CB stand out from the rest of the anime shows 
- Characters are original and interesting, therefore, character driven storytelling works really good
Faye is a very well written femme fatale 
Spike and Jet work well as a duo, and their different personalities makes a good match 
Ed is just goofy genius kid, but for me, it felts sincere and she made me smile lots of times
team of ed, faye, ed, spike and jet makes a dynamic team with each of them
                  being interesting enough on their own. Almost all of them are enigmatic, and it makes the viewers even more curious about them.
- We learn the background of all characters, and all of their stories are well written. The emotions of the characters are reflected to the audience masterfully. 
- Ending of the show is very conclusive and impressive
- This show's best quality is in its directing. Each scene is placed carefully, and piece by piece we learn more about the story. Some of the scenes are set really good, and stand out a lot (for example: church scene)
- animation is really good considered that this is a 90s anime
-although it is episodic, it's not boring and it manages to tell an overall story regardless. Many people criticize episodes in which we don't see Spike vs Vicious story, but I think they also serve well in terms of entertainment, giving a message on their own, and also showing characters where these conflicts don't exist (spoiler: they also fit well with concept of "fleeting dream" that Spike has).
- I liked that most of the episodes were named after songs
-This show is a very good example of "show, not tell." You can see this from just the dialogues. You never get someone explaining what's happening for 20 mins like lots of other show does. Instead events are shown through addition of details, and dialogues are used purposefully, rather than being used as a plot device. 
-almost every aspect of the show is well thought. You can tell that it is really done with lots of effort. If you watch carefully, you'll be surprised by how even the smallest details were considered. 
overall: 10/10. For me, the show deserves its vibe to the fullest. It really is a genre of its own. It's not so good if you are looking for an action rush and plot driven story. It's extremely good if you enjoy character-driven stories like I do.

I'm not sure why, but I've gotten into giving reviews lately so I felt the need to explain why I personally rate this anime a 10/10 and have it as one of my absolute favorites. 
I'm not like most of the die hard fans of Cowboy Bebop however. I didn't grow up watching it, or get into anime because of it (though I could have). I hadn't even heard of it until I was in high school and talked with a friend about anime. I remember watching the first episode and thinking "not bad, not bad. But I need to see more before I can
                  determine if I like it." By episode 5 I was hooked. 
The story might not be the greatest, but given the fact it is episodic, I'd say it's decent enough to be entertaining. The art style while dated, is still unique and interesting to me even now. But the true greatest part of this anime is it's soundtrack. Of course with Yoko Kanno as the composer the scores are going to be fantastic anyway, but still, it has to be mentioned that the soundtrack is amazing. As for the cast, well Jet, Spike, Faye, and Ed all remind me of real people, so I'd say they did a fantastic job of making them likable and personable.

!THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!
Cowboy Bebop is the first anime that I've watched from start to finish that didn't leave me with a, "OMG THAT WAS SO FCKUING GOOD SFETGSTIOERLF" feeling. It's not that I didn't like it, I mean obviously since I watched the entire thing, but the story left me a little...unsatisfied tbh. Idk betweenn Faye who was annoying as fuck (except in the last episode) and all this other shit that happened, I expected so much but was left with so little really. So yeah.

There are many shows or movies that have such a massive fan base and are held as undeniable classics of their genre. Many of which I disagree with. Titanic isn't very interesting to me, nor does beloved anime like My Hero Academia interest me very much either.
However, Cowboy Bebop is very much worthy of its status as a classic of the Anime medium.
Defining what makes this show such a classic is both easy and challenging. On the outset, it's a simple show; two Cowboys (or Bounty Hunters) fly around in the spaceship named 'Bebop' roam the galaxy looking for bounties to catch in hopes of
                  paying for their next meal. There's action, comedy and moments of drama thrown into the mix, shown against Jazz and Blues music. It seems simple.
But if you dive deeper, the show is more complex than that. 
Alongside most episodes that are self-contained in nature (described by the show's creator Shinichiro Watanabe as 'short films) are episodes that have an overarching theme running through them; the nature of one's past. Easy to ignore but hard to forget. The three main characters (Cool guy Spike Spiegel, Head of the Bebop and somewhat down to earth Jet Black and Faye Valentine, a girl with a strange and unsure past) all go through their own story arcs and development within themselves.
Let's look at the show more in depth and break it down:
Story: 10/10
Story is the interesting part of the show. For what we get, Cowboy Bebop's story is tightly written and layered in mystery. While the show is largely episodic in nature, we do get small segments of the overarching story woven through it. The main story is told through only 5 episodes; A stand-alone episode and 2 double part episodes. These were probably my favorite parts of the show. But that doesn't mean that the stand-alone episodes outside these 5 are lesser, as they are all entertaining to some degree. Whether it's an episode that's more light-hearted or one that tackles a meaningful theme, every episode of Cowboy Bebop is written extremely well. Every line of dialogue and every solution to their current episode's problem are tight and well worth it.
Art: 10/10
Cowboy Bebop is a beautiful show to look at. Taking inspirations from Film-noir, Sci-Fi and the Western genre, particularly American and European movies and shows from the past, Cowboy Bebop uses a lot of unconventional 'camera' angles that aren't used much in anime (especially modern anime), but are common in Film Noir flicks from the 40s. Harsh lighting with stark contrasts are seen in a lot of dark scenes with angles that highlight scale and importance to certain characters or events. 
The designs of the spacecraft and future technology have that old aesthetic from 80s films set in the future where everything looks like it's from the 80s (or 90s in this case) but simply have a small Sci-Fi twist on them. Character designs are distinct and memorable, the colors used are vibrant while managing to look bleak depending on the atmosphere and the intro is one of the most memorable looking intros to any Anime
Sound: 10/10
Jazz and blues are all over the show. From fight scenes, to chase scenes, to space battles, to moments when the characters are just lazing around with nothing to do. Every piece of music fits the scene like a glove. The jazz brings out the film-noir atmosphere, with heavy brass and piano sections sitting alongside the deep expanse of the galaxy, to Spike fighting hand to hand with opponents. The blues brings out the western influences, with slide steel guitar set upon beautiful shots of the baking hot sun on the deserts of Mars and Earth, or to bars where everyone smokes and drinks.
For dialogue, it's interesting to note that this is a show that is widely known for the strength of its English dub. While most shows have dubs that may be considered bad or on par with the Japanese audio, Cowboy Bebop's dub is considered far stronger than its Japanese audio. Every dub voice was picked flawlessly. Steve Blum as Spike is pitch perfect an every one of his lines avoids the typical dub problems of either being too over the top or rushing lines to fit all the words into the frames of dialogue. It feels almost as though the show was written for the dub in mind.
Character: 10/10
This is where the show succeeds the most. I loved every character in Cowboy Bebop. Spike is by far one of the coolest characters ever written. From his carefree attitude, his demeanor, his crooked cigarette and even his Bruce Lee influenced fighting style that is almost like a dance routine, Spike oozes coolness and suave. He's also a fairly sophisticated character, with multiple levels to his personality and with a backstory that explains his dislike for women (though it's in no way a sexist or misogynistic reason).
Jet Black is Spike's crewmate, though he is actually the Captain of their ship 'Bebop'. If Spike is the mysterious cowboy with a troubled past, Jet is the straight man. He tries on occasion to knock sense into Spike, though it mostly falls on deaf ears. He usually tries his best to trust people, though if they can't pay debts back, that trust only goes so far.
Faye Valentine is the lead female character. Her past is the most interesting off all, one that I don't wish to ever spoil for anyone. She dresses lightly in a way that could be considered objectifying, but she dresses this way to get what she wants. It's easy to have a main female character be the center of the two male character's affections as a love interest, but Cowboy Bebop never goes there. In fact, Jet and Spike usually can't stand her most of the time. Faye is allowed to stand on her own.
There're other characters in Cowboy Bebop too, but are best left to discovering yourself for the first time.
Enjoyment and Overall score: 10/10
Every minute of every episode in Cowboy Bebop is enjoyable, crafted beautifully by people who love what they do and understand how to make a multi layered show that seems to be simplistic at first look. 
A true masterpiece of Anime

Cowboy Bebop is arguably the most iconic and influential anime series ever made. Its influence can be seen in western media everywhere, from the movies of Quentin Tarantino to the lyrics of a modern rap song, i would say it is the most american anime ever made, being inspired by american Jazz music as well as western movies from the 60´s.
Altough Bebop´s influence is gigantic, i´ve always struggled with the actual story being told, but honestly, at the end of the day, that doesnt really matter. The episodic nature of the series unfortunatelly ruins what could be a potentially great story if the creators decided
                  to make a straight foward narrative rather than put random episodes that dont mean anything in the middle of 2 great episodes that actually develops and progress what is being told, still, even though the story is its weakest point, the greatness of everything else makes me not care about the wasted potential that the Spike vs Vicious storyline could have been. That being said, i absolutely adore the way the last 2 episodes wrap up the narrative, even though the journey of getting to those last 2 episodes were good, but not great.
the art and aesthetic of bebop is probably my favorite in all anime. It has a melancholic  and atmospheric vibe to it, specially spike´s flashbacks. I love the contrast between western clothing, weapons and cheap cigarrette smoke with the futuristic and cyberpunk landscapes and technology, it makes for a very unique journey through the depths of a world that almost feel alive, as if the places they go to are actual characters rather than just set pieces
so lets talk about them, the characters. I love every single one of the main five characters, they have some of the best chemistry i´ve ever seen, and slowly seeing them going from a bunch of depressed outlaws to an actual family that cares about each other is great. It is one of those shows where you really get immersed with them, feeling as if you are there rather than being just a passive outsider. Spike, although we dont get to see a lot of what makes him the man he is, we see enough to make us care and connect with him. He is a broken man haunted by his past, never going foward, just trapped in this infinite cycle of trying to relive the good old days where things were happy, and that can be said about all the characters, they are all people with nothing to live for, they just exist, they dont have any goal in mind, just everyday drowning in their on melancholy and desperately trying to let go of their dark past, but  never actually succeding at it, except for spike, who, poetically enough, only moves on after his death, the only way of him to be happy and forgive himself is to end his life in a final battle with his old friend turned enemy, also killing him in the process, and that my friends, is the main message of the anime.
Dont be like Spike, Jet and Faye, dont let the shit that happened in your past be the reason why you cant move foward, as the final scene of the show says, "you are gonna carry that weight", because carrying that weight and dealing with your past mistakes face to face is the only way of achieving happiness and let go of suffering.
in the end, i unfortunatelly cant give this a 10, because there are at least 7 very unninteresting episodes that have no reason to exist and mess with the pacing that could have been great, it for sure would be a 10 if it had lets say 18 episodes rather than 26. But anyways, Cowboy Bebop is fun, tragic and poetic, and definitelly one of the most fun i had with an anime.
9/10

This anime is just, wow. the characters are entertaining,the plot is good but sometimes I cannot keep track of it. The jazz is one of the best I've heard from anime, probably the best part for me. I mean, its impossible to hate this anime. I watched the dub version on Toonami long ago and enjoyed it so much. Wish it had more hand-to-hand combat though since those scenes are my favorite. It took me quite a while to remember this until Netflix announced their adaptation of this and I thought "wow i hate netflix" but still wonder how they would approach this anime.

Finally, I had some time to write my first review this anime sure deserves much more.
This was really a great ride 26 episodes of enjoyment this series was really outstanding it had a lot of influence on me I really enjoyed it starting by:

Art: The art was really special and unique not like these days anime which one eye is bigger than the other, to be honest, it was 85% like a Ghibli movie really outstanding, and it had a mix
                  of the western cartoon on it I really like that of course in a Japanese anime style. 10/10
Sound: I really loved the voice actors they were really awesome and I thank them for their great work on this show, the sound effects were great for 1998 anime it was really outstanding. 10/10
Character: I think this show was mostly successful because of the uniqueness of these four main characters as well as the others, each one had their own attitude and they didn't change it for some any reason except major things 10/10
Enjoyment: it was really enjoyable, but I would have loved it more if there was more dark and hopeless and despair in it 8/10
Overall: it was a very Great show that I would definitely watch it again in the future. 9/10

                  has issues she needs to work through. What is up with that outfit she wears? Super-sexy, but I can't imagine she could stay warm in that.

A boy I liked said one day: "Have you heard 'Tank'? You have to hear 'Tank'."  He sent me the album version, and insisted any series with music this good has to be worth a watch.
Most of the episodes are self contained, and oddly enough, it works.  It is actually easier to get hooked because even though there's a good overarching story with many small details, they're scattered throughout the series and you don't get bogged down with plot point overload.  The characters are consistent and realistic, and gradual changes happen along those oneshot stories.
At the end of it all, the phenomenal
                  music is the shining star of this series.  Episode Five, "Ballad of Fallen Angels," is one of the best scored episodes of TV.  Period.  Yoko Kanno is a genius; she incorporates such a wide variety of music, and still manages to tie it together.

This show is absolutely brilliant. Allow me to elaborate on why.
When you first get in to watching this show it has a calm, nostalgic atmosphere.
like watching cartoons as a kid. It would remind me of the old days sitting at home, playing DVD after DVD, wondering if Batman would stop The Joker, what kind of antics Buggs and the loony toons would get up to or thinking to myself 
"Is it truly possible for Ash to catch em' all". Mix that feeling with beautiful scenes, the greatest sound track I've ever heard, the most delved in to 
characters there are and some excitement, space adventure
                  and slightly more adult themes, and you have Cowboy Bebop. The story is beautiful, complex and special to me. The art reminds me of a simpler time in anime. The soundtrack to this show is spectacular, it's as though they looked at each scene and immediately knew the perfect music for it. Not to mention the fight scenes perfect choreography, the flow of each hand to hand fight that Spike has, just takes my breath away. Truly a work of art, and 100% worth the watch.

Cowboy Bebop is the most essential anime out there.  It is an example of everything good, of everything an anime can be.  From the stellar voice acting, to the catch tunes, to the imaginative set pieces, to the tight and flawless writing.  Even if this is an anime you dont think you will like it is something you should probably watch anyway in much the same way every film buff will say to watch Citizen Cain even if they dont like it.  Cowboy Bebop is the Citizen Cain of anime.
If you call yourself an anime fan, and you haven't seen this
                  show by now: watch it.  Seriously.

Its just some people that like this anime and it is those who like philosophy of the anime. The anime is about the tragic story of every character. The music and the artwork has a lofi feeling whitch is nice. So if you have time on the night you should watch it. But when you start watching it can be boring in the start but its get bether. So if like philosophy and filososfi you should go watch it. And if you like neon genesis you will like it but its not the same but in some ways. Add me if you want to talk
                  about the anime=)

Finding the words to describe Cowboy Bebop proved to be more difficult than I imagined. The series is a true masterpiece of animation and one of few that genuinely deserves a 10 rating across the board.
Of all the elements in the show, the one worthy of special mention is the music score, composed by Yoko Kanno. It is undoubtedly some of the most atmospheric music of any series and one the show is best known for.
The plot is nonlinear. While each character has an underlying agenda, it is their environment that ultimately decides where life takes them. Scripting for the show is exceptional; episodes are
                  nicely varied and the dialogue is very well-written and spoken from the mains to the supporting.
Besides the music, the next most recognizable aspect of the series is the characters. Each and every one of them has a meticulous design and personality, backed with outstanding art, fluid animation and excellent voice acting. All of this, combined with the aforementioned material, comes together in the form of realistically fleshed out and convincing figures.
Cowboy Bebop, in every regard, is a show of excellence. It more than backs its legacy and name among anime with painstaking visuals, beautiful music and believable characters. A must watch.

Cowboy Bebop is an unforgettable ride. This show is a masterclass in subtle storytelling, character building, and undeniable style. The way the universe feels so lived in and understandable without ever having to ham-fist explanations as to how things like atmosphere-regulation works is something very few works are able to accomplish this stunningly. Yes, the action is great, yes it's humorous and clever, but it's episodes like "Speak Like A Child" that really shine through, providing profound emotional depth for characters who aren't always willing to show their insides like they're being watched. The PEOPLE on this show are complex and utterly real to an
                  extent no other show I have ever watched has been able to reach. This show is perfect.

Oh boy another bebop review h a h a
Gonna make it simple because this show is talked about to death but I'll say that I get the hype. I get why people love it so much. This show has a few layers beneath it that I really dig but I do think it's important to talk about bebop the right away before introducing it to someone. 
If you dig neo noir cool and the anime aesthetic then you'll pretty much dig this right away and will have no problem being hooked for all 26 episodes. But if you're like me and need something a bit
                  more to commit to that length, well let me just say that I don't think the show gets really good until the final 3rd of the series. 
Up until that point, the show leans more into its episodic format with slight glimpses of its characters' cores with a change happening after the mid-series' 2 parter. I believe after episode 13, the show gets more interesting and eventually more wacky, which by that point we're given genuine reason to care about these people vs just their overall cool factor. 
If we see this series as 2 seasons, then I'd argue that eps. 1-13 are about a 7/10 because it's very much more aesthetic vs substance (and a damn cool aesthetic to boot). But the writing in season 2 gets very involved with this cast and in some ways, the more tender moments take center stage, rendering it a 8-9/10. Unfortunately that's not the case as it was possibly conceived as 1 large season but maybe that's more of a me issue idk. 
In the end, Bebop is a good show. Your mileage will depend on your taste but if episode 1 doesn't grab you then I'd suggest checking out episodes 15 (a faye valentine character study), 20 (an acid trip horror theme chase), 22 (a goofy deconstruction of spike's character), and 23 (a simple premise with heavy cyberpunk themes). It's not spoilers because it's still episodic by this point and you can actually see how far they take these characters, maybe get hooked, all while also having a good time in the process.

I think the beauty of this show is the fact that it follows a (mostly) normal group of bounty hunters. There is a sort of charm of having a protagonist that is not super powerful or special, but rather that its their more realistic problems and how they are dealing with life is. Im very glad I watched this show without much knowledge, because I got to enjoy it for what it was and not have certain parts spoiled or hyped. 
They did a good job of sprinkling in episodes and bits that further explained the backstories of the characters, and by having it sort
                  of build up inbetween episodes of somewhat "nothingness" really drove home the point that sometimes, life is messy, and just like how most of our issues dont jump out at us, we start to see our group of space cowboys, cowgirls and cowdogs, are all dealing with their own personal problems constantly without us knowing. 
This show reminded be a lot of my old friend, that at first glance it can seem "mundane" or even boring at parts, but the more you look the more you start to notice, and that my friends is what really sold this show to me. Like many others, its a real gem, but its important to understand that it will take things slow at times, and sometimes, thats okay.

This anime was well done and actually very interesting in many ways. The development of the characters was done very well and the introduction of the problems. The setting, which is in the future, is one of my favorite settings in any anime because of its alomst realistic and possible content. I enjoyed this anime very much for the violence as well. The amount of violence is actual perfect in theis anime.

I have never seen a great complete anime before this one. I started watching this anime on Cartoon Network's Adult Swim. But I always missed crucial episodes. So I finally sat down at my computer to watch most of the series and I must say I was very impressed, everything from the beginning to the end was well done, the artwork, the music, the story. I loved this anime to death dispite the fact that there was a lot of violence on this anime. The characters though are so remember-able each had growth of personality in the series. I mean the only thing that I
                  didn't like about this series is the cliffhanger at the end of the last episode left you wondering what happened. Besides that great all the way through. There is a reason why I think Cowboy Bebop is the if not the best Anime of all time.

"I’m not going there to die; I’m going to find out if I’m really alive." -Spike Spiegel
Cowboy Bebop is a philosophical journey exploring the identity of human soul and the meaning of life through three main characters with haunting pasts (plus Ed and Ein). The crew journeys throughout the universe as bounty hunters, learning on the way the sense of camaraderie and sense of self-identity. And through thrilling Western fighting scenes and episodic stories of various individuals, Cowboy Bebop extends to the idea of death and existentialism.
So is Cowboy Bebop a Classic? Definitely.
Story: 8/10
The concept the Cowboy Bebop explores is, as I explained earlier, beyond
                  the surface. As one learn more about the characters' past, the more one delves into their shoes. And with an episodic format, Cowboy Bebop is a perfect anime in which you can drop and pick up late without losing important elements of the story. And any western movie fans would just love the action inside this series
But why isn't this a masterpiece in this department? The concept of reality and fiction is, I'd say, way to much mingled.
It just feels awkward that in the age of space travels, all the protagonists use pistols rather than futuristic weapons or just even any other assault weapons. What's even more absurd is the fact that the main characters leave without much injury even against hundreds of machine guns without any protective gear. The villains are always a terrible shot for some reason, and the protagonists are way to good of a shot. And some action inside space just breaks the laws of physics alongside casual logic. I know that Cowboy Bebop is more symbolical of a story than a realistic one, but the boundary of fantasy and reality needs to be clear.
TL DR; Nice symbolical concepts. But blurred line of reality and fantasy.
Art: 8/10
This was made before 2000. Amazing art for the time.
Sound: 9.5/10
Nice jazzy soundtracks that fit with the melancholy mood of the series. It even has an iconic opening theme that will almost never be forgotten by those who watch this series. Background music and sound effects are placed on right times. 
Character: 9/10
The characters seem simple yet complicated. The interactions between the pure (Ed and Ein) and the impure (Spike, Jet, Faye) is just perfect for the exploration of the human soul. The characters are one-dimensional and complex at the same time, making them feel just so human. 
They feel like people we can relate to rather than a character trapped in a different dimension.
Enjoyment:9/10
The action packed western style action anime was a good refreshment for me. But this show may not be the best for binge-watching as these are episodic. But the story adds up, so don't skip episodes. Just slowly watch this anime from time to time.
Overall: 9/10
Just an anime series any devoted anime fan should watch. The word "classic" perfectly fits this anime.

My favorite thing about Cowboy Bebop is how motley of a crew they all are and the interaction between characters. The action is ok but nothing special. But character development is where this anime really excels. They pretty much go into everyone's backstory well enough to give you a good idea of what makes them tick. 
Can move along a bit slow at times but for the most part has a good mixture of comedy, action; seriousness and sillyness.

(Tungu's spoilerfree mini-reviewcommendation)
It is kinda episodic, but small plot-crumbles are hinted here and there, then at certain points it just blasts you with it.
Setting/worldbuilding is very nice, plays an organic part in the story.
But what really made the show are the characters and their dinamic, combined with the great writing, each of the main trio/squad are memorable.
Animation is outstanding, especially for a 1998 production, sadly is 4:3.
Very clever writing, as it will grab you by the balls from episode one, and just occasionally let go for the more lighthearthed moments.
The internet seems to hype it up, and for a valid reason, amazing show overall.
I give
                  it a 9/10, would strongly reccommend.

Masterful written plots on an episodic format that culminates into a beautiful bitter sweet ending anyone could ask for! The Philosophical themes and the variety of genre's crammed into it's 26 episodes are very engaging and are still relevant even today. I just loved the main characters as they wonder around aimlessly and without purpose on a seemingly living breathing world of Cowboy Bebop looking for there missing catharsis while observing the side characters going through there own hardships and raison dêtre.
Shinichiro Watanabe Thank you this anime is the Gold standard for writers and probably animators to strive to or even surpass

It's Cowboy Bebop. I am not a skilled enough writer or analyst that I can tell you something new about one of the most famously influential and excellent anime of all time. Everything that can be said about it? It's been said. It's good. If you haven't watched it, you should. If you have watched it, you probably don't need any more reassurance. 
It's in the debate for one of the greatest anime of all time. And it deserves to be there. I must struggle to find a flaw in this thing, and what I do find is very small. Chances are, if you don't
                  like cowboy bebop, it's because one element of the format just wasn't for you. And that's okay. If you hate sushi, the most expertly crafted roll will not win you over. If you detest the texture of fine steak you'll scoff at the most succulent cuts of beef. But hopefully you can appreciate it for what it is--masterful.

To begin, I will say that I rarely watch anime anymore, and when I do nowadays it's usually older ones that weren't/aren't mainstream. I left all of that shonen stuff back in middle-early high school where it belongs (I'm already nearing 30). I try to watch more nowadays, it's just there is rarely any anime that pulls me in, but I digress.
Review: 
Great music, great setting, great art, great characters, meh overarching plot. In the end it was little above average. When it was good it was REALLY good. When it wasn't it dragged on forever and I couldn't wait to get to the next
                  episode already. 
I didn't really have any expectations going in other than forums recommending it. But it started to wane around halfway through the series. I understand that the anime is episodic (I've greatly enjoyed other episodic animes like Baccano! and Samurai Champloo), but a number of episodes around the middle of the series clearly stood out to me as not as enjoyable to watch. 
Story-wise, what CB ends up being for me is simply a story of existing. "Simply" being the keyword here because I feel like that is the reason why the show didn't wow me, yet however, it was uniquely bland. Everything simply existed; happened. I think that's part of the beauty of it; it wasn't anything special. No mind-blowing philosophical themes are shoved in your face a la Psycho Pass. No big revelations or thrills. Life in the universe of CB simply is what it is, and like the ending, it just goes on. Implicitly, there is a lot to say there that takes a little finesse to figure out.
I will say that CB is a damn good gem. I haven't seen anything like it. But it didn't blow me away. It was subtle. I don't think I would want to rewatch it anytime soon. Maybe when I'm a lot older again and life has taken its course.

I started my journey into anime when I was 15, after watching the original run of Neon Genesis Evangelion on some random website that probably gave my old laptop a million viruses (I promise you I am going somewhere with this, stay with me).  From there I was hooked, unfortunately it would still be a long time until streaming services had more than just Naruto available and the heyday of Toonami was over. I had no other friends who watched anime and it was overwhelming to shift through what was available to watch by myself, lost I turned to YouTube anime recommendation videos. By
                  and large Cowboy Bebop was almost always at the top of the recommendation list, so I thought screw it, I'll give it a go.
And I started it, in 2016. I finished it in 2021, five years later. Initially, I wasn't hooked I watched a few episodes and thought it was pretty good but I didn't really get it and so my mind got occupied with other anime and other aspects of life. Over the remaining span of my teenage years I would watch another episode here or there, not really feeling any urgency to find out what happened next or continue on with the story because of it's episodic nature I could jump in and leave as I pleased without feeling lost. I was neither compelled or dissuaded from the story until I started binge watching TV (and subsequently anime) in the wake of 2020. Blah blah blah, we all know it's been hard and lock-down sucks I will spare the "unprecedented times" spiel. But I found myself returning to Cowboy Bebop to really give it a real try, by this point it had taken me four years to get about 7 episodes deep. You may be thinking, why would I try so hard for a show I clearly wasn't interested in? Here's the thing, I was interested. The animation and stylized characters are beautifully designed and fascinating to get to know. There is so much love and passion put in every frame it's palpable. And the music!! Oh god the music, the score is spectacular, Yoko Kanno and the Seatbelts are genius! I never gravitated towards jazz but this score had me hook, line and sinker. 
I just didn't get it. I didn't get why I was supposed to care, I didn't understand. Maybe I started the series too young and my own personal maturity wasn't high enough to read deeper and not have the meaning spoon fed to you. This is what I ended up liking the most about Cowboy Bebop, it really is what you make it. There is meaning where you decide to hold meaning, it's about the past and the future and our own relationships and how life can be such a heavy burden. But it can also just be a Sci-Fi space Cowboy show. I think revisiting this show while I was about to wrap up college felt so much more poignant because I could understand the feeling of being pulled forward into adulthood but still being swept up by the past and my last few moments in college with little responsibilities and so many friends. And even then, I still left the series for a bit and have just now returned to it to watch the last four episodes this week finishing the series last night. Regardless of how long it took me to watch in the end I was so profoundly moved by this series I almost regret taking so long to watch the series. Almost.
I couldn't tell you why it took me so long to finish the series, maybe because I hate goodbyes and throughout the entire run there is a nagging feeling of loss and goodbyes are ever present, even from the first episode and the famous tagline of "see you space cowboy". Maybe that why. Maybe it's because I was too young and "didn't get it" or maybe it's because I wasn't enthralled enough to care. But this show has wormed it's way into my brain and I've been carrying it around with me in the back of my mind for years. So if you have made it to the end of this long winded review, give it a try. Who knows how you might feel. I do think it is worth the time, no matter how long that time may be, to sit and enjoy the ride. If it takes you a few days or even a few years, you'll be in good company.

I'm not particularly good at writing reviews but I felt like I needed to for this show. I am also new to the anime community so my experience with the genre is very limited but this was honestly one of my favorite shows of all time, let alone favorite anime. 
The artwork is something that caught my attention from the beginning and is what kept me intrigued throughout the entirety of the show. 90s animation style makes me feel some type of way. From the fight scenes to the facial expressions when the characters talk to each other and everything in-between, the artwork was outstanding.
                  It was amazing to see how much they were able to create and how well it was created considering the time period.
Moving to the sound, I think the "3...2...1 Let's Jam!" is one of the most iconic lines in a soundtrack ever. Further, the creators somehow made Western music work for a show about space bounty hunters... never did it seem out of place!
Next, the four main characters... all incredible. Spike is everything you want in a badass main character and partnering with his rational sidekick (if you will) Jet, the duo is out of this world (literally). The addition of Faye added a nice balance for Spike's personality, hence why they fought a lot. The fighting was definitely not forced nor did it take anything away from the characters, it actually added a lot when you find out why both of their personalities are extremely combative. Finally, you could always count on Ed and Ein for a good laugh. At first Ed kind of annoyed me, but I was pleasantly surprised with her character development and the show wouldn't have been the same without her.
I left the story for last because I am stuck between wishing that there was more than 26 episodes to flesh out the story better or being content because the creators revealed as much of the story as they needed to. Throughout the show, I felt as if they could have fleshed out a few of the side stories and other main plot points a bit better, but the culmination of the show still made sense and felt complete even without them. I could be wishing for this because I never wanted the show to end, but that is the reason why I am not giving the story a 10, like the rest of the ratings. 
Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone who watches and loves anime and I would even go as far as recommending it to anyone who has never seen anime in his life, that is how good this was.

Please take my review with a grain of salt as it took me about a month to watch the whole thing.
~
Yet another show to cross off my list of "cult classic" animes. As expected of a show that shares the same director as Samurai Champloo, the pace and flow of the anime was fluid in its nonchalant transition between each episode and distinguished during. The overall story didn't matter as much as each individual event and this is where some of the artistry lies in this type of storytelling. It allows the viewer to be active in the moment and not anticipating the future or
                  dwelling on what happened in the past. In fact, every event seemed very real in its impromptu and freestyle...style (of course, just like jazz..). Nothing goes according to plan. Nothing happens to develop the story further on. Nothing is orchestrated for this ultimate grand scheme. Everything just happens.
--THIS SECTION ON CHARACTERS BECAME WAY LONGER THAN EXPECTED, SKIP IF YOU ALREADY DECIDED TO COMMIT THE TIME TO READING THIS--
The characters were all exciting. Relatable by their individual sins and mannerisms. Jet who reluctantly (yet willingly) supports his partners when he could be saved the headache by ditching them. Spike who personifies the Bruce Lee mantra of "Be like water". Faye who similarly throws caution to the wind and loses it all in gambling. And Ed who, after acknowledging her technological gift, could not be described more accurately than as the epitome of any lackadaisical child ever born. 
It begs the question of why a character should be stagnant on the spectrum they reside in. Should protagonists always be likable? Should antagonists always be detested? It is not easy to make a character who fluctuates in personality in a way that doesn't seem targeted or intentional. So we commonly see in a lot of modern day writing (not necessarily a majority, mind you) that good guys are good and bad guys are bad. 
I constantly became frustrated with each characters despite my previous acceptance of their flaws. But I could say the same of my closest friends and I'm sure they could say worse of me. At the end of the day, no matter their mistakes, mischief, or misconduct, characters should be as complex as the people we love and hate.
--END UNINTENTIONAL LECTURE--
The music was very good. I, for one, have a hard time sustaining a long term imprint from musical scores so forgive me if I can't provide a more structured opinion on it. I can at least tell you that I enjoyed it very well and all of it, of course, was in good taste.
The art and animation were incredible. Specific background arrangements and positioning were important. Beautiful landscape shots. Dynamic choreography and animation from hand to hand and gun fights. (Sounds pretty copypasta from my Champloo review?) Everything seemed painstakingly thoughtout and not for a moment did they consider half assing a single frame. Well.. except for the time they used a 3D model, but hey, maybe it seemed really damn cool in 1998.
All in all, I am simply another brick in the wall supporting this house of Bebop.

Cowboy Bebop is a true classic. The perfect story, characters and sound from 1998 imagining the future of late 2000 century. This is one anime that everyone should take time to watch and enjoy.
Let's start with story. It was truly unique and felt pure. For many 2020s animes they kinda don't have the purity or realism that Cowboy Bebop or other older classic have with their stories. Simply it is story about cowboys (bounty hunters) hunting criminals in futuristic space world. And I don't care much for space stuff, I kinda get bored by it.  But this anime has the most coolest and interesting
                  story. I wanted to know every characters and every detail. I was nervously waiting every episode what would happen because it was so interesting. 
For the artstyle I would say it is very 90s anime style. But I just love how the characters look, move and do such a small things. It feels very detailed and good quality. And the space backgrounds and different worlds were so amazing. 
The music in Cowboy Bebop was really good, so many good songs. Many of them were English but it didn't sound weird because the characters were inspired by 1800 bounty hunters and 1950s gangsters. I liked Fayes design even though boobs didn't make sense, but the design was too cool.
The characters were so good. They all had backstories, character development and personalities. Every character was unique in their way and you will find something that you like in every single one of them. (mines was Spike and Faye).
I fully enjoyed this series. I just can't handle that I finally watched this, I want to watch it again. It gives me so much serotonin! I recommend to everyone watch this anime, this is a true classic!
few opinions:
There are few character designs that may annoy some people (lgbt). Because there a few times possible transwomen in Cowboy Bebop. And they are shown having male characteristics and beards, because they are "men". And for someone like those amab characters the man must be gay. :/
But at least there was genderfluid representation with one character (in same episode.)

I am not export nor know anything professionally about Anime. I don't care about how good the plot is, how amazing the music is, and how fine the animation is made. The thing that Cowboy Bebop gives to me is emotional resonance. 
I feel what characters feel. I remember many scenes from it as part of my memories. They have never faded away even after 20 years. On the opposite, memories and feelings of Cowboy Bebop get more and more profound as I get older. 
I have heard some people say that Cowboy Bebop is overrated. It is never the case to me since there
                  is no other anime that could make me think of them in daily life. No other anime could let me feel deeply about myself, humanity, and the universe. Cowboy Bebop likes a mirror or a vibe of my emotions.

Writing a review because I did not expect this anime to have much of an impact on me, yet here I am, carrying the weight of it.
I think the charm of the series is that it creeps up and sticks with you without you even realizing it. The first few episodes were fun enough -- the art and the music never disappointed, and while I was slightly surprised at first, I had been lulled into being content with what seemed to be a solid episodic space western. At that point, I thought that the anime would stay just like that -- the normal recipe of
                  slightly quirky characters, quests/problems wrapped up in an episode, and the occasional deep insight. 
It was only in the latter half of the series that I realized how attached I've become to the Bebop crew, and how effective the past episodes were at building up their stories and characters so naturally that I didn't even realize that certain things were plotpoints. What makes Cowboy Bebop different from a lot of animes is that it's subtle about its story -- instead of shoving it in your face, it makes you learn about it through bits and pieces from each episode, so that by the end, you have an idea of what everything implies. No wonder people watch and rewatch this show (I'm certainly considering it).
Also, amazing art and music to the very end. I can never stress this enough.

When I was getting back into anime it was hard to know where to start, so I figured I'd go with the classics. I cued up Cowboy Bebop along with a few others and finally got to watch the show that so many consider to be an unrivaled masterpiece... and I just don't get it.
My theory is basically this. The only reason this show is so popular has nothing to do with it's content, and everything to do with the availability of anime in the west. Back in the day there wasn't any such thing as streaming, you wanted a show you either waited for
                  some American company to dub it or you learned Japanese and bought from the source. Even pirating subbed anime was difficult considering it was a time of dial-up speed internet and there were very few groups ripping the VHS tapes to make fan subs. Official subs didn't really become a thing until streaming services came around and Japan finally realized there was an audience in the west that they could market to.
Anyway, all this to say  that if you were a weeb in the 90's there weren't a lot of shows around to even watch. I don't even know how you'd go about becoming a weeb in the first place in such a landscape. It was probably mostly the internet imageboards, the places where the term weeb originated, that had people who cared anything about anime. So it is that Cowboy Bebop is held up in high regard by these people as being some great masterpiece when in reality it was just the best they could get their hands on.
Now I'm not going to be disingenuous and say I hated the show just to be contrary. I didn't hate it. I just don't understand it. It was a decent sci-fi story with solid animation and a crew of interesting characters. It's a good show, but I have none of the rose tinted feelings for it that someone who got into anime by watching this show might have. So I'm giving it an 8 out of 10 space cowboys.

"Cowboy Bebop" inspired me to write my first review, and it should already mean a lot! 
This anime is really something special (No sarcasm!). It took me 3 times to start watching. You should really be in a specific mood to enjoy it. The first episode seemed a little messy and overwhelming, but it all started to make sense as the story moved on. 
"Cowboy Bebob" is definitely a work of Art. You don`t even need to like all the space setting to realize that this anime was made by very talented and inspired people, who really put their heart and soul into it. Some
                  scenes are so aesthetically pleasing, you will want to rewatch them over and over again, they are just perfect. 
And music of course! Who would have thought that jazz will go so well with all "bounty hunters in space" topic. But it does! There are some great music themes and songs in anime, but in "Cowboy Bebob" music plays a very special role. I can even say it is as much a character as any of the Bebob crew. And the famous opening, of course. It`s definitely a "never skip" one.
Fight scenes and space battles are beautifully made. I was watching all of them with bated breath (and rewatching them several times).
What I personally didn`t like very much were the episodes about the heroes` past. I don`t expect the characters not to have a past, of course, but to my taste they were a bit over dramatic, in a "film noir" style (which was definitely the authors` idea, since they were playing with different genres of American films). It`s just that I personally like the comedy and adventure episodes more.
So, all in all, Cowboy Bebob is no doubt a remarkable series, which is worth watching!

ok so cowboy bebop is incredible and i truly believe it's the greatest anime of all time.
it's a bittersweet story about the ways that each character's past affects them and the ways that they choose to handle it, whether it's to run away from it, ignore it, or to desperately try to run back to it.
most of the show is what i suppose you could call filler episodes, but i'd argue that they're just as important as the episodes that contribute to the actual plot. every episode contributes to each character's development in one way or another and helps you grow to love the show's
                  main characters. the episodic nature of the show makes it easy to take your time with the show and take it one episode at a time and each stand alone episode leaves you waiting for the next time the main plot comes back in and there's always a sudden feeling of dread when you see "(part __)" next to an episode title because you just know it's going to get depressing.
the show itself has beautiful art that makes you feel nostalgic even if you've never watched older anime. it has beautiful backgrounds and really cool character designs.
the soundtrack to this show is absolutely flawless paired with an iconic opening. it really is one of the best soundtracks i've heard. also it has an incredible dub cast to the point that even thinking of watching it in japanese feels like a waste.
every single main character in this show is likeable and complex. spike is likely in my top 3 characters of all time. the female characters in the show are both well written, which is unfortunately a rarity. the characters in cowboy bebop are also essentially quote machines, constantly pumping out iconic quotes and sayings that just seem to stick with you.
as i'm writing this i'm rewatching the show and i'm up to a specific part toward the end where spike and jet are eating eggs (which had been cooked for 4) alone, that's pretty much it, though it sounds like a dumb scene there's a fuck-ton of emotion behind it which i think perfectly displays cowboy bebop's impeccable ability to show rather than tell.
ontop of all of that cowboy bebop has a flawless ending that perfectly ties up loose ends whilst still making you feel empty inside for the next couple weeks or so.
the overall rating of 10/10 really isn't shocking after i begun the review calling it the best anime of all time, but it really is, and if by now you still haven't watched by now it you're seriously missing out.

Okay so I feel obliged to write up a review on my favorite animated space western of all time, Cowboy Bebop. I am not alone in that this show is widely acclaimed by many others as well. The moment I watched Bebop, I expected so much from anything I've watched since and not a lot can live up to Bebop, if any.
Story: 10
So basically you have your main character Spike and his bounty hunting partner Jet Black patrolling the galaxy on their ship, the Cowboy Bebop. Along the way they pick up Faye, a woman with hardly any recollection of her past, Ein the smart
                  Welsh Corgi, and Ed, computer whiz. The plot of the story is different from many other fictional works; Bebop's plot isn't a core component of the show. It's all about how all of the characters develop over time. I'll talk about the characters in a little bit.
Art: 9
Still a somewhat older anime (19 years old sheesh!) but the art holds up from its debut. Still feels lively and more aesthetically pleasing than its counterparts over those couple of years but would be criticized if it were created today.
Sound: 10
I would rate it a 20 if I could. One of the best dubs ever? Check. A fucking amazing OST? Check. All time classing opening? You can honestly just label this as one of the best musically crafted shows not only in anime but in movies and TV as a whole. Any music fan questioning whether they want to watch anime for the first time must start with this show.
Characters: 10
The main characters are all different and each have an in depth backstory carefully woven into the series. The main villain, Vicious is only in there for like 3 episodes and he still feels like a really important character in the series. If you believe in a silhouette test, this show literally has it in the opening and it definitely passes with flying colors.
Enjoyment: 10
If I weren't pressed for time when I started watching it, I would have watched it in one go. 8-9 hours straight of Bebop is just amazing in my head.
Recommendation: 
Watch the show. If you're a hater wanting to find a bad review, watch the show. New to anime? Watch this. You've already watched Bebop and want to find other like-minded individuals? Watch it again. Also, listen to the whole OST on YouTube, shit is amazing to listen to during any circumstance.

Cowboy Bebop is a perfect anime in every way, Spike Spiegel is a memorable protagonist, as are his companions too.  An incredible animation for the time, a wonderful story, in which the viewer can watch almost all the episodes in the order they want, and the soundtrack is perfect.
Seeing Cowboy Bebop chronologically shows you a better development of the main characters, all of them are linked to the past in some way and this holds them in their own mind, at the end of the plot, we get to see everyone finally overcoming their past and being able to move on with their lives
                  (depending on how you look at it).
 Watching Cowboy Bebop non-chronologically also has fun watching the random adventures of a group of bounty hunters.
Another important point to highlight in the anime is the issue of the shaman, which is shown in several parts throughout the animation, it is important to remember a phrase that is said at the beginning of the anime about the men of the earth becoming stars when they die, after the final scene of the anime, we don't know what happens to Spike Spiegel, but we see a star rise to the sky, and from that, each one with its own conclusion.

Despite my limited exposure to the anime medium, I full-heartedly believe this piece of art is an anime masterpiece. It famously crosses several genres, it has amazing music, animation, and a creative, unique atmosphere.
I watched Firefly as child, and I loved watching this anime as an adult, as I'm sure it heavily inspired the Serenity universe. 
Personally, the jazz and songs like "Blue" were a joy to listen to.
A reminder to all those watching, pay attention to final salutations at the end of every episode, they carry a lot with them, and really cement the creator's intended mood and emotion of each episode. 
The themes
                  explored in the visually beautiful show are truly the centerpiece of the creator's vision for the show. I'm sure with each viewing, and the more time spent with Spike, Jet, Faye, Ed, Ein and their various acquaintances and bounties along the way, we can all learn a little more about our own personal outlook on our past and choices we make, especially as we age and grow wiser. 
I did not watch this show in the 90's, however I am a child of the last decade of the millennium, and I'm grateful that such an iconic show set in the future is also, so obviously, a product of that time. What I'm attempting to say, is that It's nostalgic science fiction for me, personally.
This is an episodic show, and I didn't feel the urge to binge watch as I tend to do with most anime. I'm not sure why this was the case, perhaps because I knew of this anime from before I truly knew anything about anime. I knew it was a classic, and was in no hurry to finish. I thoroughly enjoyed the experience, and felt truly moved at the end of several episodes. In the cases of the lighter episodes, I always ended with a big smile on my face. 
PS I watched subbed. I hear good things about the dub. I've seen the clips, and would agree the casting seems excellent. For me though, it is still off putting to watch dubs, and don't see myself rewatching with the dub because it's too distracting.

Cowboy Bebop is renowned as one of the finest anime's of all time, and for good reason, it's world, story and characters are so engaging and it's all multiplied by masterful direction from Shinichirō Watanabe, as well as a beautiful art style and musical score from Yoko Ono and seatbelts.
Within the first episode of cowboy bebop you're instantly enticed by it's unique visuals and stunning world, it's characters have depth that will take the entire series just to touch the tip of the iceberg in terms of exploration into their pasts, motives and ideology, the characters have such morbid and somber backstories yet they're full
                  of life that keep you smiling all the way through the show with their constant banter and bickering with one another. It's lead villain 'Vicious' reminds of Sephiroth from Final Fantasy VII, not just because of his appearance and choice in weaponry but more about the fact he has so much presence in his rather minimal screen time (compared to the rest of the cast), due to his heavy emotional connection to Spike and other characters throughout the show. Cowboy Bebop has imagery and aesthetic you cant find anywhere else, it's blend of sci-fi and noir crime simply cant be found anywhere else of this high quality, this is one negative i had with Cowboy Bebop's movie, as it lacked that blend of sci-fi and noir for majority of it's runtime, and one of the main reasons the series of so good is due to it's unique blend of two very different genre's and aesthetics, it's colourful yet bland, light yet dark in tone and it's truly an experience unlike any other, the show is a gripping adventure through a futuristic solar system full of crime, corruption, destruction and above all else...jazz.
Cowboy Bebop's soundtrack is one of the most beloved soundtracks of all time and for good reason, it brings so much life to the show, it's almost as if the show just wouldn't be the same without it's musical choice, the opening titles are simply iconic due to it's damn right masterful music and more incredible tracks can be heard all the way through this masterpiece.
The animation is clean as hell, the arial and hand to hand fights looks so fluent, a lot could of easily gone wrong when creating Bebop's complex fight choreography, but it all ended up fantastically due to a phenomenal job from Sunrise. The Japanese dub is still great but I urge each and every person to watch the show dubbed due to the English cast being perfect for each of the roles, with by far the greatest being Steve Blum as the protagonist Spike, which has implemented him as one of animations finest voice actors for his performance in Bebop Alone.
The pacing and runtime is simply perfect, it tells each of its episodical tales in such expansive detail in such a small 25 minute runtime (with 2 part special stories being seen twice in the show). It's kind of sad that anime has almost abandoned the story telling shows like Cowboy Bebop and Trigun went for, telling one single story in a single season instead of making many seasons which sadly mostly ends up in the show becoming bloated. Bebop has just the right amount of what it has to satisfy it's audience, not too little not too much in it's 26 episode length, I wish more creators would stick to this runtime as it will make it more accessible for people who don't want to watch hundreds of episodes as they simply don't have the time.
Cowboy Bebop is a show loved by so many across the world, and is one of the only anime's that I believe can be called a timeless classic, it will continue to be a gold standard in terms of anime series and I urge people who enjoyed the show to watch other anime's created by it's genius creator Shinichirō Watanabe.

Cowboy Bebop was about the second anime I ever watched.  I never could catch it all the time when it was on Adult Swim but thanks to online episodes and movie rentals I finally got to see it all about two years ago.  What caught my attention was the art.  The art is more real to life than some anime and really spoke to me.  The sound tract was great, I even hunted down and bought the OST.  The characters were unique and worked well together in the crazy futuristic setting.  The story was good over all and several
                  episodes stood out and re-watched many times.  All said it is a great anime and worthy of being called an anime classic.
