Some were pretty simple, like the ones portraying the life of the crew inside Bebop, but still, it added dynamic to a trope that seemed to be constrained by the dystopian side of sci-fi (not really in the context of the 90’s, I guess). 
The gist of the show, or should I say, the closing of Spike’s arc is only disclosed in the end of the show. It wasn’t anything mind-blowing or  beautifully crafted like a ancient greek tragedy, it felt just like The End. Some might say it was just irresponsible, but the magic of the entire anime didn’t fade in my eyes.
The art is just out-of-this-world beautiful. For me that means that I can see things as they are: no flare, no sparks, no needless reflective objects, just plain urban-like scenario and the flick of a cigarette, my favorite aesthetic. The characters sometimes look taller than usual, or just pretty asymmetrical sometimes, but, well, that doesn’t bother me at all.
Except for the delay in disclosing each character’s background, and sometimes doing a poor job at that, the overall work feels like a 10 for me. I’ve never experienced watching something like that, and I feel grateful.

(I try to keep my reviews short and sweet and straight to the point without giving away spoilers with that said lets get this show on the road)
Cowboy Bebop , is an old school, well thought out /planned anime. Anime's like these are so hard to fine. Something that is easy to follow and understandable. Most anime's nowadays are so colorful, with great animation but the story line and characters are completely shot. 
Story- The story gives off an original feel. Every episode left be wanting more and it was so easy to follow. However, there were too many plots they tried to squeeze into
                  a 26 episode series. Some questions were never answered. I believed that they tried to cover up these lapses with one big plot overall.
Art- The art was so retro. I loved it!! It totally took you back to a time were details to each character (no matter the importance or stance) was important. 
Sound- The voice actors did a great job with bringing these character to life.
Character- Some characters were develop more than others, which was a complete let down. They opened the flood gates but never closed it. Nonetheless, no character was completely left alone as a filler. Some episodes were completely dedicated to one character. Thus, it gave the reviewer a deeper sense of each main character.
Overall- I enjoyed this anime. I loved the style and how the creators used there own creative spirits to make this anime come to life. Overall it's a wonderful anime and I would recommend it to anyone.

Cowboy Bebop was, what you might call, my "gateway anime". Basically, it was the first anime I ever watched all of the way through. Sure, when I was younger I saw some episodes of Pokemon here and there, but I never actually started and completed an anime series in full. So, therefore, Cowboy Bebop was my first. And, while I may be a bit biased because of that, I think I can safely say that Cowboy Bebop is a masterpiece, or as close to a masterpiece as it can get.
STORY: 9/10
Without delving in spoilers, Cowboy Bebop follows a group of bounty hunters on the Bebop,
                  an old and worn down spaceship. Almost every episode follows a new adventure, almost completely unrelated to the previous. In one episode, they may be targeting a drug dealer in the deserts of the Tijuana asteroid colony. The next, they may be on Mars, targeting a dog thief. As you may gather from this, the series is very episodic, with only a few episodes revolving around the "underlying story". I quote "underlying story", because when you're watching Cowboy Bebop, you're not watching it for an epic science fiction noir story that spans multiple episodes. You're watching it for the here and now. And while, yes, the "underlying story" is interesting, and you want to see it play out, that's never the main focus. The focus is on the character interactions and the "bounty of the week" format. And, for what it is, it's great. 
If I were to have any complaints about the story, it would be that not every episode is as great as others. For example, the episode "Boogie Woogie Feng Shui" is not nearly as good as the episode before it, "Pierrot le Fou", or the episode after it, "Cowboy Funk". And while, yes, having every episode be amazing is a hard feat, when this show is great, it is really great. But, you can definitely tell that some episodes, just aren't as good as others. But, in spite of this, I still give a 9 to the story, because for me, hits like "Ballad of Fallen Angels" overshadow episodes like "Heavy Metal Queen".
ART: 9/10
Plenty of anime series from the 90s have a distinct look and feel to them. A lot of the time, this look and feel is dated, and doesn't hold up quite as well today. An example of this, would Trigun, a very similar anime to Cowboy Bebop. Cowboy Bebop, on the other hand, doesn't have this problem, and most of the art and animation holds up well, even 20 years later. Watching this, it's sometimes hard to believe it's from 1998, and it makes you wonder what they could've done had they had today's technology and equipment. The animation is incredibly fluid, a perfect example of this being the fight scene in "Asteroid Blues". The art is beautiful, a perfect example of this being the church scene in "Ballad of Fallen Angels". Again, if I were to have any complaints with the art, it would be that the digitally rendered scenes don't hold up quite as well as the hand drawn sequences. But, this scenes are few and far between, and aren't horrible to look at, so I still give the art a 9 out of 10. 
SOUND: 10/10
Perhaps the category Cowboy Bebop is most well known for, the sound is outstanding in most every way. The music is amazing, and fits quite nicely with every scene it's in. While Cowboy Bebop is known for having a jazz and blues soundtrack, it's surprising just how varied it really is. For example, "Heavy Metal Queen" has a very, well, heavy metal inspired soundtrack. "Ballad of Fallen Angels" has a very lyrical soundtrack, with songs such as "Rain" and "Green Bird". And, of course, it would be a disservice not to mention the amazing OP and ED sequences, with "Tank!" and "The Real Folk Blues" respectively. Both of these songs are now iconic, and immediately identifiable as Cowboy Bebop. Overall, the OST is one of the best in anime history.
Another aspect of the sound I wanted to touch on, is the dub. While the sub is very good, and I have zero complaints with it, it says something when even the original director of the anime says the English dub is better. This is the one anime where almost every one agrees that the dub is better. Even avid sub watchers, who almost always refuse to watch anything else, agree that the dub is better for Cowboy Bebop. Every actor gave it their all, and every voice fits the character. There's never a time when the dub doesn't match up with the lip movements. And, of course, the dub features the masterful work from Steve Blum, as Spike Spiegel. There's no wonder this guy is considered one of the best in the business. His work as Spike is consistently amazing, and possibly some of the best voice work in any animation, be it anime or not. Overall, the sound definitely deserves a 10/10 in my opinion. I have zero complaints, not even nitpicks. 
CHARACTERS: 10/10
This is another category where Cowboy Bebop really shines. The chemistry and the interactions between each of the main characters, is one of the draws of the show in my opinion. It's what each episode relies on, and why it's enjoyable to keep coming back to the show, even when each episode is very episodic. Each crew member of the Bebop has their own complex personality, and their own complex problems from their past. I don't have a whole lot else to say when it comes to the characters, without just talking about each character and delving into spoilers. It's just something that's best figured out while watching. Overall though, the characters are perfect, and I give this category a 10/10.
ENJOYMENT: 10/10
When it comes to my personal enjoyment of the show, I would have to give this category a 10. Like I said at the beginning, this was my first anime, and it was a great one to start out with. Almost everything about it caught my interest, and I ended up finishing it within a week. It opened my eyes to a whole other medium of entertainment, that was unlike anything I'd ever seen. Cowboy Bebop is still one of the best anime I've ever seen, and for that, I would have to give the anime the following rating:
OVERALL: 10/10

COWBOY BEBOP: Is this a masterpiece? It depends on how you define the word.
Cowboy Bebop has received significant attention worldwide that it comes to the point that it has been considered an anime masterpiece. But is this claim justifiable? In my opinion, the term masterpiece is somewhat vague. If it is synonymous to perfect, then I must say that Cowboy Bebop is not a masterpiece at all. It has its own flaws -- like any other story. If it signifies something that is a work of a genius, then Cowboy Bebop’s position becomes debatable.
The story revolves around Spike, Jet, Faye, Edward, and Ein -- the
                  crew of the Bebop. The series appears to be somewhat episodic, for it doesn’t really follow a solid overall story. It merely talks about the adventures of the crew. One could argue that Spike’s storyline is actually the overall story. But this is apparently not the case, for it is not substantiated enough to be considered as such. At best, it could be called a story arc that is scattered all throughout the series to add mystery to the franchise.
However, the storytelling is not purely episodic in terms of technicality. It still follows a logical order in the story sequences. What I like about this kind of storytelling is that it gives the viewers different perspectives of the Cowboy Bebop universe. The fact that it doesn’t just follow a single story makes the fictional world more open to exploration. What makes this episodic approach more effective is its ability to give sufficient amount of screen time to each character, so there is a lot of room for character development to take place.
The crew of the Bebop, I must admit, is very balanced in terms of personality. The characterization of its members is distinct enough for each of the characters to leave an impression -- not to mention that these characters blend well together. Spike is the laidback dude; Jet is the mature and reliable one; Faye is the chic that has a lot of attitude; and Edward is the jolly character who counters the solemn mood. Aside from Edward, each of them has a problematic past, which makes them much more relatable as characters. What makes them even more believable as characters is the fact that they show traits that are beyond their character framework -- like how Faye actually shows a lot of emotion despite her portrayal of being a heartless trickster. It just means that they are not surface-level characters with unique traits just to appear solid; they actually have depth. Even though Edward has no tragic past to make her more concrete, she is not a problematic character. Her role of balancing out the crew is enough to consider her all right.
I don’t normally tackle music in my anime reviews. I only include it if it is worth noting -- and yes, Cowboy Bebop’s music is worth the notice. Its concentration on jazz and blues gives the series a very distinct atmosphere. And I know that it is impressive when one of the best opening themes of all time is of an anime that has been released in the 90’s!
So, after everything I have said, is Cowboy Bebop a masterpiece? In its technical aspects, it is debatable that the series is a work of a genius. But it is still not perfect! It is only a matter of defining what masterpiece truly is. I define masterpiece as something that has made a significant impact in its art form or beyond. So, as a personal note, Cowboy Bebop is a masterpiece, just because it has become widely influential not just in the anime scene, but in science fiction in general. That’s enough for me to consider it as such, for, I believe, that defining masterpiece as a perfect work is just absurd.

The title is an experiment to cram a variety of genres into the Bebop Space-punk setting. In spite of this, like good music in a dance, its beat is as addictive as it is coherent, and the individual melodies of each key character's development - each plot point and progress - leads viewers in a waltz into the inevitable end. 
The music's great, and the animation (especially action sequences) hold up despite being from so long ago. The story's also pretty timeless. 
It's not complicated. Just listen to the self-referential OP - it's time to blow this scene, get everyone and the stuff together, and
                  3-2-1 let's jam.

It’s probably pointless to review this series at this point. Cowboy Bebop already has so much acclaim from the Anime community that another positive review would just be so much white noise. The reason I even bother to write this is because, for once, I actually found a series that lived up to its immense hype.
I don’t want this review to be nothing but comparisons to Samurai Champloo, but seriously, this has “Shinichiro Watanabe” written all over it. The two series feel very similar: a cast of flawed but likable characters, traveling from place to place, getting into trouble and as time goes by we
                  come learn about their mysterious pasts. Jet is the quintessential big brother we all wish we had, Edward is hilarious, (I didn’t really care for Faye, she doesn’t seem to contribute much) and as for Spike? Oh Lord, Spike Spiegel is a BAD-ASS!!! He kicks all kinds of ass, he has a bad-ass spacecraft, and he’s a strong three-dimensional character who does everything with such gravitas. These are the people you wish were your friends in real life.
Another strong point of the series we can attribute to Watanabe is the atmosphere. The mish-mash of different genres, Western to Sci-fi and everything in between, gives this series an art style that has never been seen before. No other anime has dared to combine cigarettes and spaceships, and I don’t believe any other director could bring this concept to life. But who could supply the sounds necessary to accompany this visual feast? As always, Yoko Kanno delivers. I don’t think the music score is as memorable as Champloo’s, (the exception being “Green Bird” from episode five) but it was the perfect fit and helped to set the tone of the series. Side note: “Tank!” IS the greatest opening theme for an anime ever written.
As for the voice-acting, I watched the English Dub, and now I understand why this Dub gets so much attention. Not a single character is miscast. Not one. Every random Joe on the street, all the numerous side characters that come and go throughout the series, they all serve their exact purpose: sound realistic while not distracting from what else may be going on. Of course, the real stars of the show are the main characters. These are some of the most believable performances I think I've ever heard. Steve Blum’s role as Spike Spiegel truly speaks for itself. (No pun intended)
As much as I want to give this series a perfect score, there was one thing that didn’t sit well with me. Whenever I finish watching an anime, I ask myself “so what exactly can I take away from this series?” Honestly, I can’t really find an answer for that question. Perhaps, it will come to me at a later date, but for now I see this series as kind of pointless. By the end of Cowboy Bebop’s run, it doesn’t feel like much has been accomplished. Don’t get me wrong, I loved watching these characters interact; but as a narrative Bebop feels lacking.
They say it’s not about the destination; it’s about the journey itself, and this jazzy space odyssey was one hell of a journey. Cowboy Bebop was loved in its time, it’s loved now, and it will continue to be loved far into the future. You owe it to yourself to watch this series.
Bang.

<Potential Spoilers>
There are so many good things about this anime.
Cowboy Bebop combines everything that you would find good in anime to create a masterpiece. Arguably making this series a staple in the anime industry. The perfectly constructed story, art style, and world that has its own aesthetics, use of jazz and blues in the soundtrack, and the memorable characters make this a series worthy of being one of the best.
The story takes place in a futuristic sci-fi universe where our main characters are bounty hunters. Each episode introduces a new story that the characters have undertaken. As the series goes on we are introduced to
                  more characters who join this bounty hunter crew. Each character of the main cast links to the story's main theme of overcoming past trauma. They all struggle to move forward and escape their trauma. An idea that makes the cast feel more like real people.
The art and animation are brilliant, despite being over two decades old the animation is still comparable to modern-day animation. The animation also blends in with the environment effectively, the way the environment and characters are drawn and portrayed, creates a unique aesthetic that you can't find anywhere else. However, the use of CGI was poor, to say the least. While I will sympathize considering the time period, The occasional 3D animation stuck out like a sore thumb.
The use of jazz and blues is something you don't find often within the soundtrack of anime. Considering these genres are more common among the western culture. Seeing this genre of music in an anime would instantly contrast itself from the soundtracks of other anime, that also fit into the world of Cowboy Bepop.
The characters are easily the highlight of the show, each member of the main cast linking to the main theme of the show. Overcoming and living with horrid pasts. The most obvious example is the protagonist Spike, each character overcomes their suffering. Ed returns to family while Faye recovers her memories. But Spike only comes to terms with his past during the finale, where he finally feels alive.
The themes of past trauma intertwined with this narrative. The brilliant art style, the unique genre of soundtrack use, and the memorable characters make this one of the greatest series of all time.
Overall, I rank this 9/10.

Oh Cowboy Bebop, how I adore you! If you have watched anime for any period of time you have at least heard about this series. It is an anime famous for its amazing and relaxed soundtrack, lovable characters and mature but fun story. Let us get started reviewing this work of art!
Story - 7/10
Wait a minute, haven't I just been praising the series for being a work of art? How dare I give the story a 7/10. The thing about Cowboy Bebop story is that is extremely simplistic. Now is this necessarily a bad thing? Hell no! The relaxed story blends in perfectly with the
                  setting of Cowboy Bebop. It doesn't attempt to tell a story which explores some deeper meaning, because that isn't the goal of the series. The story helps you to learn to love the characters and the world in which they live. 
Art - 9/10
For the time in which this series was created, it packs some glorious animation. I love how much western influence is put into the world of Cowboy Bebop. Vivid, earthly, colors fit the western theme of the series, to mind-blowing planets, infrastructure and science fiction which is done on a realistic scale. The character design is nothing to be ashamed of either, sporting some of the literally coolest looking characters ever created.
Sound - 10/10
Once again here comes the western influence of the anime. Great choice in music at the correct timing makes this series even more pleasant of a watch. The OP of the series fits perfectly with the relaxed and smooth tone of the series, while the ED ties in with the more serious moments within the anime. Whether you are a fan of more dated genres of music, like Jazz, Blues and Classical or not, this musical score will most definitely leave some sort of an impression on you. The voice acting is especially great in the Dub version of the series, with Steven Blum's portrayal of Spike Spiegel being one of the best examples of English dubbing within an anime.
Character - 10/10
One of the defining principals of any great entertainment medium is without a doubt the characters within the series/movie/anime/novel ect. This is yet another thing the anime does perfectly. Featuring some of the coolest characters to date as well as some of the quirkiest characters ever. From the cool and suave Spike, the reserved and wise Jet, the sexy and brilliant Faye or the adorable and innocent Ed, Cowboy Bebop is bound to have you hooked on one of the fantastic main characters. What Cowboy Bebop does better than almost most anime ever, is the way they portray their characters as human beings. They aren't some fictional characters which children aspire to be but someone you can relate towards.
Enjoyment - 10/10
Being a cynical piece of shit like myself, I really couldn't believe how much I enjoyed Cowboy Bebop and I ended up enjoying it  more than any other anime I have ever seen. The reason being is that the show takes all the elements I love from anime, sprinkle some heavy western influence on top, to create one of the best recipes for anime out there.
Overall - 10/10
If there ever was an anime out there to be dubbed as a Masterpiece, Cowboy Bebop would be my first candidate. Sporting incredible visuals, a soothing soundtrack and one of the best casts within an anime, Cowboy Bebop is an anime deserving of a 10/10 rating and I would recommend the series to anyone, because it has something to appease everyone.
Thank you so much for taking the time to read my review. Sorry if I come of as biased, but I tried to be objective and subjective when writing reviews.

Cowboy Bebop: highly rated in the anime community, abnormally well received outside of the anime community, accompanied by a cult fan-base... sounds too good to be true...
But I must say, that I don't believe the show has helped with any cures to diseases, scientific achievements, breakthroughs in technology, or advances in diplomatic relationships.
So I guess it does have flaws.
But if you haven't watched this show and are an anime fan, or even if you are just browsing this website, then you have spent some time devoted to anime that could've been better spent watching this show.
I find it a shame that anime is clouded by
                  people who complain about the episodic nature of the show. Compared to Bebop, a series that relies on overly-dramatic cliff-hangers is shallow. Bebop is developed: from the complexity of the characters (if you only see the main cast as their surface presents, I suggest to rewatch and pay more attention to the details of the characters pasts, as well as their present) to the vivid animation (and I don't mean flashy colors, I mean how the pieces move, their shape, design, etc...)
Lastly, the quality of the music can not be understated. Almost every single anime on the earth suffers from its cliched garbage music. Thank you Bebop, for bringing us a soundtrack that I don't want to skip over, but I can even call a masterpiece.

Cowboy Bebop is my first Anime ever.
I watched all the episodes in one sit, 10 hours non stop.
Although I'm not into Anime in general, I was very interested in watching Cowboy Bebop because some people recommended it to me and I've heard that it's one of the best.
Now that I watched Cowboy Bebop, I really want to talk about it and share my thoughts on it.
First of all, I loved the main characters! I thought they were pretty much perfect; awesome personalities and development, beautifully written dialogue and a good sense of humor.
The story is absolutely fantastic! I really liked the premise and it's philosophical
                  themes.
Also, music is amazing and the art style is very fitting and charming, and the quality was surprisingly high for a TV Show of the 90's.
The only thing I didn't like about Cowboy Bebop is the episodic format; some episodes felt a bit off the pace.
My absolute favorite episodes are Honky Tonk Women, Ballad of Fallen Angels, Ganymede Elegy, Jupiter Jazz 1 & 2, Cowboy Funk, Hard Luck Woman and The Real Folk Blues 1 & 2; they were outstanding!
Pros:
+ Exceptional narrative
+ Superb characters
+ Really great music
+ Very charming visuals
Cons:
- Episodic structure
Final Rating: 10/10
- Masterpiece -
Cowboy Bebop is a phenomenal piece of art that will stick with me for a long time. From the lovable characters to the wonderful narrative and the funky music, Cowboy Bebop is special.
Do I recommend it?:
Yes! It's a must-watch in my opinion.

Cowboy Bebop is now officially my favourite anime, and its not nostalgia or a biased perspective.  going into this into this completely blind  I have never indulged in an experience quite like cowboy bebop. but what is a cowboy bebop and how has it gained its title as truly genre defining classic? cowboy bebop is focused on the planetary adventures of the bebop crew consisting of Spike Spiegel, Jet Black, Faye Valentine, Radical Edward and Ein (A welsh corgi) the crew go on misadventures from episode to episode In their ship The Bebop, but through out the episodes each characters past is revealed
                  through memorable moments and character dramas that can only be fully appreciated if you see them first hand.
But how does the average episode of cowboy bebop play out? well cowboy bebop really has no underling plot to most of its episodes except for some (which I will not spoil) and are mainly short and self contained episodes that further each characters relation ships this is what gives this anime in particular a unique feel as it really does feel like you are going through the solar system with them hopping between planets with no real ultimate goal other than to make it through the day and we can all relate to that... not the solar system part but the desire of nothing more than to make it through and that's how cowboy bebop makes its unrealistic events feel real along side the developed and interesting characters.
However its not perfect, its was mentioned that cowboy bebop uses a mostly self contained and sometimes comedic structure for its episodes and that's one of the reasons some people don't like this anime. to be brief if you think that the idea of self contained stories from episode to episode tied to gather by narratives and character moments that happen very sparingly through out the show then by all means watch it but that lack of a constantly developing story and no real ultimate and established goals for any of the characters is a big turn off for many. other than that there is a part around the middle of the season that is pretty boring and unsubstantial but that is about it.
Now onto the details and general synopsis for the main crew.
Spike: A experienced member of the red dragon crime syndicate and has a troubled past he would like to forget about
Jet: as one of the only remaining honest cops in the corrupt law system Jet left his work to pursue bounty hunting.
Faye: A wanted bounty who through a turn of events made it onto the bebop crew.
Ed: a talented hacker with a child like attitude
Now would I recommend this show? absolutely. Despite the few complaints and the animation that is frankly showing its age, cowboy bebop deserves all the praise it gets and is an absolute classic

Having slept on this for over two decades to both my chagrin and that of my peers, to say that this was a bit of a disappointment would be one of the crowning understatements of the very same stretch of time. I hear Bebop described as the "least anime" of the medium as a whole which makes sense, what with it ostensibly being just a string of one-offs benchmarked by expository character moments and the occasional bit of filler, all of which vary drastically in terms of overall quality.
All in all, it's not necessarily unfocused as the primary aim's to highlight a wayward band of
                  outcasts' unlikely bond and collaborative approach to the bounties they flub time and again, however the latter episodes bring about an abrupt bit of closure for all. A bit jarring on account of how Jet's arc wraps itself up (much) sooner than everyone else's and abrupt in this case is more synonymous with rushed as the two-part finale doesn't allow for emotions to bubble and burst. It's cathartic all the same but nowhere near as poignant, especially when the series hints at said poignancy with each semblance of closure it tosses our way. It's an aesthetically sumptuous and richly drawn world for sure, and it definitely scores points for being a freewheeling exercise in coolness, even if the decades-spanning hype train made this all the more underwhelming in the end.

Cowboy bebop was one of the most unique anime I have watched and dont get me wrong, I try to watch as many different ones as possible. It still doesnt feel anime, it probably never will given the way the medium has evolved. The music is haunting, the comedy is situational, the story is episodic and the characters, well they are the weirdest misfits of all time.
It is one show which isnt about the moral of the story because there isnt any. Even though in some way its about dealing with your past cause thats a weight you're gonna carry, its all about anticlimatic endings.
                  There is no winner, no one is riding into the sunset and thats what sets it apart.  Every episode tries to touch some other genre and its unapologetic about it.
Cowboy bebop is one which I will never forget about because of its storytelling. It doesnt try to be funny or happy. Its a story about 3 people dealing with the weight and 1 kid trying to see past all of this gloom. 
As far as characters go, all 4 are unique and memorable. Jet is the dad, Faye is the rebellious sister, Spike is the lazy stylish older brother and Eduard is the overenthusiastic youngest kid. Eduard is the quirkest one and you'll fall in love with her soon. Spike is criminally stylish and has the charm which can make anyone go week in their knees. Jet is the guy who you can rely for your life. Faye is the one who you hate and love at the same time. And how can we forget our super smart dog Ein, who is the black horse at times. Their banter is when the show is at its peak.
Cowboy bebop is wildely inconsitent and only few episodes shine. Episode 5 is Bebop at its best with its criminal use of music and action. What I love about the show that even though its full of style, its not flashy and very subtle. A true masterpiece

Cowboy Bebop is a classic. It's known and renowned as an anime which you must watch. I really loved it. Something about those four characters and watching their adventures was wonderful and I can safely say that this is one of my favorite anime, I truly think that you should watch it. The story follows four people living as bounty hunters and although most of the episodes are unrelated stories, they all tie in at the end for one last adventure and end with a bang. The soundtrack is beautiful and the opening song always cheers me up. It is truly wonderful.

Cowboy Bebop is one of the best shows I have watched, period. The first episode sets the tone, with a seemingly upbeat and almost flippant protagonist, who reveals himself to be cunning, battle-worn, and melancholic. This start sets up a string of subtly interconnected stories that begin to unravel the past as we come to understand what type of show we are actually watching. The true marvel of this show is what we are not shown. Cowboy Bebop takes place after the climax, after the heroics, after the action; it gives us characters that have taken the punches, lost parts of themselves along the way,
                  and are seeking to cling on to a sense of meaning in their post-story lives. It is fitting that the main characters are basically drifting through nothing, as this is true to who they have become. 
This brings us to the introduction of Faye Valentine and Ed; the two characters representing hope and the future. Faye brings mischief to the group, a sense of change to shake up their lives and wake Spike and Jet out of their melancholic stupor. Her developing feelings for Jet give hope that he may awaken to what he has before him, and bring him from his prison of the past. Ed serves as a beacon of joy, laughter, and new life for these middle aged veterans, and brings some of the best story moments of the series. 
The music of Cowboy Bebop is legendary, and acts as a focal point of the series, bringing life to each scene and truly resonating long after the show has gone. And there are many powerful moments the show presents, touching on moral issues, healing wounds of the past, and giving closure to chapters of life. The ending itself was beautiful, tragic, and captivating; and I think it captures the soul of the series vividly. I highly recommend this to anyone willing to give it a chance

Well, Cowboy Bebop is almost twenty years old and still as a masterpiece, with one of the most memorables soundtracks evermade. It's not a mistake saying that the ost is, somehow, a character, an intermitent part of the story, the conductor of the orchestra that this anime is.
The episodes are well-done designed for the developing of the main characters, creating with the spectator a short-medium relationship of affection with each one of them. Look: there are only 4 main characters (5, if you count that fabulous dog), and you will be sure, until the end, that each one matter so much and has a great
                  background behind them. Seems something that sould be obviously in any entertainment work? Well, it's not, and here we can see it done in an amazing and unique way.
Cowboy Bebop is, in a general way, an episodical anime, and it's normal that some episodes will give you more pleasure than others, but it doesn't become a defect exactly. There are so many vritues about the anime that any possible defect seems very small and maybe you don't even notice.
See you, space cowboy!

The anime is a collection about 20 one shot stories with little snippets of character lore thrown in that seem useless for the most part. The main villain seemed to have no prevalent motive and was in about 4 episodes or something. Here are my thought on it 
Story: 5
The story was a major disappointment, like I said its kind of irrelevant. Its just a bunch of one shot episodes and if your lucky maybe you'll have 2
                  parts. The episodes aren't bad , just this anime would have been SO good if it held a prevalent storyline and went into the trauma of some of the characters (FAYE) more. 
Animation/art: 9
The art and the character design is beautiful, and the animation is pretty damn good excluding some bad cg planets. The costume for Spike is the embodiment of swag and really gives him that nonchalant badass vibe. Also not to mention the fights were very well animated especially the first episode.
Music: 10 
What can I say, The music fucking slaps bro . I mean bebop IS in the name.  Yoko Kanno really did a good job boring that space cowboy and jazzy vibe to the story.
Acting: 9 
Lots of people who watched this while it was airing in America love the dub, I think it has one of the better dubs out there but I do prefer the sub. The voice actor (kaji from eva so sexy) for spike really is just perfect for his badass vibe and the others characters delivered very well for there characters too .
enjoyment:7

overall :8
Most people seem to be blinded by nostalgia on this one . While it does deliver amazingly in most categories, I'm still disappointed in the story. This could have been one of the all time greats if the story was prevalent. I still would recommend it to most , just don't go in thinking its amazing

There isn't any other anime like Cowboy Bebop! The well written characters, relatable plots and inner struggles from each character is one of the many reasons I re-watch this anime year after year. The music is absolutely beautiful, unique and gives this show such a cool, jazzy aesthetic. The colors and space scenery in this anime really put you in the world of Cowboy Bebop and creates a sense of mystery, adventure, and all around fun. Although all the characters are gems in their own right the standouts are Spike, Ed, and Ein!This 90s anime is a must watch and a good starting point if
                  you're beginning your anime journey or interested in the works of Shinichiro Watanabe. 
- TheAnimeOkami

One of the all-time anime greats, Cowboy Bebop was a series that went well beyond what to offer up for a 1990s TV anime series in terms of both presentation and storytelling quality. Focused on the exploits of the members of a group of bounty hunters aboard the Bebop spaceship, the series mixes around episodic and ongoing storylines to tell its different tales involving Spike, Jet, Faye, Ein and Ed as they hunt down criminal targets and come to confront tragic elements of their pasts.
The storytelling approach to Bebop was unique for its time (and still holds up to this day) as many titles in
                  the 1990s either offered an ongoing plot line or focused on episodic developments with its cast. Here in Bebop though, the storytelling focus is more fragmented as episodes are either devoted to exploring the Bebop crew going after a bounty that are mostly self-contained or dealing with issues related to their past that offer more ongoing development as the series progresses, particularly with Spike and Faye's stories. Each episode helps to explore more to the world of the series or flesh out another major element to one of the Bebop crew's developments. They also have varying moods and themes explored throughout the show's run, offering a mix of film noir, westerns, sci-fi, horror, comedy, action, mind screw and drama throughout the show's run. The show is heavily influenced through Western pop culture, and it shows with its homages and parodies to popular Western media franchises and figures like Batman, Gunsmoke, Alien and Bruce Lee.
Bebop depicts a realistic approach to its sci-fi world, preferring to apply a mix of scientific advances like astral gates and spaceships with settings that closely resemble those found within the modern era unlike the futuristic settings that titles like Akira or Outlaw Star would portray. Planets and moons colonized by humanity look more like modern era cities, each having their own varying issues with criminals, poverty and corruption. In addition, ships like the Bebop and Spike's Swordfish ship are regarded as relics of a past era by those having more modern spaceships via the standards of their time period.
Visually, Cowboy Bebop is easily among one of the 1990s most impressive looking titles. It offers vast settings that have a good deal of detail and take place in a variety of settings that include space, cities, mountains and sewers. Many characters are drawn with lifelike and realistic details, not sporting the typical “big eyed” anime look you would expect of many titles with characters sporting a variety of looks and some being attractive without going overboard with the looks, like Faye and Spike. Animation is consistently fluid throughout the series and applied in a variety of ways throughout Bebop's run that include physical fights, gun fights, spaceship fights, realistic physics applied to floating in space and evading incoming obstacles like gunfire or wreckage. CG animation is employed for some of the show's more elaborate animated sequences like computer screens and space wreckage, but these bits are rendered so well that they fit seamlessly in with the show's regular animation.
The soundtrack to Bebop is just as excellent, taking on the same Western influences that the show's storytelling elements employ as it milks use of Western genres like jazz, blues, country and hard rock to flow along with its presentation. Composed by famous anime composer Yoko Kanno, Bebop is easily among one of anime's best soundtracks that you can listen to, whether watching the series or enjoying just the music itself.
With its high-quality presentation and storytelling that are heavily Western influenced, Cowboy Bebop is easily among the very best offerings that the medium of anime has to offer with its excellent storytelling, visuals, soundtrack and characterization for a TV anime that is easily accessible to both newcomer and veteran alike.

One of the best animes of all time.
From 1998
26 episodes
Genre: science fiction, space western, comedy, action, thriller 
Anime takes place in 2071 where it is almost the entire solar system is inhabited by humans. Our main characters who travel with a spaceship Bebop are bounty hunters. They make money by hunting criminals.
Protagonists: Spike Spiegel, Faye Valentine, Jet Black, Edward (girl btw), and a dog named Ein. 
They could only earn money if they bring criminals back alive. Anime has a little story arc about the main character Spike and his great love Julia. Arc also talks about Spike's life inside of syndicate and about his
                  rival and antagonist named Vicious.
Besides the main characters, minor characters also are written very well. The final episode was very emotional and it is one of the best anime endings ever. 
Amazing seal animation performance. 
The best thing about Cowboy bebop is OST soundtrack.
My favorite:
Tank!

Cowboy Bebop is considered one of the “greats” by many an anime fan, and despite my resistance to giving a show a 10/10, I’m inclined to agree. Cowboy Bebop displays an understanding of the stories its taking inspiration from, while also adding to and transforming those stories into something new and entirely unique from the things it takes inspiration from.
To begin, Cowboy Bebop respects its audience in a way that most shows simply don’t. Cowboy Bebop rarely ever tells the audience what’s happening in a scene, or how a character feels, unless it is absolutely necessary. It allows the audience to inference and theorize and
                  come to their own conclusion about a character’s intentions and emotions, something which few shows, even decades after Bebop’s release, manage to accomplish.
Cowboy Bebop is one of the most visually and musically pleasing pieces I’ve seen in media. Its character designs perfectly showing off what kind of people they are, further emphasizing the moments these characters break their stereotypes and become human in a way most shows simply don’t allow for. Its music is legendary among anime fans. With the opening theme “Tank!” being my personal favorite of any anime.
Cowboy Bebop also tells its story in a way semi-unique to television. Its character backstories are never outright explained to the viewer, instead small inklings are given to the viewer and they are left to put these pieces together, making the show seem mystical and leads to a frankly epic conclusion which I cannot spoil here.
Cowboy Bebop is the most pure science fiction experience I’ve had in a long time. It doesn’t bog itself down in explaining away the terminology of the world the characters inhabit, instead just allow the viewer to fill in the pieces they need. Rather than large portions of episodes dedicated to explaining technology, Bebop ignores that in favor of focusing on its characters.
All this and more makes Bebop one of few shows I would glowingly recommend.

11. Continuing from my Detective Conan, Death Note and One Piece reviews, I am still documenting my anime journey.
Cowboy Bebop is truly the best gateway anime for newcomers.
Back then, we got introduced to anime on a special TV channel and were mostly watching "kid-friendly" anime like Naruto, Beyblade, Yugioh, etc.
We later found out that another channel was airing anime but only after 23:00 PM. It was MTV and they aired shows like Ghost in The Shell: Stand Alone Complex and Cowboy Bebop.
Both of these shows superb masterpieces!
It is a must watch for every anime enthusiast.
In my reviews I don't talk much spoilers or go too
                  deep into the story. 
In the end if you wanted that you could just read the description of the show or watch a no-spoiler trailer or something.
If even after 23 years, people still remember this show fondly and it holds up like good wine, then it is clear that the show is good.
To be honest I only sometimes managed to watch it on TV and even then the episodes did not make much sense because I skipped the ones before.
I watched it whole when I seriously sat down and looked Cowboy Bebop and GIS on the internet.
I was always intrigued with the episodes on TV. Later a lot of people were talking good things about it and literally no one was saying anything bad (back before MAL and similar websites).
Back then people's opinions mattered because they had developed tastes.
Today every donkey has the opportunity to vomit their opinion as a review and similar sycophants of the show will support each other and breed toxicity.
That's why I do not trust the opinion and reviews of people, especially here on MAL.
I'd like to re-watch it soon, it is a great show, I don't even have to tell you this.

It's been tough getting into anime made in the 1990s, but this series, definitely one of my favorite anime in that period. Everything about it fascinated me and hooked me on until the very end.
The plot itself was simple, cowboys combined with sci-fi, but throughout the series, it expands on various genres contained in each episode. Not only does it showcase how the main cast doesn't get along with each other, but it further shows how impactful each of their cases is during the plot of each episode. The variety of tones Cowboy Bebop goes mixes in well, from a dark and frightening episode to
                  a sad and emotional episode, combined well it makes a good plot.
The story started a little slow, but manage to build up to deep character arcs for all of the main cast. It starts with a space cowboy and his comrade hunting down criminals for their bounties, but once they pick up new crew members, it starts to expand more on their backstories while chasing after those criminals at the same time. At times has its comedic moments, but also contains serious events that impact who they are and eventually lead to a nice and exciting ride to go on.
The Bebop crew was really fun and diverse compared to other anime groups. It was the case of opposites attract, yet can work with each other despite not getting along making the interactions between them unique in their way. A major theme among them is their character arcs. For example, the main girl Faye Valentine was shown to be a woman with attitude, however certain episodes expanded more on backstory and gave her the goal to figure out for herself. The best part about them is that their character arcs are well-written and wrapped up by the time Cowboy Bebop was about to end and it felt satisfying for them to realize their answers to their past.
The soundtrack in this series is by far my favorite part as it went on. The opening was so good and I like how it was able to sound amazing while having no vocals at the same time, making it iconic during each episode as a result. The background music felt like a 90s series, and it felt satisfying to hear while adding that with some impressive animation showing how it's a sci-fi series as well. On a separate note, the titles of each episode were my favorite titles of all time.
Overall, this classic shined bright like the stars in the night sky, it has well-written character arcs and showed how diverse each of the characters and episodes is. While the ending is still one of the greatest mysteries in anime, the plot and story will drag you in for a funny, yet amazing ride as we get to know the characters more. Spike Spiegel will always be one of the coolest characters in all of the anime and gave the best character arcs out of the Bebop crew. I recommend this series for those that want to get into anime and start becoming a fan of them in the process.

Rating this show was hard. For me it's between an 8 and a 7. The characters were likeable, the art and sound were fine. The show was enjoyable. But the writing was so fatally flawed that it brought the story down. Put simply; there is no overall message of the show because every episode is a self-contained story that has little connection to the overall plot.
Cowboy Bebop is an anime that starts strong. It's likeable. It makes an impression on the viewer with its two main characters, Spike and Jet, and how they have such a strong bond.
But, the anime suffers from poor writing and
                  story. It very commonly falls into cliches and tropes. And it's a short-story simulator. The effective formulation of a macro-story, a story that contains all the figures of the main plot and effectively develops all their character development simultaneously, is non-existent. 
There's a reason why Evangelion gives the existential threat of Angels or a "third impact", LOTR has the "dark lord" and so on and so forth. The purpose of these existential threats that target everyone is that they target EVERYONE. That they make everyone learn the value of one and another so that they act cohesively and thus act like a team. There is no such existential threat in Cowboy Bebop. 
The only threat in Cowboy Bebop is how much debt the characters are in.
There's also the issue of character progression. Spike is the same hothead in episode 1 as he is in episode 26.  Jet changes to not be afraid anymore and Faye does significantly change because she learns she needs people/a home. But the protagonist himself doesn't learn anything. Which is a shame because he is such a great character. One of my favourite protagonists of ALL time. 
Oh, and the other 2 characters who are apart of his crew? They are useless and do nothing. Also, not to mention the antagonist is awful. An antagonist for the sake of being an antagonist.
Furthermore, Cowboy Bebop has a serious case of Deux ex Machina. In the last episode for example, one of the characters is doing a vehicle getaway and is being pursued by assassins when they are magically saved by one of the main characters who is in this specific place for no other reason than they had to be for the sake of the plot. This is not a one-off coincidence. The entire series is filled with this type of writing convenience that trivialises any actual serious writing. If I was being fair, I'd give the story a 5 for such BS.
It's annoying and I let the anime get away with it because the characters are likeable.
Overall, this anime is good. I'd say watch it, but you can't be too critical and just have to let yourself enjoy the characters. Because the writing is bad and will make you roll your eyes with how bad it can be.

Spoilers ig.
First and foremost, I absolutely loved the music. 10/10
I think my enjoyment waned whenever the plot would shift from a stand-alone episodic format to exploring the pasts of the main cast. Personally, I enjoy stand-alone episodic animes and I would have preferred if the entire anime followed this format. 
That's not to say I didn't enjoy exploring the main cast's pasts. I especially enjoyed figuring out Faye's past and her struggle with her identity, and Ein's conclusion did leave me emotional. Whilst Ein's story didn't go into much depth, the depth and time Faye's story got really made me invested.
On the other hand, I
                  did not understand Spike's backstory as much. This may be due to me being an idiot, but I also felt that a lot of the storytelling for Spike were these single-frame flashbacks rather than a fleshed-out story like Faye's. This led to a lot of confusion for me and thus I ended up not caring for Spike's story, which is a shame considering that I would have enjoyed exploring how a criminal syndicate in a futuristic space time would have evolved and the politics surrounding it.
I'm sorry Jet but I really did not care for your story :'(( Anytime the story would explore Jet's past the anime just grinded to a halt for me and I struggled to get through the episode without skipping. But this is a personal bias than a storytelling one. Ironically, out of all the ways the backstories were told, Jet's was probably the best where it was a balance of all three I described before (just detailed enough with single-frame flashbacks to balance it).
My main gripe with the anime is just how they jumped between exploring backstory and then stand-alone adventures.

Age is irrelevant. Great Story revolving around firmly developed characters allowing for a deeper connection to the show as a whole. With a large range of personalities covered by every character allows for a deep connection for anyone. Each main character is well developed throughout the main plotline within brief episodes allowing for simple yet well-done character development. Pacing of the overall show is simple yet has many layers. Unique for its time, still holding up to day. Adding to it's rewatchability. 
Genuine enjoyment aided by the masterful comedy laced deep within the roots of the show. Art style, old fashion yet fresh. Despite being
                  older than most anime now days, its retro art style help elevate the overall feel of the show. Certainly a memorable art style, fluid movement helped aid the plentiful fight scenes. Alongside conventional yet appealing character design. All of this tied together by a kick-ass sound track that truly encapsulates to overall vibe of the show. Voice actors cast almost perfectly create a whole new level of feel to each character. 
A true gem from a time past.

Post Series Depression: ~9
Tear Factor: ~6
Laugh Factor: ~3
Drama Factor: ~8
Character Attachment: ~10
Story: There are multiple arcs throughout the show, each arc is phenomenal.
Art: The art may be dated, however it is still amazing animation.Sound: Soundtrack is perfect for the noir-esque feel of the show, and sound effects are up there as well.
Characters: Each character is unique in their own way and has their own amazing arc.
Enjoyment: Extreme level of enjoyment, the show doesn't fail to deliver an extremely well devised episode by episode story with underlying arcs throughout the show - keeping you attached all the way through.
Overall: 10/10 - One of the first anime I would recommend to anyone to see.

The journey was a fun one and there was always something going on and the characters were the ones who always shined. The story was good and tended to go in a non episodic format which really worked. Even more impressive were the characters. They were all lovable and had something they were chasing.

This is probably the best anime ever created. If you haven't watched this yet, stop everything make every attempt to do it.
For me, the strongest part of an anime must be the charactors. This show has very strong and likable characters. They have excellent back stories and they seem like they are real people. 
All of the stylistic elements are amazing. I loved the music, the anime and the different variety you get with the story arcs. 
One aspect of this show that I liked was the resolution. There is a part at the end where one of the characters leaves the group. That is
                  kinda sad, but it is life. Some people stay and some go. Also there is a definitely conclusion to this anime. I think that is so healthy and true. Lots of times we get second seasons, but we shouldn't. Tell the story, take the viewers to some fun places and end the series. 
Masterpiece.

Quick take: As the series ages, the artwork begins to feel dated. The series is also episodic and at times can feel tedious to watch, this all pays off in the end as we're treated to several arcs that never converge, but rather run parallel to each other. It's a fun concept and explores the theme "all things must come to an end" in a unique way.
The story follows the members of the "Cowboy Bebop," a cargo ship. In many ways, the story is more about the ships' adventures than the crew currently piloting it. We are treated to four minor character stories and one
                  major story that all explore the concept of "all things must come to an end." What makes this show unique is that the individual stories never really converge, but run in parallel to each other. Every character is exploring their past and coming to terms with it, eventually moving forward.  They all follow the same arc, but in a way that is appropriate to their individual stories. The entire show is about being stuck in life and having to come to terms with some event in the past in order to move forward.
The art work is good for the time period but as time goes on, I'm not so sure it holds the same muster that it used to. That being said, it was a minor point and wouldn't prevent me from watching the show again.
Character development is on point and many of the characters have become easily recognizable inside and outside anime culture.
Music is great, especially if you like bebop.
Overall, if you've waited way to long to see this show or you've just come across it, it's a phenomenal show that although a bit tedious to get through is well worth it in the end. I would suggest once finishing the show, doing a little research on the themes present within as it will help you to appreciate the story all that much more and understand that it may not have been quite as episodic as it seems.

You know when you come across something that's so good, you feel like you'll never find anything else that can live up to it? 
Cowboy Bebop has influenced the Western perception of anime and is one of the most popular, being the entrance to anime made aimed at an older audience for many. Shinichiro Watanabe creatively payed homage to Western pop culture and film tropes, blending various genres, and forming carefully-crafted storylines and fascinating characters. 
Each episode tells a different story with a new bounty to chase; the main storyline slowly develops (as do the characters), still following on from and referencing previous episodes. 
The
                  main group of ragtag bounty hunters are cherished for their pseudo-family dynamic. Spike is a dashing, carefree slacker, haunted by his past. He is often portrayed as cool and laid-back, but there are moments of deep loneliness and melancholy, breaking his apathetic facade. He moves in an effortless, fluid-like motion, which is fascinating to watch during fights. Jet is a former cop, and longtime friend and business partner of Spike's, who is loyal to and is always looking out for the other characters. He reminds me of a dad - he is always fair, reasonable and cares for the others. Faye is a gorgeous but arrogant, self-absorbed, dishonest, sarcastic femme fatale, who has an unstoppable attitude and can often be seen doing nothing whilst the others are working hard. Despite this, she is independent, shooting a gun better than any man. Ed is an energetic, androgynous, strange young girl, as well as an extremely skilled hacker. Ein is a genetically engineered Welsh Corgi. I loved seeing each character's past explored and watching them gradually develop as the series went on. 
Cowboy Bebop is praised for its soundtrack, which uses a variety of genres, most notably jazz, to create a perfect atmosphere. It has my favourite ost out of any film/series I've ever seen, which I still listen to often; some of my favourite songs from it are Gateway, Rush, Bad Dog No Biscuits and Cats on Mars. (Fun fact: I bough a harmonica because of this series.)
The animation is stunning, especially amazing for a 90s anime. Although dull at times, the colours and shading were beautiful. The backgrounds were very detailed and the fight sequences were incredibly entertaining. I especially loved the opening; it's my favourite out of every anime I've ever seen. 
Cowboy Bebop, one of my favourite animes of all time, gave us a masterful mix of different genres, unique characters and enthralling fight sequences. I definitely need to rewatch this one day. 🪐

Cowboy Bebop is the perfect introduction to anime for those who are unfamiliar with where to start. The reason being is that is a perfect representation of multiple genres of what anime has to offer a new viewer. A few examples: Cowboy Bebop more often than not relies on both overtly and subtle humorous moments to carry over serious subplots, the seemingly unforgettable lessons and musings that are unique to each character we are introduced to in the show, while we're speaking of characters- each character is memorable and has a well-defined story you can follow- even in the one-off arcs, and the action that
                  is included in the story line is gripping and fits evenly into the overall plot of the series. It never feels forced or out of place. It moves with the story fluidly.
The animation style of the series is also timeless in my opinion. A lot of people have their preferences of studios and animation style, but Cowboy Bebop doesn't rely on that to carry the show, the art compliments the various tonalities of the series well and has held over time. 
10/10 would recommend for first timers and really, everyone who hasn't gotten around to watching it too.

a little about the history of the series
It follows the adventures of four bounty hunters on board the space ship Bebop. It takes place in space where everyone lives because Earth is basically uninhabitable. Don't let this put you off though. I am not a huge fan of space things and I really did enjoy Cowboy Bebop. The characters on board the Bebop are all memorable and I liked all of them. Cowboy bebop is an excellent anime. Despite being made 20 years ago, its art, animation and sound outpace many modern anime. It does not cave in to anime tropes and because of that, it manages to stand out in the space. However, cowboy bebop is not a masterpiece and it struggles from several fatal flaws.
First of all, it has an episodic structure. This distances it from the traditional arc-focused anime storytelling, giving it uniqueness. However, this format suffers from the fact that individual episodes wont feel as meaningful, since you know in the end there wont be substantial changes to the status quo. 
Also, some
                  of the episodes lag behind in terms of quality. Episodes 7, 10 and 17 in particular didn't do it for me.

this anime is a truly masterpiece from the begining to the end. the soundtrack, the visual, the story and the setting was beautiful. if you want a story about bounty hunter in space with a humor and drama this is your show to watch. the character in this series are written so good that you can related to them or feel their emotion in the series, the art is beatiful it almost perfect except in one episode that to me it feel a bit lazy in the background but overall it great. the soundtrack and sound design is outstanding, there one episode that they didn't
                  use music only sound and somehow it make more epic. the villian in the show are mostly cartonny and comical and other are dangerous insane that can kill a group of people in second without a sweat that it make you think that this guy can kill the main character with no problem. this series have some deep thought on life that to me i can relate it to. overall, the series Cowboy Bebop to me is a 10/10! a truly masterpiece in the anime world and in anime history of how they made the series and many more.

Cowboy Bebop is probably the best representative of top-notch anime in the 90s. Though it is old, its animation is high quality. The storyboarding is outstanding, too, as if every animated frame is like those of Holywood movies. In addition, sound effects and music are pleasing to the ears. The only thing that may have ruined my viewing experience is that most of the episodes follow the traditional television format - that each 20 minute is a standalone story instead of arcs. As someone who used to binge-watch anime, I find it challenging to finish.
Nevertheless, I understand why many anime critics consider this a classic.
                  Set in a dystopian future where the entire solar system becomes a Wild Wild West, Cowboy Bebop is more than an action-packed gun and mecha anime. As each episode unravels different sides of the characters, the whole story is all about four lost souls who end up finding a place to belong in a space-junk wandering in outer space.
However, like the revenue of bounty hunters, the journey they momentarily share is not steady but fleeting. Too bad that our friends can be the family we choose, but when the circumstances will not allow, we have to give up the bonds we formed in pursuit of finding another home -- a place to return to where people are thinking of us. Cowboys Bebop's clever ending reminds us of the attachments we chose to sever, the memories of people we carry in our hearts, and the goodbyes that make us feel empty inside.

This anime is a classic for a reason: the fleshed-out characters, the stylish animation, the perfectly executed action scenes.  I loved the diversity in characters in general, since very few animes seem to show pocs and trans characters as natural parts of the show. The episodic aspect was executed perfectly, and i never found myself disinterested in any of the plot lines - even the more "boring" episodes, like the one where the food infests the ship, are hilarious and fun. I loved the ending of the show, and the mysteries of Spike's flashbacks were incredibly engaging. furthermore, I found the dub in this
                  case particularly fitting, since the show is based on the western cowboy narrative. And Faye is just one of my favorite characters period.
In every sense a must watch.

Cowboy Bebop is one of the most moreish shows out there. It's effortless entertainment. It ticks all the boxes. Amazing script writing, great setting, awesome characters, fantastic plot and a stellar soundtrack. It has super short, impactful episodes which are done in impeccable noir style. You know when everything's said and done at exactly the right moment to the point that it's art? That's what this is to the 10th degree and there's a good use of synchronicity which only adds to its addictive factor- everything's just done so darn well and seamlessly blends together. It has the emotional factor, humour, action, adventure, mystery etc.
                  The setting is massive as its interplanetary and yet many times it feels so small like when Faye bumps into Julia or when they accidentally stumbled upon Ed's father. The show has the benefits of both an extremely vast setting coupled with a small time feel of bumping into people they coincidentally know. I wasn't keen on Faye's extreme sexual objectification- that was the only crummy part for me. I'm also not a fan of space shows- they do nothing for me but I somehow still really liked it. It also helps that space wasn't the setting for a lot of episodes and scenes. If you can get past it you bound to enjoy the highly enjoyable blend of space, cowboys and jazz and really interesting and cool characters.

Reviews if you don't have time.
*SPOILER-FREE*
Some shows can be excused from any form of presentation as that’s the status that “Cowboy Bebop” has in the anime industry as one of the all-time greats. It is an original project animated by studio Sunrise and what a job they did.
As expected from a top-tier show all-around, the animation is very good. From the original and breath-taking backgrounds and different places where the action takes place to the awesome fight scenes with fluid sequences and pace to them, makes “Cowboy Bebop” a very appealing show for the eye. This is also not even referring the amazingly designed and
                  iconic set of characters and machines such as ‘Swordfish II’, the famous red ship belonging to the protagonist, that inspired multiple types of protagonists and support role characters throughout the years.
However, where “Cowboy Bebop” truly shines is when you join this unique cast and unreal and intricate alien-ish landscapes and places with the masterclass writing of the characters and stories. Since this show functions, most of the time, in short stories, that help to complement a major overarching plot that climaxes at the end, these need to be all equally good so that it prevents viewers to lose interest on some and focus only on others. Lucky, “Cowboy Bebop” offers a variety of very interesting and exciting adventures all tied up with amazing dialogues and awesome jazz music.
As one of the most recognizable and innovative shows at the time, “Cowboy Bebop” is in a league of its own in the genre and, with so many qualities, is no wonder it is one of the most loved and better rated series out there.

Probably the greatest experience ever put to screen. Cowboy Bebop genuinely feels like one of the great miracles of all time. Incredibly underrated being ranked 37th on MAL, should be at the top by more than an entire digit. Iv'e watched so many movies, tv shows, and admittedly only around 13 anime, but iv'e experienced plenty of stories.....and at some point i knew.....this is the best thing i'll ever see. I often hear people say that if you rank Bebop highly then you're being pretentious/overly intellectual etc, but honestly i just think the people who are "meh" on this show are simply indifferent to it,
                  rather there being any criticism (at all) that actually holds much weight. Simply improve your life and your attitude and i think pretty much everyone will enjoy this show eventually, even if they don't initially.

Tried writing a short review on one of my favorite anime out there, hope y'all enjoy reading it :3.
Cowboy Bebop is an episodic anime which is highly character driven, it has some of the best main casts out there, where all of our main characters who are unique and driven by their own pasts make the Bebop crew together, which brings for highly enjoyable character dynamics, and makes the characters feel like actual people. The show consists of overarching themes like loneliness and the relationship with one's past and in a lot of cases trying to know oneself more through it. Even the interactions with
                  some temporary side characters in the show have weight to them and, in a way fleshes out both the side characters and main characters without the interactions feeling too forced. The soundtrack in this show is just magnificent and only second to Steins;gate's soundtracks, with beautiful animation even for a 90s show. All in all Cowboy Bebop is this beautifully crafted piece of media which is definitely a top 3 show in my personal books.
