long review short, if you're interested in anime, you should probably watch it just because of how iconic it is. it's my favorite anime and i really could write a five page paper on it (i might even do it don't tempt me)

It's a show that was fantastic, maybe even a perfect storm, for its time.
It had good art and animation. It had a blend of episodic content and a central plot. It had a fairly consistent presentation that took itself seriously, with minimal shifts to off-model or differently-styled art. Amazing, distinct soundtrack. An iconic English dub that was one of the first that could make people seriously consider that dubbing quality could match the original Japanese.
But I think in many ways, modern anime has caught up to or even surpassed Bebop. Many shows get good dubs. Many shows have good OSTs. Many shows have very expressive
                  artwork that sticks to a particular mood. There are shows with better episodic content and there are "background plots" that are told better or more-interwoven throughout the length of the series.
It's not that Bebop aged poorly, but it was just somewhat ahead of its time. If it released today, people would likely complain that most of the episodic storylines were bad, goofy, or forgettable. Let's face it, whenever anyone praises Bebop, it's for the main story episodes, mushroom samba, the fridge episode, and maybe Faye's backstory episode, and that's it. That's less than half of the 24 episodes. People would balk that Faye's sexpot character design is pointless fanservice. Same goes for the bounty hunter TV show where one of the cohosts is a girl not wearing a shirt. People should hate Ed, because Ed is annoying.

I, as a person who likes retro animes Cowboy Bebop is one the great animes for me. It's atmosphere and characters are well written and the musics of that anime, espesically, The Real Folk Blues are splendid. Spike, Jet, Faye, Ed and Ein have their solo stories and with the help of that we learn who they really are and who they were in their past and with that we bond with 5 of them.
But to be honest, I must say that ıt's story isn't great and sometimes I felt that it didn't have an any story and majority of episodes are just fillers, but
                  it isn't too important because in general Cowboy Bebop is perfect.

It is one of the most beloved anime of all time and one watch is enough to prove that it lives up to its praise. All the main characters suffer from the same problem of having to carry the weight of their past no matter what their story is. With an amazing soundtrack,fluid fight scenes and extremely lovable characters who get proper screen time this is a classic and must watch for anime fans. If you wanna give this anime a try but are not sure whether you will like it or not, watch episode 5 named ballad of fallen angels and that would help
                  you make your decision on whether you want to watch it or not.

***SPOILER FREE
One of the great masterpieces, don't miss this groundbreaking anime. If you've never heard of cowboy bebop by now, you might just be missing out. This work of art changed the genre and still heavily influences anime to this day. Very rewatchable too.
Story
The story is episodic but does come together into a real gem. Most of them do delve into the character's backstories and expand on the universe of space cowboy high technology poverty bounty hunting. The story really does a great job of creating a believable, lived in universe where the characters are each trying to get by in their own way.
Art and
                  Sound
Great are and even better sound. My god the sound. Even if you don't like jazz it really gives life to the action and the audio couldn't be better. You might find yourself listening to the music after the series is over.
Overall
A true classic and if you haven't seen it already, please do. Anime might not get much better than this.

I'll be honest, this series is a bit overrated.
I began watching this anime with an unbelievably high expectations after getting recommended by so many people and seeing an 8.7 rating on MAL. Well for me the show is amazing but not really perfect as others describe.
What stands out for me most is how every episode brought a new story and finished it in the span of 20 minutes. There were no cliffhangers, no prolonged plot, and each of them were enjoyable.
The retro sci-fi art style and animation is also something to feast for the eye. Character movements are so smooth even when they interact with
                  objects, gunfights and space ship battles are exciting to watch, everything felt so alive. Even compared to an average anime at the present, Cowboy Bebop's animation is still top notch.
Overall I give it a 9/10
[SPOILERS AHEAD]
However I did not like how it ends. The crew was already over the moment Spike left for battle, and Ed and Ein walked away before the final arc. Jet being alone again with only his ship is super depressing for me.
Not to mention the fact that everything happened because Spike went after a woman that was already in a relationship(I loathe NTR). Personally I'd rather ship Spike with Faye but that ain't gonna happen.

This series is a meteoric (heh get it?) success. It is a classic among classics for most and if you haven't given it a chance I would urge you to do so. 
Cowboy Bebop brought anime to the west in a way no other series had done at the time of it's release. Airing on Adult Swim with a fantastic dub gave western fans a chance to witness a classic on broadcast television. In 2001. The significance of that can easily be taken for granted to contemporary fans of seasonal anime today. I wish I could have seen it. 
Some of the most memorable quotes,
                  pastiches', lines, meme formats, and callbacks in modern anime can be found in this series. That novelty alone is worth your time. 
Cowboy Bebop has been written about ad nauseum but it has stood the test of time. Give it a shot will ya?
-See you Space Cowboy

This is a fantastic series. It has many flaws, some of which are quite significant, but the overall composure of the entire show make up for them. 
This anime, IMO, quite possibly has the best sound track to any anime ever, hell, one of the best soundtracks to any show ever. It's excellently composed and thought out to match the show in its various parts. The genres of music included is impressively extensive and majority of the songs are easily good enough to be produced without association to the show. 
Anyway- What really shines about this anime? The characters and their stories. Their past. Their
                  lives. We see a variety of lessons taught through the show; we see what type of actions cause consequence. We see raw ambition, we see arrogance, we see revenge, and more. But what's important is how it's all dealt with. That's where this show shines.
The most prevalent lesson the series teaches is not to let your past dictate your future. You can learn from your past, but don't let it dominate you and consume you never to escape until it might be too late. They do an excellent job of teaching the lessons to be learnt in the show, so I'll leave my summery at that. 
The main characters of this show are extremely unique and intriguing. From the start, you see so many different aspects and possible avenues of history for each of them. They each have their mysteries, but the questions don't overwhelm you so as that it could drown out other enjoyable aspects, but everything is answered when the time is right.
Alright alright alright, you just want an action show though, I get it. Yeah it's pretty good at that, and if that's all you're looking for than the show's flaws won't be as meaningful to you. The combat in this show is excellent, and when paired with the excellent music, makes for thrilling action sequences. 
Alright imma get into the issues now. First off, it's way too episodic. I'm aware this is a popular complaint, but I genuinely believe this show would be better as a whole if they trimmed it down and focused more on the story aspect. Don't get me wrong, I generally don't have an issue with episodic shows, but in this instance I feel like the main story could have used a greater focus. 
This issue isn't exactly aided by the first episode, which kind of throws off the idea and plot of the show, especially to a casual watcher. The beginning gives the impression that the rest of the show is likely to focus on the same plot as the first episode, but in reality the show is largely made up of different plots in each episode. This area may be more subjective though, that's just what I felt the first time I watched it. 
It also needs a little more hand to hand combat as a whole. What's in the show is definitely some of the most well done human-human animated combat I've seen, but I wish there was more. There's only like three, four proper fight scenes throughout the series and I was left craving more by the end. 
The show has a lot of other issues as well, but most of them are present in most anime as a whole so I won't bother picking them out as they don't really detract from the show much. 
Conclusion: watch the show. Unless you're the type who exclusively likes slice of life rom-coms and the such, you'd probably enjoy it. It has valuable lessons to learn. 
Thanks for reading my review

¿What is the meaning of the past in one's life? ¿How can we hide from the ruins that will always dance in front of us? 
"Winter song
watercolors of the death
the longing of sand
It's to know if am alive."
And the weight, how can someone carry it without being sunk it by it, remaining human and joyful at the same time...
The series is a masterpiece, for me was slow to watch, but that was good, because that's what real art does, to make us stop to contemplate truth even if we will never know what it really is. It is a very valuable fragment of human expression,
                  I don't want to say to much more, but really are very few anime series with that profound search for something.
The music is so melancholic, and the animation of chapters like "Pierrot Le fou" with all those shadows makes you feel so heavy. In every chapter you are going to be surprised by new textures and harmonies, and if you listen well to them, they will accompany you for a long time.
The world all the things, they seem like a very special gift, one to walk with, the wind, and to vanish like you were never there.
-I'm not going there to die. I'm going to find out if I'm really alive...

This is the first review I have ever written, so please bear with it. 
[TLDR] Cowboy Bebop is a masterpiece that gets better every time you watch it; however, it is not without its flaws. 
Context: 
  You can skip this context if you want, as I am trying to keep it separate from the review as much as possible. That said I think context is extremely important when it comes to reviews of older anime shows.
  I first watched Cowboy Bebop on adult swim as a kid. It was by no means the first anime series I watched, but it was one
                  of the first shows that really made me want to actively look for more anime. It opened my mind to shows like Beck which was also airing on TV at the time. I feel the context that Cowboy Bebop was a profoundly effective gateway anime is, and should always be, recognized. The industry would not be the same without it, but I do not believe this context should have a say on the rating of a show. A show isn't good just because a lot of people like it. This is the same for every other show too. A lot of people try and convince people to watch Cowboy Bebop while talking about it with rose colored glasses filled with nostalgia. For me, however, it was not always my favorite show. It earned that title by having by far the most re-watch value of any show I have watched - ever. I wasn't going to write a review, but I feel like the lack of ability to critique it properly is harming the the community's view of the show.  
  I don't care if everyone likes the shows, games, or media I enjoy. I do not expect everyone to like everything I do, but I want people to understand why the show is an enduring masterpiece even if they don't like it. I have very specific tastes, but I am capable of understanding that some shows are great shows even if, for instance, I did not enjoy them due to finding the main characters extremely disagreeable.  
Cons: 
  Please stop trying to convince people to watch the show because of the dub quality. The dub was great when it came out, but it is only of passable quality now. The writing for the dialog of the show does not stand up to the test of time as well as people would like to imagine it does. There are often moments in the show where the dialog can feel "canned". This is, in-part, due to mediocre writing, but also due to the lower standard of dubs of the time. Too often are characters speaking what should be internal monologs or should not be said at all as it is effectively shown without dialog. There are also issues with pacing and emotiveness. Sometimes there are stark contrasts in the voice acting quality of the side characters compared to the main cast, leaving what would have been perfectly good writing also feeling canned. The show is also far more dialog heavy than people seem to remember, perpetuating this further. I believe all of this ends up being a major problem when people new to the show view it for the first time, as their expectations are not met. 
 The older art style, not quality, can also be viewed as a con. It doesn’t hold up to modern aesthetical preferences but that does not mean it is bad. I did not detract any points for this as I do not believe the quality is bad.
Characters & Story [10]:
  In my experience, a lot of people struggle with the episodic nature of Cowboy Bebop, and this is understandable as it has become less and less common in modern anime. There is an overarching plot to the show, but the driving force behind the show is the character development. There is a catch to this, however, as much of the character development for the main cast (particularly the male members) has already taken place before the events of the show. On top of conventional character development, you get to know the characters and what made them who they are in a way that is akin to getting to know people in real life. The viewer pieces together information about their pasts with new insight from each new adventure.  Cowboy Bebop has some of the most endearing and enduring characters of any anime out there, largely because of how you get to know the characters in this way. Just as in real life, some of them are a little annoying at first but grow on you as you get to know who they really are. 
Soundtrack [10]:
  For those that are openminded musically the soundtrack to the show is one of the best out there. Enough people have talked about it so I won’t dive deeply into it, but I would like to say that it is also used extremely effectively. Sometimes it feels like you are watching a passionate fan's AMV just because of how much weight the music has on the moment. 
Art [10]:
  While there are elements of the art that don't hold up well to modern aesthetical preferences, overall, the art is very well done. It really shines when it comes to the animated action scenes which remain some of the best to this day. 
Re-watch Value [10]:
  I have re-watched the show at least 6 times in the last decade, and every time I do I find something more to appreciate. I have pretty good memory, so I often struggle to re-watch shows because I already know what is going to happen, and much of the details, and I find myself uninterested in so much of what is going on because I already know so much about it. I never had this issue with Cowboy Bebop, and its ability to keep me entertained time and time again is what makes it my favorite. 
Conclusion: 
  It is one of the best anime of all time, but it isn't something that everyone will enjoy. Don't overhype yourself when getting into it, and don't overhype your friends when trying to get them to watch it, as it will only serve to detract from their opinions of the show.

-- REAL FOLKS BLUE --
I`m a little too late with this review (decades late in fact). I had started the show nearly two months ago and was really taking my time with it. There was so much too discover and take in. I didn`t plan on writing a review, but suddenly felt the urge to do so after completing it. The anime has just so much greatness and history to it that I can`t let it go by and I wanted to write this review for my own sake. Because WOW! This anime is just otherworldly mesmerizing. If that makes sense. 
Before starting the anime,
                  I wasn`t sure what to expect. And as I started watching it, the anime kept evolving. And what`s amazing is it never lost it`s flavor every episode was just as equally good if not better. I will completely avoid spoilers, not just for the story but for the anime. Cowboy Bebop is best watched with zero insights. So here, I`ll just be talking about what I found most unique about the anime and why i fell in love with it.  
Among it`s many incredible things these are a few which stood out for me:
-The style of the anime. It`s mix of 90`s music and art-style gives the world so much personality. But the most unique thing is it`s music and how it is incorporated in the show. Written by Yoko Kanno, the music is among the best in the entire anime industry. It`s is a unique take on Jazz, with beautiful tracks. This anime won`t work this well without it`s OST. The director masterfully choose the right song, at the right time, for the right duration. 
There is so many people who I know who said that they fell in love with sci-fic, jazz, and animes because of cowboy bebop. The style of the anime stands out the most and leaps on to you. 
-The other thing which I immediately noticed was it`s unique way of storytelling. While other similar shows (especially sci-fic) would focus on the world, governmental figures, the law, morality, Cowboy Bebop focuses primarily on the character and only gives you the gist of the situation. It would want you to think about the characters motivations, past and fates. Something I deeply respect as it makes you more invested in the show. While this design has it`s problems, it`s something which greatly works in cowboy Bebop`s favor. It is able to lean heavily on it`s music and incredible writing to deliver incredible meaningful story arcs and closure. The entire anime is character focused, with everything building up the character and their ultimate story closure. 
-The last thing is the writing. Cowboy bebop reminded me who it felt to be surprised and joyed at the same time. The animes contains incredible and unique characters. And that includes everyone, not just the main character. Every episode will introduce a new character who will have a unique aspect to it. The anime will build up the entire episode and then drop a emotional or jaw-dropping reveal at the end. And none of it fells out of place. None of the episodes felt filler. Each was masterfully done and the level of writing never dropped. 
And all of these three things come together to create a work of art. An experience you`ll never forget and one which you will carry with you.
COWBOY BEBOP is one of a kind anime. It is something which fells genuine and unique, and I know I been saying that word a lot, but it truly is that. It feels like lightening in a bottle. There is no piece of entertainment media which aims to do what it does. It`s something which I would give my first 11/10. It`s that good to me. 
Cowboy Bebop is one of the best animes ever made, and THE most unique anime ever made (and yes I`ll die on that hill). 
THANKS FOR READING. I HOPE YOU ENJOYED IT. GOODBYE.
-- SEE YOU IN SPACE, COWBOY --

While I agree that Cowboy Bebop is far from flawless and perhaps doesn't deserve the mythical status it has obtained, I can't fathom why anyone would ever knock the music!?
I see so many reviews that didn't even mention that each episode is named after a song, and that music itself is so much a part of the overarching mythos of the show.
Yoko Kanno is arguably the best composer in the world right now.  She can write any genre (she can change genres like most people change a t-shirt) and composed/orchestrated ALL the music for the show.  
The theme song, "Tank!" is the only
                  jazz standard to ever come out of Japan, and has been performed by the most prestigious of US military bands for the President at the White House.  If there is other anime music that has recieved such a prestigious performance I would sure like to know.

I feel like I can sum up this review in five words: "It's fucking Cowboy Bebop, dude."
But that's lazier than Cowboy Bebop, frankly, deserves.
An absolute watershed, iconic piece of animation - of, frankly, television with no genre or medium boundaries - Cowboy Bebop is one of the most beloved, respected, and cherished pieces of anime television, and I'd say especially in the US.  And that kind of makes sense.  When put against its piers, Cowboy Bebop is one of the least "anime" of anime.  It's a story that could be told in a lot of different mediums - in, really, a lot
                  of different genres, as you could pare away a ton of the sci-fi, planet-hopping trappings and be left with an almost identical piece of storytelling that would lose very little.  This makes it commonly peoples' first anime, at least away from something like Pokemon or even Dragonball Z or Sailor Moon that feels, at times, like "just a cartoon" to a childhood audience, whereas Cowboy Bebop is clearly something removed into a new genre, and a new world.  No wonder it's so often recommend as a good intro-anime for people who aren't into the medium, since you don't have to put up with the wacky fanservice and distended faces and bizarre anime trope-isms that litter the medium, and look, a lot of that stuff is great, but it can be pretty goddamn impenetrable and off-putting to an outsider.
That being said, Cowboy Bebop doesn't run away from its medium, or its sci-fi genre.  It can exist safely and strongly without them, but that's a comment on its strength of narrative, character, and restraint, not a condemnation of the other elements.  Cowboy Bebop uses its medium deftly, better than most, to build a stunning moody, gripping, cohesive universe.  Later works like Firefly owe themselves to Bebop's sense of realistic sci-fi, and it's something that stands up with the original Star Wars as a lived-in, decaying, authentic world where space travel simply exists, and it doesn't feel glossy and unrealistic, but simply a part of life.  The starships and such of CB exist in the same plane as the heavily graffiti'd subway trains of our modern world, comparable to our time where air travel is commonplace and mundane, even frustrating, in a way that would be mind-blowing to those from a century before.
There are few worlds that really feel as cohesive as Bebop's, to both itself - a world that lives and breathes and exists and never feels like the fiction is pulling at its own seams, or barely painting over the rough edges that no one stopped to think about - but also to its story.  While you could drop the crew of the Bebop into 1930s New York or 1960s Shanghai or modern LA and not have to change a ton about it to make it work, this is a world perfectly suited to its cynical, jaded, wandering bounty hunters.
And what a cast they are.  Spike, Faye, Jet, and Ed are simply four of the most iconic faces in anime - a stunning 90s anti-hero who works as what an anti-hero should be, not just a gritty and violence asshole, but a man who is deeply flawed, mysterious, cynical, but driven by a good heart and an ugly past that is compelling without being exploitative; a femme fatale lead who is one of the most beloved women in anime, not just for her stunning looks but the depth of her charm, her broken bird charisma, the heart breaking reality of what being Faye Valentine is against the sensuous image she portrays; the grizzled right-hand man, who stands as the perfect balance for Spike, a fully defined and fully realized character in his own right that could easily shoulder the weight of his own narrative, and gets to on a number of episodic occasions; and even Ed, who seems at first like she's going to be your standard wacky comedy teenager, but has so much more to offer and say, with one of the most touching character send-offs I've seen in a long time.
And, look, there's this modern opinion that Cowboy Bebop has been deemed some unassailable classic that you're not allowed to say anything bad about, and maybe that's true, a bit.  It does have its fervent defenders.  And it should.  It's an unassailable classic like the Godfather is, frankly, or Citizen Kane - a movie I personally don't like, but can at least see the potent strengths in.  Hell, I don't like Final Fantasy 7 or Seinfeld, either, and I still know they're both genre defining classics.  That's what Cowboy Bebop is.
Is it perfect?  No.  The episodes can sometimes feel meandering, an episodic piece that is more interested in mood and philosophy than a defined arc or story.  If you're looking for a complete, coherent, satisfying narrative, Cowboy Bebop is not going to scratch that itch, more than likely, because it isn't interested in trying.  Bebop wants to tell you a story about who people are, about what redemption and atonement mean, about how your past defines you, or doesn't, about what it means to step away from the ghosts that haunt you, or revisit those haunted places and understand what's become of them.  You have to be willing to put in the work and peel back the layers to fully appreciate a show like this, and I don't say that to imply that people who don't like it are watching it "Wrong" or "don't get it" or, even worse, aren't smart enough to.  Sometimes you just don't click with things.  Sometimes you don't want media that forces you to do your homework and rewatch it again and again to get the full picture and appreciation.  Sometimes a show, or a book, or a game, or whatever should just be what it is, and can be perfect as what it is, without needing to be studied and dissected.
But Cowboy Bebop isn't one of those.  It's an ambitious, weighty, mature narrative, one that has stood the test of tine, with animation and visual and music and really every production metric you could hope for standing the test of time like it rolled out this week.  Bebop did one of the best things that any piece of media could do: it knew exactly what it wanted to be, on every level, embraced that style fully, and did everything it could to make it work.
Cowboy Bebop isn't perfect.  Nothing is.  To paraphrase a famous anime villain, perfection is the enemy of any scientist, or artist for that matter.
But goddamn, it gets pretty close.

Cowboy Bebop is an outstanding anime that still holds up to this day. The story is quiet different to what I am usually used to, where it does not follow a strict story line to reach a final destination, but an anime that consists of small different plots that involves bounty hunting, and in turn has some correlation to the overall storyline. Even with all of the depressing features to the show, the characters are able to get by with a smile on their faces even during troublesome situations. In the grand scheme of things, the story involves the impossibility to let go of the
                  past and the pointless efforts to find out if you are truly alive or just stuck in a dream. Is anything really real? Even with the illustrated view of a future, dystopian society, it really got me staring up at my ceiling late at night contemplating life just because of an anime. Made me feel like I was staring at a mirror for 26 episodes. But, then again... whatever happens, happens.

Critical: A masterclass in animation, music, character personality, English dubbing, and style. 
This is an overall consistent, timeless show with a few stragglers here and there, but plenty of fun (and serious) scenarios.
Personal: Although the series is structured episodically, each scenario is so distinct from each other, offering a package of genres, atmospheres, and movie-like progressions. And yet, everything feels coherent: the main cast is witty, charming, and real (in part by the amazing English dub); the animation still stands as one of the best I've seen, especially with dynamic actions scenes from fists, guns, to spaceships; the jazz music hits hard and often feels
                  involved with the scenario at hand.
While there is no central story at hand--a bombastic science fiction plot that could mean the end of the universe--the series carefully drops bits and pieces of these characters' pasts and motivations, developing these characters at a slow, low-key manner. If you're more inclined for stories that are more straightforward with character growth and overarching narratives, then this series may offer a change of pace. That is not to say the main cast is dry or bland; rather, we are observing them from a perspective where the most significant points of their lives have already past. Learning about that past is one of the most enjoyable aspects of this series.
Are there a few scenarios that miss the mark? Yes. Do I wish that the main cast could be explored further? Yes. But as it is, even after 20 years, Cowboy Bebop's vast variety of scenarios and animation makes it an easy recommendation for newcomers and anyone else looking for something a little unconventional.

At first, I was recommended this show from a friend of mine. He said it was very good and that I'd love it. I was skeptical at first. Sure, I've heard of this show, but is it all it's hyped up to be? Does it deserve the praise it gets? To find out, I simply watched the series. Now, that I'm done, I can finally give my answer.
Firstly, I'd be remiss to not mention how much I love the premise of the show. A space western with a rag tag group of bounty hunters exploring the solar system is done amazingly well. The potential a
                  show like that has is utilizes every aspect of it's world here. Each plot, while not really connected to each other, fully explores the concepts set up and gives plenty of opportunities to build character.
Speaking of which, I found myself falling in love with every character. Each one of them is defined by their past and we get to explore that, understanding how these characters got to where they are by the time of the show. The amount of great character building is mind blowing and left me immensely satisfied. The characters at their core aren't that complex, but get fleshed out as the series carries on, giving us their perspectives, and allowing the world to become more three dimensional. From the first episode, these characters are relatable in their motives and actions, and yet we see them do things quite literally out of this world. I found myself becoming emotionally invested in each character, and found each character moment great. 
On that topic, I should talk about the writing. Each episode, while separate from each other, only works in the show's favor. We see more and more of this universe and the people inside of it. While conceptually, this seems far out, the show does a fantastic job at grounding everything and making it feel realistic in a lot of ways. For example, Jet passing Spike a cigarette using zero gravity. While very minor, it's a moment I love because it makes sense in context of the world. It feels like the characters have lived here and know everything about the world, like we're just looking at a moment.
The plot of each episode is also very tight and well done. The stories are short, but wrap up in a satisfying way at the end of each episode. It never feels rushed, and instead feels like each action in the episode lead to a natural conclusion. We get to see a few characters and locations get explored and by the end, there are no loose threads. Because of that, each episode is wholly focused on making our characters consistent and our plot logical. That is the show's best strength. Giving us an interesting concept with a logical plotline. Our characters act completely in character, and make decisions that follow that. Because of that, we get satisfying payoffs because of the logical through line.
I'd be remiss not to mention the music. Every single song underscores the action perfectly, and gets us in the mood of the scene. The theme alone gets this section a ten, but every other song is great too. 
One other thing I love is the animation, It's amazingly expressive for the characters. I found myself looking at shots a few times to see all of the character's reactions simply because of the entertainment I'd get seeing how creative the animators got at expressing emotion. The settings also look phenomenal. Each cityscape and planet feel lived in and full of character. Some of them would make great wallpapers simply from how much is in them. 
So, now that I've got my thoughts out, do I think this show is good? Absolutely. It's the best anime I've had the pleasure of seeing with some of the best characters in media period. The setting alone got me hooked, but I stayed for the character interactions and tight plotlines. I'd highly recommend watching it and, if it's been a few years, watch it again. You won't be disappointed.

*don't take this to heart on this review- I just want to spill my love towards this anime*
Cowboy Bebop is something I grew up with my Dad and I have a sentimental bond to it. Ever since I was a baby my dad would play the OST in the car and I just became very attached to it since. Fast forward when I'm 14, I watched it for the first time and immediately fell in love with the anime.
This only strengthened my emotional bond with the anime. As it reminds me of my Dad and our bond together, and also my early childhood as it
                  brings so much nostalgia. The OST my Dad introduced to me from the beginning is the reason why I fell in love with jazz music and big band concerts. Also the reason why I got into music in general. 
I thank my Dad for introducing Cowboy Bebop- as it means a lot to me,  making this anime special.

Cowboy Bebop was like one of the original anime to come on adult swim back in the early 2000s. It basically was the pioneer of anime to get me into anime, but that was probably yu yu hakusho. But, anyway, that's a different anime entirely. I loved the non-stop action that cowboy bebop is just as I thought it would be, packed with action and with some additional added comedy, it makes for the semi-perfect anime with at first confusing backstory of all the main characters, at least that's what I thought while first watching it. But, it slowly sucks you in, you know, kinda
                  like a black hole or whatever. I enjoyed it, but I cannot say the same for others. But, what I like most is the graphics I miss how these types of graphics used to be. Now it's all cell-shaded. Which I don't particularly care for. I urge anyone especially the tide pod generation who are born from 1996 onward to watch this anime. Instead of basic anime like naruto or tokyo ghoul.

Cowboy Bebop is one of my favorite anime and still to this day one of the only anime titles that I can rewatch consistently and never get tired of.  The artwork is fantastic, the english dubbing on it is quite possibly one of the best to ever do it, the soundtrack is second to none, the entirety of the show isn't too long or short and the story is amazing.  The rag tag crew of bounty hunters has been done a thousand times but this feels different and feels real.  It feels like so many genres melded into one.   Scenes
                  transition from laugh out loud comedy, gritty action, to soul crushing sadness making sure you can relate as we experience all of this in our day to days.  I feel it's almost a commentary on loneliness at times based on all of the characters.  No love, no identity, no parents.  All forced to come together as a family but destined to break apart.  There is no filler but episodes like Toys in the Attic  where something is hunting the crew provide an interesting transition from some of the hard hitting themes and thus the order of the episodes is crafted brilliantly.

Cowboy Bebop is one of those classics that everyone talks about. The perfect "gateway anime" that gives you an idea of some of the fun to be had in this weird and wonderful medium.
The first thing to blow me away about Bebop is just the sheer quality in nearly every aspect of it's production. From the well-developed, likable-yet-flawed characters, jazzy foot-tapping music and beautifully gritty animation, all the way to the inventiveness of the stories concocted for each individual "session". 
Some things that are important to know before going in: While the show is told in a linear way, this is very much an anthology
                  series. The majority of the episodes are stand-alone, with only a few connecting into an over-arching story. If you go into this expecting a long, brilliantly-told story over 26 episodes (like me) you will be disappointed. Most of the episodes work as stand-alone stories, with the main cast rarely bringing up prior events.
Despite this, each session brings with it a new and exciting story that pays homage to one genre or another, the love of which the creators express with full granduer.
Another thing. The cast, making up the crew of the Bebop, don't change much throughout the series. They don't overcome their individual flaws and "progress" like characters in other popular shows. This doesn't really matter though, as each of the crew are charismatic and effortlessly cool in their own way and watching them bounce off each other is a joy to behold. 
While I won't say much on the last few episodes to allow viewers to go in as blind as possible, (this is a *very* spoilable show) I will say that the ending is brilliantly executed and will stick with you long after the final credits have rolled. 
You're gonna carry that weight.

A western (in the cowboy sense) with a metric boat load of western elements (in the European sense). Watching this in dub would have certainly emphasised this element of the anime for me, but this was fine by me. This is a great homage to Westerns, Film Noir, and all of the other genres they decided to blend together to make this fantastic show.
The world, or should I say universe, set in the near future with space colonization and a desolate Earth, is pretty intriguing. I found myself googling about it a fair bit when watching the show, but I will admit it's a fairly
                  straightforward universe.
The story has an overarching plot which is slowly revealed in the process of the show. Whilst it comes off at times as a generic villain of the week show, there is more than meets the eye, and even if the villain doesn't relate to the main plot, it usually brings out elements of the main characters you haven't seen before. I suppose the second episode about the dog was kind of lame, but honestly I still enjoyed it a lot.
Spike, Jet Black, Faye Valentine, Edward and the dog all contribute well to the story, the first three in particular. The emotional depth to these characters is astonishing, even if the show is stingy with the details. It almost demands you to pay attention to get little tidbits of information, and by the end of the show you have what I would consider a satisfying fix on the characters. I like the conclusions of the story arcs these characters face, they are perfect in a sense.
This is all not to mention the damn catchy intro. And it just looks so aesthetically pleasing, and is such a ridiculously perfect fit for what the show is about. I'm glad they didn't swap the opening with another mid-way through the show, I'm assuming this was before the time anime creators decided to swap the intros to their shows every 12 episodes or so.
I think the only factors stopping this show from being perfect to me would be the occasional lackluster episodes, sometimes forgettable villain/characters of the week, and sometimes the slow pacing does get a little boring for my taste, even if it is done excellently most of the time. Also Edward was kinda eh and I think brevity in the show could have been added another way, or with a better character. But I found her origins and original locality very cool.
This is a must watch, not just for anime fans but I think fans of television, movies and other forms of media generally speaking. You need to see Cowboy Bebop, it's a strong 9/10 for me.

Cowboy Bebop is one of those special shows has risen beyond a limited audience to become a cultural icon, being incredibly popular not only with eastern audiences, but with western ones as well, thanks to the heavy inspiration it draws from western media and pop culture. Even after over two decades it has a dedicated cult following and is lauded as not only one of the greatest anime of all time, but one of the best TV shows in general. So, does Cowboy Bebop live up to its incredible reputation? My answer: Yes and no. 
Let's start with the basic premise of the show. Cowboy
                  Bebop is a sci-fi western, following the adventures of a ragtag group of bounty hunters that travel across space, trying to make a living for the future while dealing with their dark pasts. It is primarily episodic, with most episodes consist of the gang trying to nab a bounty while dealing with the problems and misadventures that are thrown their way. There is a bit of an overarching plot, but out of the 26 total episodes, only about 5 of them actually focus on it, at the beginning, middle, and very end. Each of the characters have their own individual stories that are gradually revealed over the course of the show, with each of them having a resolution by the end. Most episodic shows usually go down the slice-of-life/light-hearted route, so it's definitely interesting to see it done with a more serious setting and story. However, the real question is whether or not it truly works, and honestly, I don't think it does. 
The problem with Cowboy Bebop is that it has a lack of focus and originality. Many episodes simply consist of a random adventure the crew happens to bumble their way into, most of them lacking any kind of meaningful development or insight into the plot or any of the characters. What's more, there were many plot holes and inconsistencies, to the point where it got almost frustrating. Stakes and problems that would carry over between episodes were almost nonexistent. Many of these plotlines were basically ripped from lots of famous movies and TV shows as well, as it tries to pay homage to western media. Entire episodes could have been removed and there would have been zero impact to the overall experience. To be really blunt, a lot of it was simply boring and uninteresting. 
Most of the episodes that I DID enjoy were the ones that focused on the overarching story or at least had some kind of focus to them, such as giving more info about a character's past. However, they mostly took place in the second half of the show, and were outnumbered by the mediocre episodes. Out of 26 entire episodes, I would say I only truly enjoyed maybe 10 of them, and these were mostly in the second half of the show.
The frustrating thing is that the show is very good when it really tries to push things along, especially when it comes to the characters. While a bit tropey, they are genuinely interesting and well-written. The slow-burn pacing and revealing of their pasts gives the show a mysterious and compelling quality. The banter between them was one of the most enjoyable parts of the whole show. The fact that the show neatly wrapped their arcs together at the end makes the climactic conclusion even better. I also appreciated what it did thematically, as there's a great underlying message of moving on from the past and looking towards the future. 
Onto what's probably the best aspect of the show: the audio and visuals. For a 90's show, the animation is genuinely amazing and incredibly fluid. Action scenes are fast and dynamic, and there's a lot of great visual directing in general. The setting is incredibly unique and interesting, and is compounded by a very nice soundtrack. It creates a great aesthetic that almost makes the show worth watching purely for the spectacle of it. 
Ultimately, Cowboy Bebop is a show that has a lot of charm and objectively good qualities, but has many glaring flaws that really bog down the experience. It has great audio and visuals, and a truly interesting cast of characters, which are unfortunately subjected to mostly directionless and boring plotlines that make the show feel like a chore to watch. It's a bit painful, as I really feel that it was really hampered from being as good as it could have been. 
All that being said, I would still say that Cowboy Bebop is worth a watch. It's a genuinely unique experience that has something to appeal to everybody, especially if you're a fan of western media. Just try to appreciate it for visuals and characters, not for its story.

Cowboy Bebop is one of the most appraised animes ever, people call it the best anime of all time, the best piece of media they have ever seen. Sure, it's nice, I liked it, it's enjoyable, it's pretty good if I must say, but extremely overrated.
Basically, Cowboy Bebop is from how I've understood it a slice of life that implemented a storyline within characters. And with it being a slice of life I can't rate it a 10, because the genre itself is undeserving of a 10 since it's purely for enjoyment. And now, the story was implemented... fine? Faye's stroy was amazing, I was
                  blown away by how well it was done, Jett's was great too, Ed's story almost wasn't there but it really wasn't a problem since Ed was purely comic relief, and here's where the problem comes. Spike's story was done really poorly. Faye had a progressing story that was extremely enjoyable and kept you hooked, while Spike was just randomly meeting vicious and doing nothing.
Characters were amazing, there were no one-dimensional characters, and Spike is definitely one of my favorite MC's, he's really charming. The episodes were pretty fun, the ideas were pretty creative and interesting.
So in conclusion: Cowboy Bebop is a great show that's worth watching, but it's overrated. It's a slice of life that tried implementing a story within characters and succeeded for the most part. So... just watch it, you won't regret it.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS MANY SPOILERS
Watching Cowboy Bebop feels like drinking a nice cold beer after a hard day at work. You can just sit back and relax while watching octane-powered chases and action scenes along with great jazz music.
The story goes like this: we follow the misadventures of Spike Spiegel and Jet Black, broke bounty hunters aboard the Bebop in a futuristic sci-fi context. There is no complex plot to wrap your head around -- we naturally and effortlessly learn more about the past of our beloved main characters along the anime as they partner up with the amnesiac femme fatale Faye Valentine, orphan whiz
                  kid Radical Edward and the genetically-modified dog Ein.
Spike is our action man, a non-womanizing version of James Bond. His spontaneity and dry humor more than make up for his lack of flirting, though. A prolific thief with unparalleled agility, his weapons of choice are pistols and martial arts. Thankfully, his agility is no carte blanche for every challenge of his, as he often gets shot and hurt along the anime... his unpretentious walk always gets me. Contrasting with Spike, Jet is a behind the scenes techie who acts as support, identifies their next targets and makes sure every runs smoothly. Jet has a friend in every corner of galaxy, which makes viewers wonder about his past as the episodes advance.
Interestingly, the crew of the Bebop present a truly chaotic sense of justice, in the sense of D&D. Sometimes, they do not seem to care about, or even understand, the impact of their actions. Consequently, they downplay their role in the fate of humanity in galaxy.
Other times, their personal lives conflict with their pursuit of money, which leads to nice ethical dilemmas. This is the means through which we learn more about our beloved misfits. Since I chose not to care about how much I am spoiling here, why not reveal all my thoughts? The relation with the past is a major theme in Cowboy Bebop. The decisions and personal lives of the crew of the Bebop reveal different ways to deal with the past: we may run from it, we may chase it, we may be forced to face it or perhaps we may want to chase it -- yet it might not explain the present anymore!
The icing on the cake is the ambiance of Cowboy Bebop. There is zero political correctness -- cigarettes and drug trafficking are all over the place, exactly as they were in wild west movies. Gory scenes are always to be expected... and even ones which hint at sex. Maybe I am just too used to western-style clean movies, yet it is just refreshing to see an anime which does not try to hide it all. At first, it seemed to me that the sexual tension with Faye was underplayed. On a second moment, I realize it was better like this: the "born sexy yesterday" trope is already present on Faye Valentine -- an emphasis on sexual tension with her would inevitably lead to boob jokes or male-centered fan-service. (so kudos to the producers for not having fallen in such pitfall)
For a sci-fi anime, the incoherent mix of technologies used by the characters would feel contradictory -- maybe even nonsensical -- if noticed anywhere else: pistols and machine-guns are the weapons of choice, while we see more futuristic guns in spaceships and occasional missile launchers. If there is anything sacred here, it is its aesthetics: this anachronic mix is dosed gracefully as to the cultural significance certain guns are endowed with. This seemingly incoherent mix... it just works. As for the revolvers, this is an anime about (space) cowboys, after all...
The way I look at it, Cowboy Bebop is a must-see for any otaku young and old, period. Why restrict it to otakus? It simply is a must-see. It contains iconic scenes of anime as a genre, pays homage to several pop-culture icons and references classical scenes of movies.
To finish, Cowboy Bebop has earned its legendary status without relying on a 2deep4u plot crutch justification. To be fair, Cowboy Bebop is not just a nice cold beer. It is a fine whisky.

Cowboy Bebop is one of those series that is just impossible to criticize, it has fans who will defend it. And I think that's okay, because this anime is masterpiece.
We follow two bounty hunters Spike Spiegel and Jet, who own a ship called the Bebop. They travel the Solar system, chasing wanted criminals to earn money. In later episodes they pick up 2 women. Faye Valentine and computer genius Edward (yes, Edward is female).
Each episode brings about a new bounty which they chase after.

This show is MUST WATCH. I highly recommend

One of the best shows EVER.

Cowboy Bebop is a good anime, with incredible animation, even more for the time it was made and the soundtrack is just fantastic.
It's an episodic anime, that is, each episode is a different story, that makes 6 or 7 episodes really important (I'm not saying that the other episodes are bad). The development of the characters is very simple, it tells you the basics of the characters, it makes it look like at the end of the anime that you still don't know the characters.
The construction of the world is very good, it is indeed a very interesting universe and it seems to be cool
                  to live there.
The anime also deals with very interesting philosophical subjects
It has a good timing of humor and the ending is good
I recommend!

This anime is in that realm of if you watch anime AT ALL, you have seen this. Especially if you were born between 1980 and 1990. This show was on Adult Swim along with Fullmetal and Trigun. It was the first anime that I watched that I truly felt was something special. Like, I felt cool watching it. If I told someone I watched it, they wouldn't think I was a weird weeby nerd in highschool. At that time in most peoples lives, what others thought about you was perceived to be important. It will always be one of my favorite anime ever made.
To
                  be honest, this show isn't one I would recommend to someone for their first anime. The animation was absolutely stellar for its time, but like most other anime, it hasn't really aged that well. It's still good, but I would hold this one until you have had a few other shows first. This one is for the cultured that want to hear a creative music score in an intro, enjoyed Firefly, and love the idea of the wild west in space.
-See you space cowboy...

Hey there, i wanted to share my thoughts on this anime, i have to tell that my english isn't thaat good so there may be mistakes. I will divide this review from the best aspects to the "worst", if there is any.
Sound and OST (10/10) : What can i say about the OST, it's truly breathtaking. It's principally jazz and blues, and ocasionally other genres like metal or pop rock. This soundtrack success at making a moment not that amazing into a hole audiovisual experience.
Art (9/10) : I think the animation of CP it's incredible for 1998, specially the action scenes are wonderful. The enviroments
                  are beautiful, i like most of the character desings but i find it quite simple and not that atractives for my perception.
Character (8/10) : I actually loved the principal characters of the series, i have no complains about them, Spike being a person escaping from his past, love the Valentine's identity crisis and his resolution, Jet's backstory is quite enjoyable, Ed... well, she's just a child and there's not that much to say about her. But i have a little problem with some secondary characters, some of them aren't interesting at all and feel like filler characters. I'm specially talking about Abdul, Morgan, Maria, Mao, remember them? Yup, me neither.
Story (7/10) : Well, this may be an unpopular opinion, but let's get to it. Cowboy Bebop it's about the past, how it afects us, and how we deal with it, the story it's mainly about telling us little by little the past of the principal cast, throwing to us some facts about out characters in different "missions" and sub-plots. The only episodes that are only about Spike, it's the two last ones, and honestly, they're perfect and beautiful in all ways. But this anime is an episodic series, and that's, in my opinion, where the problem is, let me explain. Half of the episodes feels pointless, they are not telling us nothing about our characters, it just relays in subplots, some times they're really good, like the sect one, or reaaaally pointless and boring, this is really a hit or miss. I would give Cowboy Beebop a 10 if it all of those subplots were actually good.
Anyways, this anime is a "must watch", do not personally think of it as a masterpiece, but when it's good, IT'S REALLY GOOD. I recommend to watch it slowly and not swallow it in one sitting, because you may get a wrong idea of what CP is.

I do not give 10's lightly. However... sometimes, if I'm lucky, something comes along that changes me in a profound and special way. It comes in like a flash of lightning, and you know something will always be different once its gone. 
I originally added this to my "classics watchlist" at the beginning of quarantine last year. I knew it was beloved by anime veterans, but I know that a lot of the classics don't always hold up to new audiences. I've fallen for that trap in the past, and it's always frustrating when a well-loved show ends up falling flat after all the hype
                  I hear about it. However, Cowboy Bebop surprised me in one very important way: it lived up to my expectations, but did so in its own way. It wasn't what I was expecting, not even a little bit, but it now has a very special place in my heart.
At first glance, the art is definitely rough around the edges and has that "90's anime vibe", but the motion is fluid and the fight choreography tight and exciting to watch. You can tell a lot about each character by how they move and throw punches, which says a lot about the art direction and the skill of the animators. 
The music is godlike. Yoko Konno & The Seatbelts are legends for a reason, and I adore the western twang mixed with synthetic sounds and funky jazz. Every scene is immediately improved the moment the OST kicks in, and I doubt I would have loved this show as much as I do without their compositions. I suggest looking up "Too Good Too Bad" or "NY Rush" if you want a good taste.
Typically I am not a fan of episodic shows. I love epic sagas and self-contained slice of life stories with a clear rising action and resolution. As with most episodic shows, not every single episode was a winner for me However, Cowboy Bebop uses those episodic adventures to pour all of its love and attention into fleshing out its characters. 
And oh, what characters they are. This is the element that really takes center stage here: the character work is godlike. Then, when you slip into an uneasy feeling of affection for these people, the story roars in again at full throttle. I put it this way to a friend after finishing the how for the first time: By spending most of the show's runtime focused on their individual characters, the story can unfold without wasting any time.
This show is moody, depressing, and also more than a bit edgy. But there are also some episodes in here that made me laugh harder than I had in ages. This was the perfect quarantine companion for me, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who loves character-driven stories and classic sci-fi space-opera's.

Cowboy Bebop is about the life of average bounty hunters who have adventures around different planets and places in space, it is a very fun journey in which you learn more about the characters. which are endearing, are well developed throughout the plot and leave you wanting to know more about them.
This series touches on some rather philosophical and self-retrospective themes about the characters' past lives, each and every one of the protagonists has a past that they cannot let go, that haunts them to this day and that have an impact on both personal level as plot.
The development of the series is in an
                  episodic format, but every so often there will be small linear plots with respect to the protagonist.
It is a series that I highly recommend, it has a great soundtrack and a very fluid animation for action moments, the characters are fun, they have interesting interactions with the rest and the development of the story is great, it tells the story in a very subtle way and you have to tie loose ends, if you liked everything I told you before you should see Cowboy Bebop.
Cowboy Bebop trata de la vida de unos caza recompensas promedio que tienen aventuras por distintos planetas y lugares del espacio, es un viaje muy divertido en el cual aprendes mas de los personajes. los cuales son entrañables, son bien desarrollados a la larga de la trama y te dejan con ganas de saber mas sobre ellos.
Esta serie toca algunos temas mas bien filosóficos y auto retrospectivos sobre la vida pasada de los personajes, todos y cada uno de los protagonistas tienen un pasado que no pueden dejar ir, que los atormenta hasta el día de hoy y que tienen un impacto tanto a nivel personal como argumental.
El desarrollo de la serie es en un formato episódico, pero cada tanto van a haber pequeñas tramas lineales con respecto al protagonista.
Es una serie que recomiendo mucho, tiene una gran banda sonora y una animación muy fluida para los momentos de acción, los personajes son divertidos, tienen interacciones interesantes con el resto y el desarrollo de la historia es genial, cuenta la historia de manera muy sutil y tienes que atar cabos sueltos, si todo lo previo que te conté te gusto deberías ver Cowboy Bebop.
See you later Space Cowboy

lutôt disappointed by this series which is correct but does not deserve its place in the Top 111.
The main fault is a very flat scenario. Almost all episodes are interchangeable because there is no progression. The characters evolve very little. Here is for example the plot of an episode: the hero falls by chance on a psychopathic killer. The hero manages to escape. The killer invites the hero to find him to finish. The hero accepts and kills the psychopath a little by chance. End of the episode.
It remains of course that the music, the action scenes and the universe are really cool. But the
                  Space Cowboy deserved better stories.
Or I play devil’s advocate and I say that the message of the show is that in a world devoid of meaning and values, there remains the quest for food (a leitmotiv of the characters) and the cool of space gunfights.
See you, Space Cowboy

Such an incredible anime. Every character is extremely well developed throughout the course of the short 1 season, as the mystery of each individual past is slowly unveiled in a cryptic, fragmented way that keeps you guessing. Spike, Jet, and Faye all have very interesting and different character designs, and the mystery that the show envelops their origins in is truly captivating.
What truly steals the show for me, though, are the episodes where Spike and Vicious clash; the two feel so different yet similar. The settings and atmosphere of these episodes are extremely memorable as well, as the church where their first fight occurs and
                  the snowy, cold landscape (in which spike changes his wardrobe for the only time) are two of the most memorable motifs in the entire run. The Red Dragons have such an interesting power dynamic that becomes revealed near the end, and Julia's effect on Spike develops his character even more: from careless and detached to emotionally numb due to his troubled past.
The ending is truly shocking and abrupt but is beautiful and a great conclusion to the tale. Spike being killed after slaying everyone who caused his past trauma is very dark but fitting. In the end, everyone takes their new family and home for granted and chases old things that aren't coming back.
The visuals and soundtrack build a complete and captivating world in only twenty-something episodes, which is a feat in itself. The gorgeous 90s style artwork and animation are perfectly complemented by what is in my opinion the greatest soundtrack that I've encountered thus far in any form of Television or film. The blues and jazz influences make for some incredibly memorable sequences and really enhance the atmosphere and emotional beats. 
Pretty much perfection.

Cowboy bebop is a western-inspired anime series and probably one of the first anime to come to your mind when you think of classic. 
The story is simple enough, we have our group Faye, Spike, Jet, Ed and Ein who are bounty hunters in 2071. This is an episodic anime which means some episodes might or might not have some relation between them but each one is just about hunting a bounty-holder. Do not expect much plot, as much of the series is just hunting people, dialogue and story. These kinds of anime tend to get horrendously boring and repetitive but cowboy bebop managed to
                  make 26 original and fun episodes. The dialogue is just amazing, I loved the quotes and way of talking too. The anime is also pretty groundbreaking for 1999, with lots of homosexual characters, tons of black ones and overall a pretty revolutionary anime with lots of messages and comedy. The story is a 9
This anime aired in 1998-1999, the quality is quite good for that time. Not only is the anime really crisp but the quality of the art also is pretty good. The animation is smooth and all the characters look great. The anime had some fanservice too which is always helpful. 9/10
The op of the series is tank. You must have heard of it from some friend or seen it in a top anime op list. Tbh it is not THAT good, it is iconic and the song on the background is pretty cool but there are no voices except from the very start and it isn't that good overall, pretty overrated, would say it is an 8.5/10, there are 3 endings for the series.	First, "The Real Folk Blues". Pretty fine song and visuals 8.
Secondly "Space Lion" (ep 13) not that great, it looks fine but the song is not too good 7/10. Third is "Blue" (ep 26), pretty average too 7/10. The voice acting is great. Sound is an 8/10
The characters of this anime have non matching personalities but they all fit together somehow, they all have their cool pasts and stories to tell. Each one has their charisma and good points. Just like the anime, these are some classic and iconic characters. Would say 9/10
I enjoyed watching Cowboy Bebop quite a bit, it was packed with jokes, interesting characters, good writing, cool and sentimental story and overall high quality and effort production. 
Even then, it did have some flaws like not having enough plot and not all episodes were 10/10, some were just fine or great. For these reasons I must give Cowboy Bebop a 9/10 (9.5).

Cowboy Bebop feels like Avatar the Last Airbender. I have never watched Avatar the Last Airbender, but I know it is about a million episodes long. This kind of structure lets you make a bunch of nonsense filler episodes and then have a few episodes of plot, and you can take as much time as you want to flesh all of the characters out. Cowboy Bebop is where you follow that formula exactly, but you try to do it in 26 episodes rather than 100. 
As I am writing this I am tempted to dock it because Cowboy Bebop doesn't really have a story, certainly
                  not an engaging one. There is a love interest, and she is never developed meaningfully at all. The love interest is only developed by you being repeatedly told she is a love interest. In fact, Cowboy Bebop's approach to storytelling is mostly "This is what is happening." Practically every episode is a new character, a new plot, and it is compressed into a tiny little blurb that doesn't say much in the end. There isn't any room for subtlety in this story. Things just happen, and you just kind of have to accept them. They aren't well-developed, and they won't become well-developed later.
No one has clear motivations, or really any motivations. 
Cowboy Bebop is pretty though. It isn't extremely well-animated, but it is incredibly beautiful at times. Probably the most beautiful anime I have ever seen. The characters are pretty too: they are all very likable. Again, they don't have very much character, but if you take liberties you can imagine quite a lot to them, and the little bits they do have are quite nice if you look at them in the right light. This is similarly why I gave the story such a high score even though it is very lacking in structure/substance: it is a pretty story too. The universe of Cowboy Bebop is interesting, and the things they are going to do are interesting. The writers didn't write anything stupid; they just didn't write anything special. Basically, if you don't really care for story but need at least an honest attempt, Cowboy Bebop could very well be a perfect ten for you.
Here is some extra review:
Cowboy Bebop's music is okay. I don't care for jazz, so the whole "It's so different and jazzy" thing is totally lost on me. It is good and nice, but is often awkwardly bombastic at times. I didn't really care for the endings of every episode. Not even really foreshadowing as much as its just blunt and overbearing. I like the opening enough, it is pretty and has nice music.
