                  as music its a job well done.😄

Wow where do I even start...
Cowboy Bebop was an anime that I was very prejudiced about because I don't like neither space nor old animes. I hate space theme I didn't even watch Star Wars. If you ask why I don't like old animes. It's simply because the animations dont buy me most of the time. But this anime was an exception I wasn't ready for...
Story: (10/10)
Cowboy Bebop is about a crew of bounty hunters in space, it takes place in year 2071. Crew is first found by Jet Black and Spike Spiegel and as time goes on new people join. They are living a
                  hard life sometimes not being able to eat anything for days. They are trying to survive and have fun along the way. In  this show every character has their own story. They are going through their own hardships in their minds and lives. 
The series has an episodic form which I normally hate but again this show is such an exception.
Characters: (10/10)
Cowboy Bebop sold itself to me when I saw that classic scene of Spike Spiegel "Whatever happens, happens." I love carefree characters because I feel closer to them. Spike is one of the most carefree characters you'll see in anime world this trait most of the time makes him the funniest guy on the squad. But as series goes on you see what Spike gone and goes through, what his goal in life is and you love every second he is on screen.
Ship's leader, Jet Black is a man of duty. He is an old cop that left the job after realising the cops were getting corrupt. He then gone on to be a bounty hunter meeting Spike on the way and taking him to his ship Bebop. He is the leader and father of the group, he always does his best to keep everyone together whilst going through his problems.
Faye, the arrogant woman of the ship as Spike says. She seems like a loose bomb doing whatever she wants, coming and going out the ship without giving any notice most of the time and she is a gold digger. Everything is in place to hate her. But you can't, you just can't. Her character developement is amazing, you see her getting more and more connected to the crew and seeing the crew as her family. 
Ed, The genius kid. She is definitely the funniest girl in the crew. She is a genius hacker that can get into anything and everything. When you see her on screen you start smiling immidieatly because her character is so likeable and so childlike in such a cruel world that you love it.
Ein, The data dog. Well Ein is the smartest dog. I'd love to talk more about Ein but to be honest it doesn't really add much to story as it's a dog and I don't wanna bore you. So moving on!
There are more characters to talk about that are very well designed indeed but I'm trying my best to make this as spoiler-free as possible so I reccomend you watch the show and see the other characters first hand.
Sound: (10/10)
I never really cared about music in anime not gonna lie. But this anime raised my expectations of music in anime so high... After finishing the show I added 12 of the soundtracks to my spotify. I've never done something like that before in my life. Music is such an amazing part of this anime I don't think words will be enough to describe.
Art: (10/10)
This anime was made in 1998. And it's animation quality is on par with todays. The fighting scenes are amazing, the scenery, the cinematography. It's so beautiful that most of the time  I felt like I was watching a movie. The dark tone of the anime matches the problems characters are going through and fits the anime perfectly.
Overall: (10/10)
I doubt I'll give anything other than Death Note and Cowboy Bebop a 10/10. It's a masterpiece in my opinion but at worst it's still a must watch show. Hope you liked my review!

Cowboy Bebop is an old anime set in the distant future where interplanetary travel is possible. The plot focuses on the adventures of a group of space bounty hunters who are completing missions (some successful and others not so much).
Most episodes tend to be self-contained and don't develop the characters until the final chapters.
My opinion:
Plot → I don't usually like anime whose plot doesn't progress in a linear fashion. Until the final chapters nothing interesting happens.
Setting → I don't really like science fiction or the futuristic either
Characters → Although they are objectively well written, their development does not occur until almost the end of the
                  work, where they explain their origins.
Conclusion: In general, it was a boring anime for me, since it gives the feeling that there is no interesting plot to follow. The highlight is the past of the characters, but this is not explained until the last chapters. If the beginning of a series doesn't grab you, it's hard to get to the end to discover the true potential of this work.
Final score: 7

Needless to say, Cowboy Bebop is one of the classics. The show is much ahead of its time, unaffected by the generation gap. It is set in a futuristic backdrop where the Earth has become kind of a junkyard and humanity is not restricted to a single planet.
Spike Spiegel and Jet Black are partners in such an environment, who make their living by hunting bounties, like space cowboys. This is one interesting oxymoron as it brings together the two opposing concepts of western countryside cowboys chasing after criminals across the galaxy, riding their spaceships. Each episode brings to us a new adventure that takes Spike
                  and Jet after a new bounty, picking up the other crew members on the way- Ein (the doggo), Edward (the kid), and Fay Valentine. Though it may not be the perfect team with perfect coordination, each member has a unique role to play, that brings them together…or maybe not, but hey, that’s what makes it different and interesting to watch!
We see information from the characters’ past, spread unevenly in bits and pieces, which starts to make sense as the story progresses. The characters are given depth, instead of portraying them as the typical tsundere or the undefeated fighting master.
Considering the late 90s, the art is amazing and appeals to the aesthetic sense which was the first thing that compelled me to watch this show.
The antagonist arc was not too strong, but in the end, it was not about defeating the last boss or a happily ever after; it was all about the friends we made along the way! 😊  
Story: 8/10
Enjoyment: 9/10
Characters: 10/10
Art: 9/10
Soundtracks: 11/10
Ending: Cracked screen/ 10
Overall: 10/10

Here it is, the big kahuna. The single anime many believe to be the best ever made, topping list after list that I've seen. Finally, I get around to watching it and oh my god.
The blues is such a perfect soundtrack in keeping with the pace of the show. The characters, flushed out slowly and brilliantly, never learning too much about one character until the right moment. The plot, keeping you entertained while slowly building up the setting and people in it. The animation, looking absolutely stellar for the time. The dub voice actors, which many believe to be the superior version in this case,
                  conveying emotion and always this underlying mysteriousness. It all combines to become an absolute blast to watch.
I fell in love in the first 10 minutes, the show hooking me instantaneously. If I could have a favorite character, it would most likely be Edward since she is one wacky girl and absolutely hysterical. The plot continued to evolve, teaching important lessons along the way until the pulse-pounding conclusion that will leave you just speechless. I knew many of the plot spoilers going into it, but the show was still enjoyable to watch nonetheless. 
Recommended to any anime fan who has not yet seen this, as it is a most definitely a must-watch.

What can I say, it is a work that when you start you do not know what you will see, at least it was my case. Everything that he poses to us in each episode he does in a sublime way, they took the time to develop each element such as the environment and its characters. With the music used I am not very familiar with it, sometimes there are scenes that needed some background, but it is just a whim of mine,
There are also in scenes that silence symbolizes a lot while we see a panoramic view of the characters talking. My favorite character,
                  I can say that I like everyone, everyone contributes what is necessary and I really like the main group when they work together. and it is simply a series that I would see again.

Cowboy bebop focuses mainly on animation and soundtrack but that's what makes it special.
animation and soundtrack are just wonderful, bold, unique, evocative. Both fit perfectly despite being from 2 different worlds. Probably if you only listened to the soundtrack without seeing the anime you would have a completely different idea of the anime environment. If you read the cowboy bebop manga without seeing the anime there is little chance of guessing the background of the soundtrack. they are without a doubt its strongest point and for that in my opinion is already a good reason to give this anime a chance.
Another strong point are the
                  characters, and I'm not talking about their past, their experiences, etc. I'm talking about the characters themselves, the way they are portrayed,s, the essence of their being that leads you to know what their next adventure will be even in the leastgood episodes. You know that if you were part of their group you wouldn't spend a dull moment and you'd feel like you're in a family, a family that has been consolidated episode after episode, a family shaped by Jet as a sort of father figure, Faye as the daughter in her moment of rebellion, Spike as the mysterious son who doesn't keep to himself and you don't know what he's thinking and Ed as the little sister playing with the sweet Ein.
Together they have their funny, action, cool, sad and even boring moments but you're ready to forgive them that maybe in some episodes they didn't give you your dose of coolness because you're simply won over by their substance, kind of like when you keep being in love with an attractive person even though they've hurt you.
However If we penetrate more into the anime structure and the characther’s pasts we find some flaws that I can no longer overlook.
Cowboy Bebop is an anime made up of almost all indipendent episodes that illustrate the story of our bounty hunters chasing bad guys for money and failing maybe more than half the time. These episodes are some good, some average and some just plain bad.
Only a few episodes try to make a fixed thread every now and then scattered in the rest of the independent episodes telling the past of the 4 main characters.
Obviously I preferred this kind of episodes compared to the "filler" ones even if Jet's plot doesn't ring a bell to me. I like the character but only that.
Ed's past was good and yet the anime only devotes 3 episodes to her I think they are well constructed. The first 2 moments of Ed in the spotlight are pretty funny. I especially like how the music, the vibes, the whole atmosphere of the anime change when this character becomes the main character for 20 minutes. It's as if Ed's entire personality has influenced the events happening around her. Her third to last dedicatory episode as well as the third to last of the anime is just heartbreaking....
Spike's moments have the best action scenes although these are constant throughout the anime; the animation and soundtrack are breathtaking especially in these scenes. With Spike the anime introduces us to, let's say the main villain although I dare say an average villain. He's just typical white-haired guy who used to be the main character's best friend but for some reason now they want to kill each other. Sort of like Griffiht (or if you prefer Ryou Asuka) but boring. Eventually, in the last episode, Spike's story descends into an average revenge story.
Faye's past is the most interesting and in which I showed more interest because it had more complex and more intriguing puzzles. Another point to its advantage is that the pursuit of her goal seems more human, more natural, so that in a way you feel in Faey's shoes. Certainly not on such a tragic scale, but haven't you ever felt moved when you return to a place you haven't been for years?
The problem with Spike and Faye's stories is that they tried to be deep, but the inconsistency with which both are told ruins everything. The anime doesn't give them enough time to develop into strong, deep stories.
I know it's an episode/character driven show, less about the plot and more about the cool stuff happenning, but there are anime like The Great Pretender, which has a very similar structure to Cowboy Bebop, that is more concerned about its characters, their development, and makes us understand more about the motivations for their actions and decisions.
well, despite its flaws cowboy bebop is an experience not to be missed for its creativity and the audacity to try something exclusive and uncommon audiovisually.

Cowboy Bebop is in the unique situation of being a bit too immature to be considered a Seinen, yet just dramatic enough to be considered a really great Shonen at the same time. Despite the fact that the narrative on the surface is rather straightforward, the anime's characters are what actually carry the program. In terms of introducing the characters, the program does an excellent job without resorting to exposition. As a result, we, as an audience that has invested in the program, are interested in seeing where these characters end up in the future. In order to keep the story from becoming imbalanced, each
                  character that is subsequently introduced has their own moment to shine in the spotlight. Even though the anime's plot twists and turns towards the finish, it is worth the viewer's time to see it through to the end. The anime does an excellent job of not taking itself too seriously, resulting in a number of hilarious moments that do not detract from the overall tone of Doom. It results in a program that is both fascinating and entertaining to watch.

Everything was outstanding except the story. Although it is still great, it just isn't that explained. Like nobody says a thing about what you see less then one second but it still is important. If you watch with a lot of attention you will understand it but I still belief  it could have been better. The ending is very good and I am happy with it. As for the characters it's a 10. Everyone is just interesting and all have their backstories and different relations to each other. This is for sure a must watch, if you don't like the old anime style or
                  the smaller frame, you should still try.

"Are you living in the real world?"
I was still in my tens when this anime came out. When I was becoming more interested in anime, this title was in my watch list. I'm glad I did not pressed the play button for this back then.
This anime is like whisky. Because you need to let it age to flavour the peak of a perfect taste. I have known this anime for a long time, but back then I knew what I needed to do. I literally waited until I was just old enough to watch this.
I waited until I developed a good palate with the recollections
                  that real life has to offer.
Now, when I started this, for every single episode I watched, I was literally reminiscing many things in my life. That's why I couldn't binge watch this. There was more in the story that I took a weekly basis to complete this. Watching this felt like looking at an old album of photos. Every picture you see is full of feelings and thoughts. The philosophical standpoint of this title is made like that. The tone, the music, the art, the whole development will make you feel real folk blues. I can't express it in other way. 
My final recommendation, for everyone out there that have accumulated enough years on pressing the flesh and trailing the town streets, just don't grow old enough without watching this masterpiece.

rare shows come along such as this that manage to deftly balance sincere deconstruction of their genre while simultaneously reveling in the bombast of their unique vision and interpretation. what hasn't been said about bebop that hasn't already been said about the show for decades at this point? it maybe plays a little too fast and loose in it's stereotypes, if you look at it from a distance, but always treats it's characters with a baseline humanity most of it's contemporaries lack. masterpiece of a show. an absolute watermark in animation, sound tracking & character drama. the kinda thing you just need in your life.

Part of me feels like reviewing a show like 'Cowboy Bebop' is a little redundant. I'm well aware I'm very late to the game with this show, I've been watching anime for, I'd imagine, 7/8 years now, and I'm only just watching it now. And that means that I can't avoid feeling a little like everything that could be said about this show has been said. But I do still feel like I want to talk about some of my thoughts (others I'll have to keep for arenas without rules against spoilers).
Obviously, this show is pretty incredible. The tone and world is like nothing else
                  in anime, perhaps anything else in storytelling, the characters are iconic beginning to end. The animation still looks fantastic by modern standards, Yoko Kanno's soundtrack is one of the all-time greats, the direction is artistically charged whether the story is taking us to its dramatic extremes or just sitting with the characters eating. Each episode feels unique and precisely put together, and pretty much every one of them turns out near perfectly. 
The idea of this show as 'space jazz', in contrast with a Space Opera, feels incredibly apt and somehow manages to make perfect sense; the almost free-form storytelling, off-beat yet incredibly coherent. It's like nothing else out there. 
Honestly, I went through most of this show entirely expecting it to hit the right beats for me to brand it a 9/10, one of my all-time favourite shows. As you can see, I haven't. Because, and this isn't the first time this happened for me, I just... I didn't quite click with the ending. The ending isn't unearned, by any stretch; this isn't a 'Revolutionary Girl Utena' situation, where the ending felt SO dissonant to the rest of the story, to the point where it actively ruined the show's message. I can't say the way things pan out aren't consistent, aren't earned, that the show isn't playing totally fair. But I still can't help but wonder what to take from the ending. At end of the day, good or bad, I think a good ending needs to put the character's journey out in front of them, show the audience how they've changed and developed over the story. That definitely doesn't have to be in a good way; I'm not here complaining about, like, MacBeth or Othello. But I like to at least feel like the things that happened mattered in the end. And, where this ending is concerned... I'm just not sure they did. I don't feel like the Spike Spiegel we say goodbye to in the final episode has meaningfully changed in any way. And that's a shame, because everything inbetween is SO good, so immaculately put together, so exciting and funny and resonant, that I feel it deserved more than the way things ended. 
And hey, maybe that's the point. The dissatisfaction, the muted tragedy, the anti-climax. I can certainly see readings where that has its own message in it. But I can't pretend that the final episode wasn't the first time in this series that I didn't come out of an episode feeling ultimately satisfied.
Again, thought, this isn't 'Revolutionary Girl Utena'. With that, my issues with the ending really did spoil my feelings on the show as a whole. I still had a phenomenal time watching 'Cowboy Bebop', I still loved the characters and the adventures and the stories told in this incredible world, and the ending does nothing to change that. I'm still incredibly glad I finally got to experience what really is one of the artistic heights of anime as a medium, and I'm glad it exists. So, while it may have not tipped itself over into that oh-so-rare 'nines' list, I still have to love this crazy ride.
See you, space cowboy...

The second anime I ever watched and as of now it's my favorite. I haven't seen that many but I love this show so much I don't see it getting passed by anything. Just an absolute masterpiece of a show. As much as I would've loved to see more with these characters, this story is so perfect that I don't mind. Spike is the perfect protagonist and the rest of the bebop crew fits in the series so well. One of my favorite shows in general of all time. And oh my god the soundtrack is just perfect. The opening theme to this show is
                  one of my favorite songs of all time its just perfect. The rest of the show is wonderfully scored with just the right track for every moment throughout the entire series. I can't seem to think of any flaws in this masterpiece.

See you again space cowboy….
Had the opportunity to watch the classic anime that is beloved by many.
The story is mostly through single episode adventure that showed Spike and his crew going through life collecting bounties. I definitely like the cool and chill vibe throughout the show. However, my problem is that I didn’t see a complete story that I could follow. I didn’t find a lot of thrills in many of the single episode. Still, there were still episodes that were exciting and made me think about the message of the show. There was an overarching story, but I would prefer that there were more
                  times dedicating to this main story.
Of course the best thing about this show was the music. The opening was for sure one the best. It was so cool and definitely got me excited. Then, the music within the show was just as dope and create a unique vibe to each episode. This reminds me a bit of Megalobox, which also has fun and variable genres of songs. 
The four main characters had great chemistry with each other and created comedic moments. They also each had interesting backstories, but the show revealed little, more like a quick glimpse, of each character, and I can’t help but desire more. Eh maybe that’s not the point of the show.
Overall, I enjoyed part of the show, mainly for its music and entertaining characters. 7/10

10/10
Cowboy Bebop... man this really is something. The main character (spike) is one of the greatest anime protagonists of all time, and Vicious fills all the checks a villain should have in an anime. And if anyone didnt watch this, i recommend to watch this in English Dub version, that feels like a classic movie. 
This anime is one of the best anime's to binge watch (I finished it in 1 day). Has to be one of the 15 greatest anime ever. 
The last few episodes were really touching, and everyone watching could feel it. 
Highly recommended to everyone who still hasnt watched this masterpiece

Honest to God one of the best forms of media I've the pleasure to have witnessed. Let me start off with the story. The lack of a a continuous narrative, barring the 6 or Spike-orientated episodes which I'll touch on later, allows an episodic approach to a series. This works in Bebop's favor as each episode can be set on a different planet, allowing for fantastic world building and characterization. It also gives each episode something unique to it. Now, being a 90's anime the level of animation was nothing like it is today, but that is part of the charm of Bebop. It would
                  look off had it been re-animated and given modern effects. A benefit of the 90's style is that it allows Cowboy Bebop the opportunity to be what it wants. A space-western. That's the best I can describe it. Next up is sound. Sound...music. The soundtrack. Rain is a fantastic and haunting song with a guitar solo that fits the tone without removing from the song. The soundtrack by seatbelts is up with the Evangelion's and FLCL's as the best. Let me say this; Jazz is not easy to nail. Mix in a James Bond-like loop of horns and you've got TANK!, the second best opener (Evangelion is 1) of all time. Cosmos is great, Memory is melancholic yet nostalgic, and every track is fantastic, but the sound is above and beyond the time, most likely on par with something form the 2004-2008 era of sound design in anime, so needless to say, it to, is ahead of its time. Last we come to the Characters. Jet, my least favorite. He seems to be the calm to Spike's storm. Jet is by no means a bland character in the least, just I find the other cast more interesting. Jet seems to fill a stereotype at first but then we learn about his backstory and his... but that would be spoilers ;)... and he suddenly becomes this man we can empathize with and relate to his struggle. Next is Edward. Edward seems so out of place on this lonely and melancholic spaceship due to his... everything. His design is bright and cheerful compared to the washed out colors of the rest, and then his animation is also a lot more fluid-like, I guess. Ed brings Ein who could've been more developed. seriously. Then there's Faye who, to avoid spoilers I'll say this: she is heartbreaking. Spike is our fast talking master of fighting and seems to be the driving force of the Bebop. Saying anymore would likely get this review taken down again, but needless to say, Cowboy Bebop is a treasure. See you, Space Cowboy.

Thanks to Cartoon Network's Toonami programming block in the early 2000s, I was introduced to this phenomenal anime as a child. This would be the second anime I ever watched, second to Dragon Ball, but Cowboy Bebop would be the first anime I would obsess over. I would use my father's computer to access online forums in order to keep with the narrative, as watching two episodes a week was simply not enough. This sci-fi western is absolutely fantastic, filled with great voice acting and wonderful, fitting music. I am so lucky to say that this was my official introduction to the world of anime,
                  and I suggest this series to everyone, anime fan or not. The rich and emotional stories within this series transcends media barriers.
